title: The Princess Bride: S. Morgenstern's Classic Tale of True Love and High Adventure
author: William Goldman
my_review:
I've seen the movie, obviously, and it was fun. It's hard to disentangle the nostalgia of the movie from the reading experience. The novel certain has an interesting framing, with the story within a story, and the whole meta conversation.

But unique framings are not enough to get a high rating. Novels should be interesting or compelling or exciting or thoughtful or funny, or anything damn it. And I just don't know that I got much from this. I don't remember laughing at any point. I don't remember thinking deeply. I don't remember being excited or eagerly waiting so see what was next.

On top of this, the book has some real issues. Every female character in the entire novel is somehow utilized for her sex appeal. The starlet at the beginning exists exclusively to be sexy and tempt our main character, and to frame his as a powerful man in film. The lawyer at the ending exists exclusively to be sexy and tempt our main character. Before you protest that she has agency, any real conflict she brings to the story isn't her own, it's at the leisure of another man, Stephen King, to resolve. The countess in the book exists to be alluring and rich and to tempt the FMC's love interest. The FMC herself exists explicitly to be beautiful and sexy and tempt literally everyone. And the continuation in Buttercup's Baby is no improvement -- Indigo's love interest doesn't merely exist to be sexy, she is quite literally the explicit manifestation of his fantasies.

For a book that drones on and on about true love, it sure does manage to marginalize it. There's a fascinating aspect to love -- that we hold it in higher esteem when it is undeserved.

Reading this, I don't see any valuable love. I see cheap and obvious love. I find myself thinking, "Oh, so you love the literal most beautiful woman on earth? Good for you, who wouldn't?" "Oh, so you love the man who beat the best fencer, then the most intelligent criminal, then the strongest giant, who became the rich and famous pirate captain, is a natural leader, owns boat, who braves death to find you, who's actual catchphrase is 'as you wish?'" Girl, that's not love, that common sense.

It should be noted that our male love intrest is the smartest, strongest, and most capable man on earth, and our female love interest is a little dumb, but by golly she sure is the most physically attractive girl on earth.

I'm sure there is someone out there smiling at my naive inability to recognize satire when it stares me in the face, but I can hardly justify the label when the gross tropes are accompanied by no cutting bite.

I had originally given this 3 stars, but after thinking about it more, I've dropped to 2.

I don't mind killing a girl. God does it all the time, and if it doesn't bother him, then why let it bother you.

title: Roadside Picnic
author: Arkady Strugatsky
my_review:
A weird and interesting book that was genuinely compelling. I hesitate a little bit in giving it a full 5 stars, maybe it should really have 4.5 rounded down, but I wanted it to be distinguished from my sea of 4 star ratings. Sadly I forgot to take any notes while reading it, so I'll go off my memory.

I really like the idea of the aliens coming and leaving their random garbage and changing our civilization. The extreme _wierdness_ of the zone, and the strange personalities who leech off it. I always love a book that can throw you into a weird and grungy world head first, and this accomplishes that admirably. I'm trying to figure what exactly drew me to it, why it compelled, outside of simply listing the style.

I really loved the ambiguous ending.

I should note that this book has some definite sexualization of all the female characters -- they hardly feel like people -- but this is a small enough part of the book to not bother me overmuch.

The narrator, Robert Forster, I think, was absolutely excellent. He carried the excitement with breathtaking brilliance.

It was once said, and very rightly, that a man who is well-brought-up may read anything.


Bit of a scattered review here, I know. Maybe I'll think on it a little and come back. It's a solid sci-fi recommendation though.

title: The Sirens of Titan
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.
my_review:
I remember reading some more mainstream Kurt Vonnegut about a decade ago and really enjoying it. This book has all the weirdness I remember from other Vonnegut reads, but I just didn't find it compelling.

There is some interesting thinking in here, that was perhaps very new to the 1950s, but seems somewhat pedestrian to my modern knowledge-base. For instance the idea that we intentionally unite humanity by artificially creating a trivial common enemy (chatgpt informs me that Unite and Conquer had this plot as far back as 1948 tho).

There's a cruel irony to the man who has everything being shown beauty he can't have, and when he finally obtains it it languishes under muck at the bottom of a pool. I mean, the whole novel is basically a set of cruel ironies.

The idea of existing punctually vs infinitely temporally is interesting. There's a pleasing futility in the idea of the human race being a trivial messaging apparatus for a robot delivering a period to another star system. I think you can see the influences of this book on Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy. Actually, after a bit of research, Adams explicitly stated that he read Sirens of Titan SIX times and that it was an influence.

Adam's says that he likes the kind of scifi that lets you stand far outside of human life and reinterpret it.

It is interesting to ponder this, because intellectually I see what Vonnegut was trying to do, but I simply don't like the book. Meanwhile, I quite enjoyed HGTTG. I suppose we stand on the shoulder's of giants.

I was originally going to give this a 2.5 rounded down, but I think it has enough merit intellectually to deserve a 3.

title: Binti (Binti, #1)
author: Nnedi Okorafor
my_review:
This was an interesting an unique story that tried to deal with themes of cultural isolation and belonging. It struggled both as a story in general and to accomplish it's thematic goals.

As a story, it struggled to be believable. There's a scene where our FMC realizes that she can talk to the bloodthirsty monsters, and they are actual sane and capable of conversation. She is the smartest in her tribe, an expert at harmony, selected to attend a premier university...and she totally neglects to engage in any meaningful conversation whatsoever. "why are you killing us, how can we end the bloodshed, where do you come from, let me tell you about my people" We get absolutely none of this until the almighty instrument of plot sees fit to grace us with a dose of reality.

Then, the entire conceit of the conflict is based on lack of communication, which Binti solves with her magic and personal nature...until we arrive on the planet and it turns out there is a second alien who can casually speak in the language of the bad guys. Why was there ever any conflict if we could speak their language the whole time??

Thematically, I never really got to the point where I cared about her or her people. Her isolation was told, not felt. Then, there were key moment where she could have had a meaningful struggle to work through but simply didn't. When making her red clay paint, she could have failed, which would have been philosophically interesting, but didn't. This may have been ok, but then to test both the wholeness of the clay and her value as a person instead of a tool, she uses it to heal the alien. This could have failed, but again didn't. Both of these successes really robbed the plot of meaningful challenge, and the story of depth.

Anyway, I don't regret reading it, but it wouldn't go on any recommendation list, and I won't trust this author with any more of my time.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
my_review:
4.5, maybe even 5. What a masterfully crafted novel. It's simply amazing how awful all these people are, and yet how the author makes them seem somehow real, instead of trivial caricatures. Each characterization feels strong, unique, and compelling.

I also appreciate how the author never feels the need to hold your hand. You learn that Gatsby is involved in shady business not because it is ever said out right, but through an accumulation of little evidences. The suspicion of other characters, the association with Wolfsheim, the nervous phone calls immediately hung up.

Anyway, this is a lightning fast read and an easy recommendation.


As for Tom, the fact that he “had some woman in New York” was really less surprising than that he had been depressed by a book. Something was making him nibble at the edge of stale ideas, as if his sturdy physical egotism no longer nourished his peremptory heart.



The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty.


Love the use of Platonic here. It speaks to an older time when philosophy was common learning.


I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child.

What an excellent emotion. To completely recharacterize your negative emotions with the after the realization of the complete worthlessness of the opposing party.

title: Divine Rivals (Letters of Enchantment, #1)
author: Rebecca   Ross
my_review:
This was fun. Not quite 4, maybe 3.5? I enjoyed the premise and the build up, and I felt the author wrote with great feeling and clarity, if at times self-indulgently. The last 100 or so pages somewhat fizzled for me -- after the big reveal, I rather felt all the tension had gone. I can't say that I have emotional investment in any accept the two main characters. FMC's friends and her landlady haven't really left an impression on me.

I didn't love the details of the ending, nor FMC's reaction to her brother. How hard would it really have been to bring MMC? I know that later they try to explain it all away with the stress of breaking free of the mind control, but while it was happening I was pulled out of the story by how annoyed I was.

Overall, the book was quick and enjoyable and I wouldn't mind reading more from this author.

title: The Buffalo Hunter Hunter
author: Stephen Graham Jones
my_review:
I read this book blind on recommendation from the person who recommended me The Incandescent. I did know that it was the horror genre, and a quick search told me (very, very wrongly) that the book had no gore.

Immediately, the writing was good. I think good writing speaks for itself, and it can make up for innumerable flaws. I didn't take as good notes as I meant to, but it has some moments where the language is just beautiful. There are some turns of phrase that are very suggestive without needing to spell everything out for you. I hugely appreciate an author that doesn't feel the need to hold your hand. At one point, he says he's worried about leaving the candles lit to come back to the church in flames, and his concern that he'll realize this is the proper home for one such as I. Which is a lovely sideways way of saying that he thinks that despite being a pastor, he deserves to burn in hell.

I like the indian's characterization of the crucifix. "You put reminders of pain on the wall and pray to them. We still hurt, so we don't need that reminder."

The writer captured the vibes really well. I don't know if I want to call it racism exactly, but the casual cultural ignorance and the pervasive stereotyping from all sides felt very accurate.

I can't say that I personally enjoyed the book. The characters we are reading about are ancient history, so there is no suspense and I can't be bothered to know what will happen to them. I wouldn't say the author telegraphs the plot, but if you are paying attention it is certainly obvious what is going to happen to grandpa. For horror, it certainly wasn't scary. Major, major gore warning.

3 starts because it was objectively good but I just didn't enjoy it and can't see myself recommending it to anyone.

title: The Incandescent
author: Emily  Tesh
my_review:
Quite a fun and inventive take on the endless magic school formula with some interesting musings on demons in the mix. The plot is rather telegraphed at times, but I don't think it is to the detriment of enjoyment.

"What I would say is morality is social. So it is very difficult to apply the rules of morality to an asocial creature."

I quite liked how demons were handled. How they gained a sense of self based on how the defined themselves, and how you could have an imp that was a copy machine demon, and then ultimately (spoilers) you could have a demon embedded in a teacher for 15 years become the territorially protective warden of an entire school.

I definitely has some moments of frustration. Like, holy red flag when she ignored the girl who wanted to ask about the book. And good lord can she please just tell this girl her life story.. But we are dealing with a character who is deliberately portrayed as less socially capable than her peers. She is outclassed in teaching by that one guy, and then she is consistently a social failure in relationships, so it I let a few of these irritations slide, since they jived pretty well with the character.

In general, the character's internal dialogs are good and they are enjoyable. It's cheesy at times, but it's also fun. At no point do you feel like the characters are making decisions that someone with that personality wouldn't really make.

It's easy to get wrapped up in the story too. At one point I wrote, "Man, you know you are in too deep when you get excited that she decides to wear her sleeveless dress _without_ the cardigan."

Tldr, the plot was good, the characters were good, the relationship was tolerable, it had excitement, and the magic was nice. The conclusion was good and I liked the Phoenix and the demon mentality exploration. This is a safe recommendation for an easy read.

title: Infinity Gate (Pandominion, #1)
author: M.R. Carey
my_review:
What a transparently stupid book. A bunch of ill-considered ideas masquerading as plot. You could be forgiven for thinking the author spent literally no time whatsoever thinking through the characters, the plot, or the ramifications.

I really hate reading a book and feeling like it is full of obvious holes, where there are really obvious ways a character or society would act, but they simply don't, in service to some clearly manufactured plot device.

You know, sometimes you can forgive a book for having one or two plot holes, if it manages to have excitement or engaging characters, but Infinity Gate manages to have neither.

This book is just one long complaint. I wrote an endless number of angry notes while reading it, and I don't honestly want to dignify this book with the mental energy required to consolidate them into a meaningfully coherent review, so I'll just list them as I wrote them in chronological order.

There is a unique pain in reading 'smart' characters written by morons. If I was a masochist, I'd have been in heaven. The main character -- a focused scientist who discovers travel between worlds with the help of an AI, is tortuous to read. In my own personal day job, I work with a parade of physicists and scientists of all colors on the latest AI topics, and so I feel qualified in saying that our main character is grotesquely unbelievable. She bears no resemblance whatsoever to an intelligent human being.

After spending days and weeks on a problem which is her direct area of research, she fails to come up with a solution (mapping the worlds based on initializing parameters) that I'm sure every mildly attentive reader could have given her after a couple minutes reading about her dilemma. She has to have this trivial solution spoon fed to her by an AI which she is reluctant to use.

Did I mention that she is essentially in a life or death situation on a dying world, and she doesn't want the help of a genius AI? But let's talk about how the branching works. She finds what are supposedly very close branches and instead of finding minor variations on our world, she finds different sentient species.

So, the supposition is that worlds branch at quantum decisions, which means that for a world to have a non-ape sentient species, the first branching would have needed to be millions of years ago, and untold trillions of quantum branchings in the past. So almost by definition, there is no way that you go to a close world and end up with anything other than humans.

Although the book dresses up the many world's theory in the guise of scientific legitimacy, the structure isn't even internally consistent. The reason there are sentient rabbits and cats is not because it remotely makes sense based on the explanations and internal logic of the book. It's because the author thought it would be cool.

Which like, if you want to write a book about sentient rabbits, then go for it. But don't waste our time proposing a mechanism that would obviously never result in the outcome you propose.

Oh yea, and I forgot the weird virtue signaling at the beginning of the book. It opens with 10 solid minutes of deeply boring exposition, then immediately they have a conversation where an AI has a female name. After a throwaway comment where it is accused that the namer must have given an almost sentient AI a female name because they think at some level that women are also only 'almost' sentient, we are then told that every time you name your code something female, you are drawing upon a problematic history. Which, sure, the gendered naming of AI assistants is certainly an interesting topic, but holy virtue signaling batman.

Ok, so then we see her leave her sentient AI alone on a dying planet with a room full of science equipment and drones it can control, and her last thought is, "wow I can't see how leaving a genius AI alone with the ability to travel the multiverse and send robots to other worlds could possibly result in anything happening".

Which like...wow. And later in the book, you realize that this wasn't even a death flag. The author was really was uncreative enough to think that the AI really couldn't do anything useful. If you can think of how an AI with god-like levels of processing in a scientific laboratory with multi-universe access and a fleet of sensor loaded drones with audio outputs could possibly get anything done, then my own creativity is at a loss as how to respond.

Then, our main character decides not to do a memory backup, because she felt like she would be leaving a small part of herself here on the dead world as a prisoner, and she would then always feel herself to be incomplete. This is absolute trollops. "Feel herself to be incomplete." Excuse me, WHAT? Yea, I know that I personally feel like every time someone takes my photo, it's like something was stolen from me. What a stupid like of reasoning from our supposedly highly analytical researcher.

Of course, the real reason she is thinking these things is not because it makes sense for her character, or because this is a reasonable thing that a human being would think. The reason is because this author writes his characters however he has to so that plot can happen later. Spoiler alert, I have now finished the book, and this is absolutely why the author wrote it this way.

Ok, so then we are treated to the hooker-slave character who is so obviously just misery porn as to leave me completely unfeeling. It's kinda gross that the author trivializes the real people who experience these kinds of lives by exploiting a shallow facsimile of their stories in his book.

Anyway, if our genius scientist can be comfortably called dim witted, then our slum dweller is a certified moron. At least the author is consistent. So he has access to a literal unlimited money printing machine, and his bright idea is that he is going to sell it? What does he think is going to happen to inflation when raw materials become meaningless?

Then after shenanigans, we get our introduction to the Pandemonium. The, as usual, unbearably ill-considered pandemonium. I'm not sure where to begin with the economics of having literally infinite resources -- both physical capital. Why do they not let in her world since she discovered step travel? Why do they go to worlds and kill people? Why is there literally _any_ resource conflict when there are infinite worlds? Why do they not have more technology? Why is there no system in place for onboarding worlds? How could they possibly manage to maintain control over jumping?

It's just that as soon as you start actually thinking about any part of anything, you are left with a million questions, and the feeling that if there actually was a multiverse, it wouldn't be anything at all like how it is described.

And as the story goes on, it's not even internally consistent, much less externally consistent. As a way to hand wave the glaring absence of any technologies meaningfully more advanced than what we have on earth -- despite literally infinite worlds to commune with -- we are told that when the pandomonium encounters civilizations more advanced than them, they leave them alone and go their separate ways. ...and yet, they come to a planet of borderline magical level machine being that can generate new machines out of nothing, and they are like, "yea, I know what to do. Let's pick a fight with a planet-wide, multiverse-spanning machine system that surpasses all our understanding."

No they fucking wouldn't. You don't simultaneously let sleeping bears lie and stab dragons in the face. There is literally an infinite number of planets. What possible reason could they have to burn resources attacking one that is clearly outside their understanding? They would never have gotten to the point where there were 10s of thousands of member worlds if this was how they operated. The story is just dumb.

Once again, the simple explanation for how a multiverse-spanning empire makes such a transparently ridiculous decision is not because of political machinations, or convincing characters, or being backed into a corner...it's because the author thought that would make a fun book.

I still have another couple pages of notes where I complain about swam intelligences, idiot rabbit characters, inconsistency of magical machine reconstitution, helpless super AIs, and ridiculous plot devices...but I am rather horrified at how much ink I've already spilled over this travesty of a novel, so I'll cut it short here.

I don't literally hate myself, so I obviously didn't read the sequel, but I did read the plot summary on Wikipedia to satisfy my morbid curiosity. And wow, it sounds even dumber and more contrived than the book I just finished.

I actually was originally going to give this 2 stars, but after writing this review and being reminded of how deeply frustrating this entire book was, I don't see how it deserves anything better than 1.

title: A Fire Upon the Deep (Zones of Thought, #1)
author: Vernor Vinge

title: The Mercy of Gods (The Captive's War, #1)
author: James S.A. Corey

title: Alien Clay
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
my_review:
I'm a bit conflicted on this one. The plot and the ideas were engaging and interesting, if a little predictable. And I certainly enjoyed myself reading it. But the author made some kind of strange choices with the narration. Maybe a 3.5 overall?

He would occasionally switch from the normal in the action story to a breaking the fourth wall past tense narration. You would feel like you were in the middle of the action, but then the narrator would suddenly say something like, "I didn't know it at the time, but ____ would be very important in my life later." It's hard to know exactly what Tchaikovsky was going for here, but in almost every instance, what it did for me was clumsily take me out of the story and remove elements of suspense.

I guess what I'm saying is this is not a book to read strictly for the writing. It's a book about fascism and living inside of it, and the author does good work on at least talking about (if not always making me _feel_) the horrible isolation and perpetual distrust of living in a police state where intellectual non-orthodoxy is a literal crime, and anyone you know might be a betrayer.

He weaves this dynamic integrally into the plot, with the first half of the book being riddled with uncertainty and its associated failures, and the last half with the shared knowledge of Kiln. I loved his final conversation with the head of the camp, where he struggles to find words that can communicate the way the spores allow him. The way the little misunderstanding of spoken language seem like an insurmountable gap in comprehension.


A couple of interesting quotes from the author:
"The greatest privilege of power is being able to overlook that you are even wielding it"
"Just because the tyrant is dressed as a clown doesn't make him funny"

These are quotes from his interview after the book:
" 'This could have been your greatest crowning achievement, but you chose to make it all about politics.' Thus says the politician when the scientist ventures an opinion"
"Authoritarian regimes tend to hate artists and intellectuals and academics, but at the same time, they really covet their endorsement and approval."


"It might seem odd, that a mild-mannered academic like me was also an active worker against the Mandate. But you’ve got to care about truth, haven’t you? I won’t say that the speeches didn’t move me, but it was the intellectual dishonesty of the whole orthodox thing that galled me into action. Science, as a creed, should care about truth. It shouldn’t be bent for political aims. You shouldn’t say there’s a Wild Man of Kiln when there’s clearly nothing of humanity about the place. And on such hills I die. That doubtless sounds stupid, to you who tell yourself you will take up arms when they starve your children, when they rob you of your goods, when they come for that demographic which includes you. But it’s deviation from truth that lets them do these things. It’s the lies, at all levels, which mean when they come for you and yours, the others won’t lift a finger, because they’ve believed the lies spread about you. It is the lies that starve your children because you believe the stories about general shortages, even though the grandees of the Mandate feast off gold plates every day of the year. And it is lies about science which cut most deeply, telling you that this or that group of people are naturally inferior, or another group has an innate ability to lead. That there is sufficient genetic distinction to make the call, when in actuality we share the vast bulk of our inheritance with mushrooms. Or else that, because of this kinship with mushrooms, our leaders are justified in keeping us in the dark and feeding us shit."

Love this quote.

title: The Library at Mount Char
author: Scott  Hawkins
my_review:
This is a pretty easy recommendation, a solid 4.25. Unique and engaging story with a satisfying plot and good closure.

The ending was fun and really wrapped up the story nicely. I think the character writing is also pretty good. There were quite a few scenes that really spoke to me that I took note of while reading, like the realism of him cussing out the lion.

I like how they blend in the magical realism. There's a kind of interesting way that the lion's understand their own speech, but only partially understand Steve.

The fights are good too. They do a great job with David, both in the jail scene and in the house scene. I remember really enjoying the house scene. Both the action of it and the way that what he really excels at is murder, and not at actually saving everyone. I will say that I felt like there was one plot hole here -- why did the future girl never raise the red flag?

The writing in general was just really engaging. The way they slowly build up Carolyn. My intense dread as I wait for Steve to fuck everything up because of his _feelings_. The author switches points of views just the right amount and at just the right times to build suspense and action.

Overall a short, fun, and unique book. The sort of thing to get you out of a slump.

title: Destiny Disrupted: A History of the World Through Islamic Eyes
author: Tamim Ansary

title: The Woman They Could Not Silence: One Woman, Her Incredible Fight for Freedom, and the Men Who Tried to Make Her Disappear
author: Kate  Moore

title: Autumn in the Heavenly Kingdom: China, the West, and the Epic Story of the Taiping Civil War
author: Stephen R. Platt

title: Kaiju: Battlefield Surgeon
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review:
3.5 rounded down, mostly because I use fours as easy recommendations, and this definitely isn't. I enjoyed this book. It's exciting and fun in the same way that DCC is. It also feels much less rambling and never-ending -- it was so great to just read through, have fun, and finish the story. At times the gore was a bit too much for me, I skipped a couple parts, maybe about 5 minutes worth of the book?

As usual, I think Dinniman could really use an editor to tighten up some of the story lines and logic. Some of the stuff just felt kind of off. Like how we had a magic scalpel hand but then ditched it for the ascension knife. Or how I couldn't never quite get a grasp on whether he could shrug off insane monster attacks or if a 30 foot fall would break his bones.

I did think the story was fun -- the entire premise with the pods and being stuck in there with the half crazy girl. The twist at the end was fun. The very, very end was somewhere in between cringe and realistic.

It was interesting to see the beginnings of DCC in the book. With an AI that wants to make the game solvable and NPCs that realize they are fake. However, it just wasn't quite realistically fleshed out (especially the part about his familiar realizing he wasn't real. I mean, I can definitely come up with some head canon about how he realized, but a couple progression notes dropped here and there might have been interesting).

I enjoyed the recording. The sound effects and occasionally music were actually quite well done and well integrated. I usually stay far away from books with scores, but this one really worked. I will say that it was hard a couple times to understand the kaiju, and that I missed a couple parts of dialog even after rewind.

So anyway, if you want some of the battles and excitement of DCC (but with much more gore and with less humor), this is a fun and quick read.

title: Bad Samaritans: The Myth of Free Trade and the Secret History of Capitalism
author: Ha-Joon Chang

title: First Steps: How Upright Walking Made Us Human
author: Jeremy Desilva

title: Talking to My Daughter About the Economy: or, How Capitalism Works—and How It Fails
author: Yanis Varoufakis

title: The First Human: The Race to Discover Our Earliest Ancestors
author: Ann Gibbons
my_review:
At this point, I've read quite a few books on fossil hunters and evolution. Fossil Men, Neanderthal Man, The World Before Us, Kindred, A short History of Humanity, Lucy, etc. This work stands out as being the least interesting of the bunch.

In researching this book before reading it, I came across a reviewer that lambasted it for being mostly about the stories of the hunters, theories over time, and political infighting. They gave it a miserable score, proclaiming that they thought it would be about evolution. As someone who actually read the subtitle of the book, I have to wonder about this reviewer's reading comprehension, and was immediately excited by what they described.

I've read about the likes of Tim White, Svante Pablo, and Don Johanson from their own mouths and was very excited to hear an overview that could give more details, more perspectives, and solidify everything in my mind.

I was grossly disappointed. We all know someone who can keep us enthralled over the most mundane details...and likewise I'm sure we all know someone who could make breaking news about invading aliens sound boring. Well sadly, Gibbons falls into the latter camp.

During the first 1/3 of the book, she retold stories I've heard several times before, but managed to leave out the most interesting parts or to restructure them in a way that robbed them of any human connection or drama.

I thought that maybe I was being too harsh, so I read on to more stories that I was unfamiliar with...only to find them confusing and uninteresting as well. Ultimately I abandoned the book at the 60% mark.

I reserve two stars for books that I think you should actively avoid, and I give that to this book because there are a host of better books that are more engaging while being equally informative. Fossil Men, Neanderthal Man, and Lucy all come to mind. Oh, also, the narrator was insufferable.

Now, I will say that in the 60% that I read, there were a couple cool things that I got clarity on, so I want to briefly mention them here for the ole memory banks.

- White's protectiveness: I left Fossil Men really viewing White as deeply protective of his fossils, but this clarifies that he was willing to show Ardi to people who had old fossils they needed to compare, such as Mary Leaky who brought a 4 million year old fossil to compare to see if it was the same species
- Taung Child: Many of the stories say that the skull on the mantle was the child itself, but this convincingly clarifies that it was a baboon skull. Also, she adds an interesting detail that there was a competition in the class to bring in bones, since professor Dart was dismayed by the lack of a good reference collection at the university.
- Mary's Discoveries: I already had this feeling, but it was interesting to be reminded of how much she discovered, not her husband. Pro Consol, Zinj, etc
- Immunological Trees: You take animal albumen and then inject it into chickens to get an immune response. Then you can take those immune cells and see how well they bind to a variety of proteins to measure relatedness and build trees. Goodman did this work in the 50s? and it was the first time we had evidence that we were more closely related to african vs asian apes

title: Justice: What's the Right Thing to Do?

my_review: This book rocked my world when I first read it fresh out of high school, still trying to figure out what I thought was right and wrong. And when I read it a decade later, several years into my working life, it still had things to teach me.

title: Some Assembly Required: Decoding Four Billion Years of Life, from Ancient Fossils to DNA
author: Neil Shubin

title: The Story of Earth: The First 4.5 Billion Years, from Stardust to Living Planet
author: Robert M. Hazen

title: Everything Is Tuberculosis: The History and Persistence of Our Deadliest Infection
author: John Green
my_review:
This is undeniably a moving and heart-tugging book. If you are looking for a very brief tour of tuberculosis, interwoven with a touch of personal story, and a firm cry to action -- this is the book for you.

I appreciate all these things, but was rather hoping for more historical and factual meat, hence the average review. I will say that the author gives an excellent reading list in the postscript, which I will probably source more than a few books from.

Some assorted takeaways:
- tuberculosis being so named because it makes tubers
- switch from consumption to tuberculosis after the discovery of the infection's (not inherited) identity. the commensurate transition from an illness of artists to an illness of the poor
- beauty standards of waifish paleness and eye make up and their relation to tuberculosis
- cooke's disgrace, and the spawning of sherlock holmes
- greed as a primary driver of unavailability of a cure worldwide
- disgusting prices of new drugs, and how this relates to corporate profits and (lack of) government investment
- lack of government investment preventing a larger variety of cures
- adds on to my disgust at people who campaign against evolution, and how deeply harmful they are to world health
- the insane system by which they force patients to travel 2 hours to get treatment, instead of sending them home with pills
- huge multiplier number he gave of how much each dollar spent on tb returns in economic output for the country
- 1.2 MILLION deaths per year. some excellent writing near the end about the personhood of henry, and then multiplying that to 1.2 million
- author's stark characterization of the disease as completely preventable

title: Who Is Government? The Untold Story of Public Service
author: Michael   Lewis

title: The Golden Enclaves (The Scholomance, #3)
author: Naomi Novik
my_review:
3.5 rounded down. This series was honestly really fun, definitely would recommend. It's a totally different take on magical school, and it has a well-considered plot that carefully stretches the entire series.

One of my biggest issues with the series was how willing they were to close down the school. It's a literal magic school that hard core trains the students with magically given classes, training, fighting, everything. And they act like loosing this valuable resource is no big deal.

If you can look past that, the series was great fun. It was enjoyable to watch her powers grow and watch the epic reversal from outcast to grand sorceress. The underlying idea of the mawmouths and the fundamental evil of the enclaves and the way it both gave safety and terror was wonderful. I think it was clear that the author spent some genuine time thinking about the magic system and its repercussions. Especially the idea that believing in magic was such a huge part, so wizards lost their power when surrounded by too many normies. Which neatly explains why wizards aren't constantly exploiting the normal world, why witches could legitimately be burned, why magic would have been more common in the more ignorant ages, etc.

I know I gave the first book 4 and the next two 3.5s, but there wasn't really a quality difference. I just feel a little uncomfortable throwing around 4 stars like it's nothing, when I don't think that this totally stacks up to some other, incredible 4 stars on my list.

Anyway, definitely recommend this as a quick and fun read, especially if you are into magical schools or turnaround stories, and I'll gladly read some more from this author.

title: The Last Graduate (The Scholomance, #2)
author: Naomi Novik
my_review: 3.5 rounded up.

title: A Deadly Education (The Scholomance, #1)
author: Naomi Novik
my_review: That was a lot of fun. A really interesting take on the normal school story, as well as an interesting take on the dynamics of the female lead. I was a little disappointed that FMC played less of a role in the battles. The way she gets hyped up, I expected her to take an active part in the fighting at the end. But overall, this was a quick and enjoyable read. I'd say its a rock solid 3.75 rounded up.

title: Never Let Me Go
author: Kazuo Ishiguro
my_review:
This book tries to do a lot more than Artist of a Floating World or Remains of the Day. It has a whole element of sci-fi dystopianism. And while the characters are just as painful to experience as in his other books, the sci-fi element falls short.

I think a hall mark of Ishiguro stories is watching the train-wreck of someone else's life and being powerless to stop it. To see the mistakes and the problems, and to desperately wish you could just violently shake the characters.

Ruth is, simply put, toxic. The whole time, you're just desperate for their "friendship" to end, and yet it never does. And as always, true love and happiness and thwarted. I think this is the first Ishiguro book I've read where the cause of the main character's unhappiness was clearly external.

I think that with only this as the story, I may have even liked the book better. But any time there is a fantasy world proposed, I cannot escape thinking about the details. And the details of this fantasy world simply don't add up.

The clones could just leave. They drive all over the place in their cars. They could advocate for themselves, put up a big scene, anything. At a minimum, I would expect something like that to happen, and be talked about -- with the consequences being why our characters don't do it.

Yet we get none of that. And it just isn't believable. So, I try to enjoy the story, but the doubts just nag at me, leeching out the enjoyment.

After having read three Ishiguros, Remains of the Day remains my favorite, with the other two not even coming close.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters: Book Twelve (He Who Fights with Monsters, #12)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review:
I think it's been about a year since I binged the first 11 books in this series, so it was a much different experience reading it. The author still did a decent job reminding me of all the characters so I could remember all the in jokes.

I think the important thing to remember about these books is that they are self-indulgent power-leveling-porn. The whole point is that the dude get awesomely strong, people never realize it, and we get to watch awesome fights and see the comeupances. It's silly, and it's not always mature, but it's fun.

If I remember correctly, the earlier books, (especially the audio books) were plagued by literal tables in the middle of the text, which totally ruined the flow of the fights. The books have gotten much better in that regard -- the fights are exciting and enveloping.

Jason has come back to earth and magic earth this time as a legit immortal prime avatar astral nexus god-king, and the gratifying power level showing off throughout the book is perfect. Shirtaloon has gotten much better at this, mixing in low characters who can only really glimpse the threat Jason poses, with actual interstellar travelers who are completely gobsmacked by him.

Obviously the book has a ton of tropes and sayings that would be cringe if you said them to yourself in the shower, much less if you read them in a book...but the thing is, this book is unabashed power-leveling-porn, and it works. "Is that a threat, Mr. Asano?" "You don't threaten a mosquito that lands on your arm. You swat it..if it bothers you."

I mean, holy cheese balls. But then again, when you are in the roil of the story, it's awesome.

Anyway, these books are exciting, they are fun, they are trash, they are only average writing...but I just can't put them down.

title: An Artist of the Floating World
author: Kazuo Ishiguro

title: Why Evolution Is True
author: Jerry A. Coyne
my_review:
1st read review, 2012:
This was a pretty straightforward book that was easy to parse and understand, although I don't think I liked it as much as some others in the genre, such as Making of the Fittest by Sean B. Carroll. However, if I was recommending books to help people understand evolution, this might come nearer to the top of the list, by virtue of it's digestability.

second read review, 2025:
revisiting this as I prepare to answer some questions about the evidence for evolution. Honestly a really great introduction to the subject. It's not perfect - there were definitely some things I would have stressed or presented differently - but overall I think you can't go wrong recommending this to a denier.

title: How to Talk to a Science Denier: Conversations with Flat Earthers, Climate Deniers, and Others Who Defy Reason
author: Lee McIntyre

title: The Republican Brain: The Science of Why They Deny Science—and Reality
author: Chris C. Mooney

title: Misquoting Jesus: The Story Behind Who Changed the Bible and Why
author: Bart D. Ehrman
my_review: Of all the Ehrman books, this one is the best introduction to the subject. The rest are also easy to read and enjoyable, but they occasionally cover the same ground, with the exception of God's Problem, which I bought but never read.

title: Alexandria: The City that Changed the World
author: Islam Issa
my_review:
In today's political climate, it's fascinating to read of the collapse of a previously welcoming city into hatred and pogrom...especially after suggestive 300 year run.

Often, when I already know about the subject, I find that the author stretches the truth or relies on bad logical leaps or untrustworthy sources. For instance, he claims that Philadelphia's original meaning was not chaste brotherly love, but a reference to incestuous love, which is at best disputed and at worst a flat out untruth. Then, a few chapters later, he uses the Gospel of Thomas to support the narrative of Jesus's flight to Alexandria, claiming that this is a common practice for biblical scholars -- to use these later texts to fill in the details of the originals (Matthew, Mark, etc). Certainly no biblical scholar I've read has ever taken that view, and I have literally 8 books on biblical scholarship under my belt.

I'll come back and write more here later.

title: Blindsight (Firefall, #1)
author: Peter Watts
my_review: i struggled to stay engaged in this one. yea, there was some interesting stuff about non-conscious intelligence and evolution, but for some reason the plot just didn't keep me hooked. I see why people like it i guess

title: Wild Swans: Three Daughters of China
author: Jung Chang
my_review:
This is my third book on China after WWII, and by far the one that I recommend. I also read Mao's Great Famine, and although it gave an excellent picture of the famine, it lacked the human understanding that could communicate _how_ it happened. Like, why the citizenry put up with it.

Especially in the early part about the warlord era, Wild Swans can lag at times. About 3 hours in I wrote that, "it really begins to just feel like a recitation of facts." But I think the early part about the grandmother was quite interesting -- hearing about her foot binding and the way women were treated. The suicide of her grandfather's son to protest the marriage. The insane lives of concubines.

Historically, it is very clear to me why the american-backed forces lost. The reign of torture and terror. The insistence on the protection of the upper class. The backing of traditional anti-woman stances.

I've written already about Wild Swans in my review of Mao's Great Famine, so I'll skip some of that here. It's horrifying to me how much destruction was done by the Red Guards, of historic monuments, books, and culture. I shudder to think of what was lost. The terrifying group mentality of young people seems something to be reckoned with, at an age where peer pressure is its strongest. I'd be interested to see an age breakdown of historic global atrocities. How many of them were committed on the ground in large part by people under 25, whose prefrontal cortexes hadn't finished developing?

It's insane to think about students beating their teachers every day, and living in a world where as a teacher you can't leave - there is no option but to endure.

It's incredible the way Mao turned on his closest allies and the whole country just let it happen.

There is so much to ponder here about the human condition, and I feel that I should at least revisit a summary of this book every couple years.

title: Mao's Great Famine: The History of China's Most Devastating Catastrophe, 1958-62
author: Frank Dikötter
my_review:
I'd like to first explain the 3 star rating. I tend to reserve 4 stars for books that I would happily recommend to many people. For non-fiction, that tends to require that they be somewhat easily readable. Despite the great subject matter, this book is certainly not readable -- it is rather a slog to get through. If we were talking about importance of the content, this is an easy 5 star read. But I think that there surely must be easier ways to consume the information. Namely, I have now also read Wild Swans - a tri-biographical picture of three generations of women who grew up first in the warlord period, then the communist revolution, then the cultural revolution - and it gives a much broader perspective that really provides the reader with the ability to understand _how_ the tragedy of the great famine occurred.

It's important to me to get to grips with the time period and understand it, but it's been hard for me to really summarize my thoughts on the book, because there was so, SO much to learn and digest. It's an overwhelming amount of information and connections. So let me sort of just word vomit some of the connections I learned, both from this book, and from Three Swans.

After the war with Japan, you had two sides in China. The Communists and the American backed forces. The American backed forces tended to be associated with the land owners and the elite. They were well-funded and often considered corrupt, and they were well known to brutally torture and kill communists and suspected communists. When the communists eventually gained power, it was by being in sync with the wants of the peasants, and deliberately denouncing the power and privilege of the monied and landed elite. Prior to the communist take over, officials across China were just assumed to be corrupt and to engage in constant nepotism to benefit their families. It wasn't even necessarily looked down upon - any man who was raised to power would be absolutely expected to bring his family and extended family along with him.

Women in the old world occupied an extremely lowly position. As children and teens, they were expected to obey their parents in all things. And then, after a husband was chosen for them, they were expected to obey him as well. As an American reader, it is tempting to think that I can relate, having heard about such attitudes in our own 40s and 50s. But this is a mistake. As far as I can see, there is no comparison. A popular saying said something to the effect of, "If you marry a chicken, obey the chicken. If you marry a dog, obey the dog." A bride has no choice but to accept the life and commands of her husband.

In Wild Swans, the eldest woman was of the warlord era, and she had her feet broken as a child so they could be bound. She was married as an official concubine to a local official so that her family could get ahead in life. Seriously - women held such a place in life that concubines were a wide-spread, officially sanctioned, and culturally accepted practice.

So, as we consider the great famine, and how it was allowed to happen at all levels, we have to understand that the communist party line was considered absolute. It was meant to overthrow centuries of social practices which allowed such corruption and nepotism. It also meant to eliminate discrimination against women, peasants, and the lower classes. Criticizing communist ideas was deeply discouraged, and blind loyalty to the party was the ideal. In the beginning, perhaps this made sense, as many of the ideals enforced equality, prevented wasteful excess on funerals and weddings, and generally seemed to move China from an age of backwardness into a time of progress.

But the party line also featured a slavish devotion to an impossible, and often imagined, ideal. Peasants, and their supposedly intense struggle and hard-working ethos, were held up as a golden example for every citizen to follow. And so you end up with pregnant women being told to march with bad nutrition and illness until they miscarried, because, after all, don't peasants give birth in the fields and just keep on working? You see major illnesses brushed off as anti-communist attempts to shirk work, because obviously a real communist would be dedicated to the cause.

If you were a member of the party, it slowly took over all aspects of your life. For a time, members were only allowed to see their spouses on Saturdays. Both husbands and wives were expected to sleep in the very offices where they worked. If you wanted to marry in the old days, it was your family that arranged it and allowed it. In this new world, if you wanted to marry, you submitted an application to the party.

There was a cult-like practice of self criticism, where you would sorrowfully admit everything you did that was against the party to your peers. If you didn't do a good enough job, you might be forced to continue to criticize yourself day after day for months. This practice happened at all levels of society and the party, from the peasants all the way up to top party leaders. Bosses and co-workers would memorize tiny infractions in action or ideology and trot them out during criticisms to degrade and humiliate their enemies.

In a society where individualism was being actively demolished - on a political, personal and social level - the acceptance of the community was essential to an individual's well-being. So at all levels, people were constantly forced into conformity, and punished for stepping outside of it.

As a result, anti-intellectualism flourished, and groups which had reservations about communist party ideology were intensely criticized, removed from political power, and socially ostracized.

Much of my understanding of these social aspects came not from Dikotter's work, but from Wild Swans. As I read through Mao's Great Famine, I couldn't help but be constantly horrified and shocked at how regular people were entirely complicit in the widespread cruelty and suffering throughout China.

In 1958, my understanding is that Mao wasn't really a dictator in the way I personally imagine them, as backed by the might of a state military. He was simply the leader of his party, and could theoretically have been usurped. However, he held absolutely massive political sway backed by an incredible cult of personality. Despite many party actions being theoretically done by committee, criticizing or disagreeing with Mao was political and social suicide, and so functionally speaking, he was a practical dictator.

Indeed, I think most textbooks would classify him as such, but I think it is essential to recognize the difference between a military dictator, who rules by force of arms, and a social dictator, who strangles the hearts and minds of the people in an icy grip.

In fact, there are several instances where it looks like his power might wane, but he carefully divides and denounces the possible opposition. I think this is especially interesting to consider in the light of modern populist leaders.

But, let me talk just briefly about the famine itself and the domino effect of how it happened.
- can't cook at home anymore, fed by canteens
- desire to fertilize so tear down houses
- need steel, so stop farming to do steel production
- need steel, so melt all the tools and cookware
- need steel, so deforest
- numbers are inflated at every step of the chain, so party planners are deluded
- mao tells farms they produced too much, eat and get fat
- they kill birds that eat bad insects
- need massive irrigation, but don't trust intellectuals. bad dams and irrigation built
- this wastes time and ruins previously working fields
- later these dams collapse, killing people or ruining fields
- runoff from the deforested land ruins agricultural land
- deep plowing prevents water retention
- mao wants to be the leader of the 3rd world, so he gives away food to countries that ask for it, in the middle of famine
- russia offers to delay loans, but mao wants to look strong, so he pays back loans with food at an accelerated rate
- international communities offer aid, but it is considered an insult and is denied
- local people blame their immediate overloads, not mao

There's a lot more to write here, but I need to close this out so I can look at some other books. I found suicide to be a particularly particularly interesting phenomena. In Wild Swans, they talk about how in the warlord era a woman is expected to marry who her parents choose. If she says she doesn't want to marry, she is being virtuous and chaste. If she says she wants to keep living with her parents she is being virtuous and filial. Only if she commits suicide are her protests taken seriously.

Suicide also seemed to be the only public protest in a world where society comes always before the individual. I gathered a couple quotes from the book related to suicide and group killings.


In Luoding county, Guangdong, local cadre Qu Bendi beat to death an eight-year-old who had stolen a handful of rice. In Hunan, Tan Yunqing, aged twelve, was drowned in a pond like a puppy for having pilfered food from the canteen.



Sometimes parents were forced to inflict the punishment. When a boy stole a handful of grain in the same village in Hunan where Tan Yunqing was drowned, local boss Xiong Changming forced his father to bury him alive. The father died of grief a few days later.


Dikotter highlights one crushing scene where a woman tries to get permission from her work leader to take her sick child to the hospital. Permission is denied, but desperate, she goes anyway. She leaves her two other children behind, to be looked after by the village. She makes it to the hospital, only for her son to die. Distraught, she returns to the village, only to find that her neighbors have ignored her children, now sick and crawling with worms. They both die. The local cadre comes to her house every day to accuse her of shirking. She ultimately loses her mind.


Some of the abused women felt too ashamed to return to their homes. Twenty-four-year-old Zhu Renjiao, stripped and paraded for petty theft, ‘felt too ashamed to face people’ and asked to be moved to another village. She killed herself when her request was turned down.



In Kaiping county, a fifty-six-year-old lady pilfered two handfuls of grain. Her entire household was banned from the canteen for five days and sent to a labour camp. She committed suicide.



In another small village in Guangdong, the militia stripped two young women and tied them to a tree, using a flashlight to explore one of the girl’s private parts, and drawing a large turtle – symbol of the male organ – on the other woman’s body. Both committed suicide.

title: A Drop of Corruption (Shadow of the Leviathan, #2)
author: Robert Jackson Bennett
my_review:
3.5? This was another good installment from Bennett. It was a good, easy read, and it was fun to see more of this world. I don't know that it quite gets 4 stars from me. Worth reading if you liked the first one, but this is not a resounding recommendation from me.

The characters and peoples are interesting. The sexual elements made me pause a bit. I suppose they are pretty realistic, and they did give some opportunities for humor, but I guess they just didn't really add much to the story for me?

It's been a while since I read the first one, but I want to say that I liked it better. I remember feeling engaged by the story and enraptured by the wildly different world. This book just felt clumsier.

title: Exhalation
author: Ted Chiang
my_review:
Another excellent work by Ted Chiang. Overall, this was not as good as Stories of Your Life...3.5 rounded up to 4? I'd say if you liked the first one, you'll like this, but it definitely isn't as good. He really held the reader's hand throughout the stories, force-feeding you the philosophy, the setting, and the plot. Everything was too clearly spelled out, and it gave the stories an almost young adult feeling as a result. It's like the author didn't trust his audience to take the right message from each story, so he was super careful to explain all the plot and science details and then tell us the right way to feel at the end. Now, the creativity and the situations were still fantastic, and this is still overall a book worth reading, but I couldn't help but be a little disappointed coming off his previous masterpiece.

The Merchant and the Alchemist's Gate
A fun, consistent story about time travel. Doesn't really uncover any new ground

Exhalation
Suffers from over-explanation. Fun idea though, and great way to hit home what may happen to our own universe.

The Lifecycle of Software Objects
Also very interesting, particularly now, in the wake of the LLM revolution. It's a nice exploration, but it failed to engage me, and, as usual, it over explained its own point. It's like the author didn't trust us to see all the implications, so he made sure to have the characters carefully walk us through them.

Dacey's Patent Automatic Nanny
fun. I think I may have liked this one more than the others

The Great Silence
eh

Omphalos
Again, a really fun idea. Having suffered through my share of creation science, I enjoyed this one more than some others. But I still feel that it was very, very on the nose. I wouldn't mind letting some of my less scientifically-minded friends read this though.

Anxiety Is the Dizziness of Freedom
Good ending on this one. Chiang's endings rarely disappoint. Another that felt too explained, but I did definitely enjoy it.

title: The Paper Menagerie and Other Stories
author: Ken Liu
my_review:
Overall, this was excellent. Much darker than the Ted Chiang stories, and often longer, but with more emotional impact. Although some of them ponder technological progress and alien civilizations, just as many are concerned with painful episodes of the Chinese experience. Overall this was an excellent collection that I would highly recommend.

The Bookmaking Habits of Select Species
Interesting but forgettable.

State Change
Souls tied to objects. Quite an interesting idea. A little bit of forced messaging. I feel like I'm hyper sensitive these days whenever I see men writing the supposed sex lives of female characters. Her choice of how to finally exhaust her soul felt somehow demeaning in an abstract way, but maybe I'm being too harsh.

The Perfect Match
All seeing personal assistants. Another good one. Follows a kind of expected path -- I don't think that Liu manages the sort of really technologically innovative story that Chiang sometimes does -- but I still enjoyed the ride.

Good Hunting
Fox demon girl and lost magic. We are getting into darker territory here with this one, as the railroads kill the magic of the land. This one was told in spurts, and was one of the nicer stories in the bunch. A great use of the short format.

The Literomancer 4.5/5 maybe 5/5
Girl with CIA father. I guess I just like dark stories, and this is darker than most. A little graphic at times, but chilling. Throughout some of the later stories, Liu really explores the dehumanizing effect of politics and the state. Stories like this one are a great compressed history lesson in human atrocities, paranoia, and misplaced intentions.

Simulacrum
Father with holo daughter. Brutally judgmental children seem to be a recurring theme in this collection. Some interesting ponderings here on what it means to be you, and what it means to change.

The Regular
Cyborg lady detective. Simply an enjoyable story with a satisfying ending.

The Paper Menagerie
Excellent. I cried. Heartbreaking and sadly believable. I enjoy all the themes that Liu touches on. Here, it is the isolation and loneliness of immigration.

An Advanced Reader’s Picture Book
Mom who wants to be fermi. Great intertwining here, with the perfect sad ending.

The Waves
Immortal space travelers. This felt like multiple good stories in one. Sometimes I feel like Liu doesn't know when to end his stories, but then as he keeps going, I keep enjoying them.

Mono no aware
Lone japanese survivor suicide. Not too much here that makes it stand out from similar stories, but it was still well done with some good emotion at the end.

All the Flavors
Chinese gold miner cook. A reluctant feel-good weaving of myth and history, this one gives us a story to latch onto while talking about the first wave of Chinese immigrants. I can't help but admire the easy way that Liu weaves in darkness of the past with out ever raising the hackles of the reader.

A Brief History of the Trans‑Pacific Tunnel
Tunnel. This is a fun alternate history. Seems like an improvement over our history, until you discover that humanity sucks in ever timeline. Painfully realistic.

The Litigation Master and the Monkey King
Monkey king lawyer. The whole second half of the book is a roller coaster ride through the dark parts of the chinese historical experience. This reminds me of the 1381 Peasants Revolt in England. The way the written word is a tool that the ruling class weaponizes to subjugate and marginalize the lower. It's such an alien view to my modern sensibilities, but I see it again and again in history. The German Peasants war of the 1520s also had elements of peasants revolting against written contracts. Anyway, this was another dark, and good story.

The Man Who Ended History
Time travel atrocities. Another exploration of the darker side of real history, couched in the fantastical setting of time travel that erases the past. The time travel mechanic is really interesting, I've never heard anything similar proposed. Some really interesting (although overly spelled out) comparisons to archeology. I may be in the minority with this complaint, as perhaps this is not an association that would occur to the average reader. This one is less powerful as a story, and feels more like rough expose meshed with an interesting idea. One the most impactful books I read in 2024 was The Rape of Nanking, so I may be a little biased in my high reviews for adjacent subjects.

title: Stories of Your Life and Others
author: Ted Chiang
my_review:
The whole collection is just masterful. The stories are engaging and well-written, and as soon as you begin to ponder on them you are struck by the insight, creativity, and intelligence of their author. It is not without reason that some of these stories have been turned into movies.

In the comments at the end, the author says, "One of the things we admire most in fiction is an ending that is surprising but inevitable." This is fully evidenced in his writing. The endings are uniformly wonderful.

Todd McLaren, great narrator.

Tower of Babylon - 3.5/5
Interesting and well written, with a nice math thing going on there, but not quite as much punch as I had hoped for.

Understand - 4.5/5
I find most literary portrayals of genius to be frankly uninspired. Uncreative, uninteresting, unrealistic, and seemingly conceived by authors who barely manage to be above average themselves. Understand was captivating, thrilling, and let shine the author's own formidable intelligence. The mechanics of the ending were wonderful, but I question the need for any battle at all. It must simply be the case that they could have achieved their aims in concert without death.

Division by Zero - 4/5
Lovely idea. Not the most engaging. Interesting ideas of empathy, sympathy, and understanding. Great ending.

Stories of Your Life - 4.5/5
Great intertwining, great plot, great emotion. The author touches on so much. Linearity of time, linguistics, determinism. As usual, the author has punchy endings.

72 Letters - 3.5/5
Pretty good. I don't know that Chiang does action as well as contemplation. The idea is really neat -- a world where homunculi and golems are real and normal. I love that Chiang never babies you into a story, he immerses you in the world and lets you swim. The ending is a really interesting view of the philosophical implications of DNA.

The Evolution of Human Science - 3/5
Can't even remember the ending.

Hell is the Absence of God - 5/5
DAYUM. What a great story. I have the feeling it could be read by a devout or an atheist with similar pleasure. I love how it speaks of the arbitrariness of God's acts, the senseless casualties of miracles, the internal struggle with blessing and curse. The idea that god is truly real, but people struggle to love him and go to hell anyway. Really the whole thing is masterfully crafted. And the ending. I was so worried it would be trite and disappointing. It was perfect.

Liking what You See - 4/5
Are we more fully realized when we minimize the physical part of our natures? This is simply great. All the different viewpoints. The comparisons to magic. The incredible foresight of filters etc.
genres: Short Stories|Science Fiction|Fiction|Fantasy|Book Club|Speculative Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy

title: Summer of Fire and Blood: The German Peasants' War
author: Lyndal Roper
my_review:
initial thoughts:
summer of fire and blood wasn't bad, but I think it lacked a general reader's overview. it was a touch scholarly and lacked a bit of assumed context which I definitely did not have

could have greatly benefited from a broader perspective on how the revolt played out - I felt like it took the major battles as a given, and they were brushed aside so quickly that I often didn't even realize they happened. same with many of the massacres

I think this was a book that was more concerned with reevaluating the place of certain men in the movement at large, in understanding peasant and town motivations and, notably, understanding the place of women

some of the analysis was very good. I greatly enjoyed learning about how the peasants endured serfdom in germany, and I feel this backdrop is extremely important to understanding the reformation in general. stuff like how they couldn't travel at night without permission from their lords. if they married a freewoman, she and her children would become subject to the lord. it was like slavery-lite. the lord demanded taxes and labor, at the expense of the peasants' own fields.

and on top of that, you could owe towards multiple lords, and be sold and traded between lords. you could owe an entire hen every year to the local monastery, which would then compete with your egg sales in nearby towns.

i had no idea how economically dominant the nunneries and monasteries were. special ponds full of fish that the peasants had to buy during lent. luxurious beds and buildings.

a massive part of the early revolt was just in burning castles and monasteries, and not in killing anyone.

I do think the author had a little bit of an imposed modern view of sexuality, often strangely characterizing the male rebels' emphasis on "brotherhood" as somehow exclusionary towards women in an intentional way. along with some unsubstantiated comments about how the common man was a brother, but the common woman was a whore. I was extremely interested to hear what part women played in the revolution, how they were able to keep the farms going, how they were absolved of guilt after the fact, who they ran out of town, what part they may have played in formulating demands, etc. but I often felt the author took an unhistorically negative view of the men as intentionally disregarding the women's desires that wasn't supported by the evidence aside from conjecture.

Interestingly, there was very little anti-jewish sentiment by the rebels, despite their positions as lenders. There were instances of taking back possessions, but no pogroms, as we often see. Similarly, there is very little evidence of rape by the peasant armies, while conversely, there is much talk of rape by the retaliatory forces.

i need to come back here and add a more considered review, especially in the context of broader themes. these are just some off the top of my head reflections.

title: Summer of Blood: The Peasants' Revolt of 1381
author: Dan Jones

title: Powers and Thrones: A New History of the Middle Ages
author: Dan Jones
my_review:
easy 3.5 rounded down. Honestly, I should maybe give it a 4. This is a very readable account of the middle ages that covers a lot of territory, but does it in a satisfying, interesting way.

One of my biggest takeaways is the breathtaking disregard for human life. Again and again, in every age, in every country, people just brutal tortured and massacred each other.

Dirty muslim? Massacre. Wrong kind of christian? Massacre. Protested the government? Massacre. Minding your own business on some valuable land? Massacre. Wealthy merchant? Massacre.

Some of the stand outs for me was the realization that they started calling crusades on *other christians*. Like holy shit. For example, there was the Albigensian Crusade (1209-1229) in southern France, where they massacred entire villages whether they were Cathar or not. The papal legate was famously quoted as saying, "Kill them all; God will know His own." Modern historians think a minimum of 200,000 people were killed, for a mix of political, linguistic, and cultural reasons, and importantly, for being the wrong kind of Christian.

Good reads is a garbage website, and doesn't let you have a end date unless the text is posted, so until I can come back and add some more thoughts, I'll jot a few notes here which I will later flesh out:
- prayer and donations to the church as a hobby for the rich, vs intellectualism and research in the 1700s-1800s
- how delayed was the industrial revolution because of religious attitudes?
- anti-intellectualism in the church
- the latin west killing a latin ruler of jerusulem?
- the insane insistence of all people in all times for obsessing over self-denial. ancient ascetism mirroring modern veganism/5am workouts/etc
- didn't talk as much as I wanted about the transition from serfdom to a middle class of merchants, etc. would really like to read a dedicated treatment
- need to revisit the protestant reformation and it's larger political and economic effects

title: This Inevitable Ruin (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #7)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review:
3.5 rounded down. As usual, Matt Dinniman provides an engaging read, and the narrator Jeff Hayes is incredible.

It may be that I needed more of a refresher on the characters after almost a year between reading books 6 and 7, but some of the scenes which I think should have had a lot of punch for me just didn't. Like, when they killed the empress, I couldn't even remember who she was.

The former crawlers were a bit of a let down for me. I think we had a real opportunity for some really amazing showcasing of the incredible mastery that a former crawler should have over the dungeon environment. They beat the dungeon, and then lived in it season after season. I was expecting them to explode onto the stage with jaw dropping mastery, but they just kinda seemed like normal characters to me.

As always, I love as the AI gets increasingly powerful and unhinged.

It's been said before, but I have to wonder what it would be like if Matt had edited versions that came out after the serialization.

If you liked the other 6 books then you'll like this one, and I certainly will continue to read whatever Matt writes in this series.

title: Flights of Fancy: Defying Gravity by Design and Evolution
author: Richard Dawkins
my_review:
2.5 rounded up...this was just really not good. I'm a big fan of Dawkins's biological works -- I own literally NINE different editions of _The Selfish Gene_ -- but this was just a massive disappointment.

It was uninteresting, meandering, and unfocused. I was constantly bored, and I struggled to finish it.

title: The Return of Martin Guerre
author: Natalie Zemon Davis
my_review:
This was a delightful little read in the vein of The Cheese and the Worms. If you don't know the ending, and have any ability to skip the introduction, please do. I have no idea why authors go out of their way to ruin the endings of their own books like this.

[spoilers ahead]

Overall the case was totally fascinating. I found myself rooting for the imposter the entire time, and was crushed at the ending. Socially, there was a lot to find interesting in the book.

For instance, the seeming prevalence of lawsuits between peasants. The book makes it seems like a somewhat common occurrence, and this is really not at all how I imagine village life. It's also always shocking to see the casual disregard for human life. The absolutely trivial things for which you could be tortured or get the death penalty are wild.

This book is short and interesting enough to make it an easy recommendation.

title: The Left Hand of Darkness
author: Ursula K. Le Guin
my_review:
Excellent reading as always from Le Guin. Compared to The Dispossesed, I found the characters and plot in this book much more integral and compelling.

It's interesting as she explore gender as something which both limits and enables us. Her fascinating idea of human's perpetual baseline sexual arousal as perverted and socially limiting. The idea of gender as being such a key philosophical duality that without it, a society might not focus on dualities at all. Her exploration of how gender might drive us towards competition and success.

I should note that George Guidall is a miserable narrator -- incredibly awkward pacing at a sentence level, full of weird pauses, rushed phrases and nonsensical intonations. I switched to Michael Crouch and it was much better.

This is a short and interesting enough book that I think it is worth the read. If it lacked the interesting philosophizing, I don't think that it would stand on it's own though. 3.5 rounded up to represent the recommendation.

I've left a few quotes from the book here that I made note of while I read.


The only thing that makes life possible is permanent, intolerable uncertainty: not knowing what comes next.

Love this. It's like why playing games with cheat codes eventually gets boring, or why eventually dying can be said to give life scope and meaning.


The First Mobile, if one is sent, must be warned that unless he is very self-assured, or senile, his pride will suffer. A man wants his virility regarded, a woman wants her femininity appreciated, however indirect and subtle the indications of regard and appreciation. On Winter they will not exist. One is respected and judged only as a human being. It is an appalling experience.

Le Guin is always grounding us throughout the book with these little reminders of how ingrained gender is in our culture.


Being so strictly denned and limited by nature, the sexual urge of Gethenians is really not much interfered with by society: there is less coding, channeling, and repressing of sex there than in any bisexual society I know of. Abstinence is entirely voluntary; indulgence is entirely acceptable. Sexual fear and sexual frustration are both extremely rare. This was the first case I had seen of the social purpose running counter to the sexual drive. Being a suppression, not merely a repression, it produced not frustration, but something more ominous, perhaps, in the long run: passivity.

Le Guin is exploring her how our very sexuality might give us passion and drive. The competition, the preening, the desire to be desired...what happens when that's gone? She may not be far off basis here. I've heard some decent theorizing that some of the driving of evolution intelligence might have come from sexual selection, especially regarding cross-cutting intelligence like humor and eloquence.


he chuckled a little and said, "In kemmer all the time… Is it a place of reward, then? Or
a place of punishment?"

Again on the same theme. Even human society has been smattered with groups that voluntarily deny sexuality, like monks and nuns.


"Tell me, how does the other sex of your race differ from yours?...Are they like a different species?"
"No. Yes. No, of course not, not really. But the difference is very important. I suppose the most important thing, the heaviest single factor in one's life, is whether one's born male or female. In most societies it determines one's expectations, activities, outlook, ethics, manners—almost everything. Vocabulary. Semiotic usages. Clothing. Even food. Women…women tend to eat less… It's extremely hard to separate the innate differences from the learned ones.
