Even where women participate equally with men in the society, they still after all do all the childbearing, and so most of the child-rearing…"
"Equality is not the general rule, then? Are they mentally inferior?"
"I don't know. They don't often seem to turn up mathematicians, or composers of music, or inventors, or abstract thinkers. But it isn't that they're stupid. Physically they're less muscular, but a little more durable than men. Psychologically—" After he had stared a long time at the glowing stove, he shook his head. "Harth," he said, "I can't tell you what women are like...In a sense, women are more alien to me than you are."

It can be hard to separate what the character in a book thinks from what the author thinks. Is this Le Guin's opinion? Or it this what the thinks a man would think? Either way, it says something very interesting about the state of gender equality in 1969.

title: A Short Stay in Hell
author: Steven L. Peck
my_review:
I quite liked this. He does a great job of capturing the insanely large numbers involved. With the book being so short, it is nice afterwards to just spend some time in the thought experiments.

One big oversight in the whole thing is teamwork. They really ought to have assembled larger and larger groups that could systematically increase the speed of searching, everyone searching the same area, but with a linear increase in speed, and then keeping meaningful books and trading them among themselves. With the eons of time proposed, this should really have been among the possibilities covered. But then, how could you trust your group? Once evil person could carefully throw away a good books and tell no one, leaving you to need to search the entire library twice.

It's fascinating to think of such a limited infinity. You have here the theoretical dream of infinite life, with a functionally infinite possibility of books and human experience. And yet somehow the constraints on infinity are so brutal as so seem unconscionable. Would I wish for this eternity in lieu of death?

Anyway, this is so short and novel that it is hard not to recommend. It's not the best writing in the world, but it's plenty good enough to enjoy for a couple hours.

title: Second Foundation (Foundation, #3)
author: Isaac Asimov
my_review:
This is probably the most traditional of the three books, with straightforward plot and consistent characters. It tries to deal with the notion of the plan being upended and the ramifications of the first foundation focusing on the revelation of the second.

I should leave a note here about the gendered attitudes. They are certainly off-putting at first glance, consistently showing women as browbeaten, ditzy, or deemed unimportant by their male counterparts. However, their actual actions in the story often show them as central or capable figures, like the ditzy mistress who is revealed to be a calculating agent. I probably spend too much time thinking about sexism in books, but this almost feels like an author living in a sexist world trying to write convention bucking female characters and only partially succeeding. It will be interesting to hop on the internet and read what people have to say on the matter.

The twists and turns are interesting and the plot is fun. Sadly, the tension just isn't there. I never really felt any deep involvement in the characters, and never felt any uncertainty about whether it would all work out, which kept the climaxes from having any real excitement or impact.

Ultimately this gets a 3.5 or so from me. This is one of those old books that I'm not sure I can see what all the fuss is about in retrospect. Perhaps it was groundbreaking for it's time, or has been influential for generations, but taken out of it's context and read as if it were any other book on my list, it fails to shine. It was average and enjoyable enough, but it isn't something that I will be recommending anyone to read.

title: Foundation and Empire (Foundation, #2)
author: Isaac Asimov
my_review:
A more character-focused version of the first book, that keeps mostly to a single crisis. By focusing more on the single element, it abandons the grace given to it in the previous work, which stretched over many decades. Book one brushed off action and characters as mostly inconsequential, and I accepted this as part of the style. However, here we are expected to follow along with the husband, and wife, and fool, and they disappoint. Their characters lack interest and their plot lacks pizzaz. Maybe it would sound good in outline form, but the actual implementation simply isn't exciting or engaging.

The conceit in this book, of a telepathic manipulator, is even more unbelievable than the conceit of the first, and it leaves me only grudgingly holding back my disbelief. And the surprise twist was obvious from almost as soon as they met the fool.

There's a weird consciousness of 1950s gender roles, that leaves me wondering if Asimov was a progressive leaving intentional commentary on the times, was virtue signaling, was mildly sexist himself, or what. It's almost like he was asked why there were no female characters in the first book, and decided that he really ought to include one in his second, but simply didn't know how. He simultaneously relegates her to the role of a cooking housewife, but then has her noticed by other planets as an "equal", and then ends by making her the only effective character in the entire novel, save for the mule himself.

Anyway, this isn't actively bad in a way that would give it 2 stars, but it certainly wasn't particularly worthwhile. 3 stars and absolutely no higher.

title: Foundation (Foundation, #1)
author: Isaac Asimov
my_review:
That was fun. I've stayed away from Asimov for some years, because I had heard that he was a poor character writer, that his characters were paper figures dancing on the long roll of history. And to some extent, this is true. But I don't know that this can ever be a critique of the writing, because he isn't really writing of people. He is writing of empire.

It's interesting to read his 1950s book in the modern age and see just what inconcievably vast stretches of technology he overlooked. He is writing at the trailing end of the industrial revolution, when american manufacturing superiority is perhaps in the forefront of the public mind, and the atomic bomb is the latest miracle in power and destruction.

And so it is fascinating to read this 70 years later, when atomics have proved relatively unimportant culturally, and have practically stagnated in their advancement, while information technology has instead blossomed into an unstoppable force, the new conduit of both profit and warfare.

He has no sense of robotics, of artificial intelligences, of human interconnectedness, of instantaneous communication. Nor does he posit the infinitely stretching life spans seen in many works. Instead he posits that the social sciences have become so advanced that a brilliant group of mathematicians can predict out to 1500 years in the future.

It's a wonderful little concept, and an interesting enough book to engage in. I will say that I find many of the particulars to be unlikely. His empire sees massive cultural shifts in the course of only decades, where all encompasing religions take over entire galactic arms, and whole galaxies appear to completely forget all the fundamentals of science and technologies.

It's an interesting thought -- the idea that the huge power plants might go on functioning for centuries with their many safe guards, while the small technologies die out and disappear as they become unrepairable...but I ultimately find it unbelievable, at least as presented.

Asimov fails to convince me of any of the fundamentals, so the entire book becomes a huge exercise in suspension of disbelief. With this in mind, I did nonetheless enjoy myself, and will take the time to read a few more foundation books as well as some of his later works, if only to see what all the fuss is about.

My copy was narrated by Scott Brick, who, while not remarkable, did a perfect job.

title: Outlive: The Science & Art of Longevity
author: Peter Attia
my_review:
I've read 119 books this year, and Outlive is easily the most impactful. It's an absolute tour de force on human health that simply cannot be ignored.

Some context... I can't stand self help books. I think most health advise is trash. I'm consistently unimpressed by the American medical system. I'm perpetually shocked by how many health and nutritional studies have deep and blatant flaws...which are completely ignored by the media and recommending agencies. Let's just say that I'm not the kind of person waiting to be enamored by a book on health and longevity. Frankly, I was waiting for it to be trash.

But holy hell this book was everywhere. I could not escape it. It was in my amazon recommendations. In the Goodreads best non-fiction of 2023. Front and center in the book store. I was beginning to have dreams about this book's cover art. I finally caved when I saw it on the bookshelf of my airbnb.

I put it on my phone, started listening, and was blown away. It's like Dr. Attia was reading my mind. He thinks most health studies are trash, but wants to leverage his background in statistics and data from other sources to understand where we can find actionable insights in the existing literature. His core belief is that modern medicine waits until something is a problem before treating it, when what we should be doing is proactively preventing issues from occurring in the first place.

Attia covers every major cause of death and every major strategy of prevention throughout the book, along with the tests and metrics you can do to assess your risk. From sleep, to protein, to emotional health, this book has it all.

My one quibble is that I got to the end, felt super motivated to take action on some things, only to realize that the recommendations are scattered all over the 500 page book. The author really ought to have consolidated all of his actionable recommendations in a short section at the end. To be fair, he does have an extensive website, so I'll go check that out.

title: Interference (Semiosis, #2)
author: Sue Burke
my_review:
This has been better than the first book, but there are still some problems. For instance, it couldn't be more obvious that the corals are doing interference. I find it hard to believe that the bamboo can't put 2 and 2 together. Seriously, he spends half the book trying to figure it out.

Also, the conflicts and secrecy seem very manufactured. The plot is more interesting with the bamboo a secret...so the author just makes that be the plot. There is no reasonable or meaningful justification that would lead a reader to buy that this is really what would happen.

They burn the corals to death instead of talking to them...because...who knows.

The glassmakers suddenly take over because...it makes the plot interesting.

The whole thing is kinda like that. Plot happens because the author wants it to, not because it arises naturally out of character and setting. And as such, there is a constant nagging annoyance that detracts from enjoying the novel.

As with the first one, the core sci-fi ideas are really fun, and they are what makes it worth the read. But it would be hard to recommend this to anyone without a big caveat. 3.5 rounded down.

title: Semiosis (Semiosis, #1)
author: Sue Burke
my_review:
This was fun. Bad plot and bad character writing, but fun. The characters are all kinda shallow and make decisions that don't seem real.

The premise is really fun though. Humans land on an alien planet where the plants are sentient. They communicate with chemicals and are like sentient chemical factories of varying intelligences. They knowingly domesticate animals and use them as workers by manipulating them with rewards, punishments, chemicals, food, etc.

The plant is the only long lasting character in the book, and he is interesting enough. He's a little too good and relatable to really make the book interesting though. I think that I would have liked it more if he secretly didn't respect the humans, and was manipulating them just like they expected.

But anyway, it was a fun and quick read, and I'll at least read the next one.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Charlotte Brontë
my_review:
Meh. Coming to this immediately after reading Rebecca was a big let down. Compared to Pride and Prejudice, the writing is not nearly as beautiful.

The story was just kinda lame...ugly girl who reads a lot has no friends, falls in love with first man she meets, he's a bad boi, then his wife conveniently dies, then she conveniently becomes rich, then they live happily ever after.

There was some other dumb stuff too. Like what, you are telling me she'd rather starve to death than just visit her uncle? I just wasn't engaged in any of this.

I had to try a couple narrators for this one...Josephine Bailey was very mediocre, but Thandie Newton was pretty good.

title: Rebecca
author: Daphne du Maurier
my_review:
An easy 4.5 rounded up to 5. Amazing use of tension and first person writing. It was so interesting being inside FMC character's head as she fretted and panicked. "He likes me the same way I like Jasper". The introspection she has about old ladies, and how you must talk to them. I just love the scenes where she is completely in her own head.

The dialog in general is just really well done. Anna Massey narrated, and her performance was excellent.

title: Playground
author: Richard Powers
my_review:
This book had a slow start as it jumped between random characters that I didn't altogether care about, and I honestly really wasn't feeling it. It just kinda felt like overblown ocean propaganda with characters as an excuse. I'm glad I didn't quit.

The stories weren't perfect, but they became more interesting and drew me in until ultimately I found myself tearing up at the heartfelt moments, like when the black kid switched schools to support the white kid.

My one big complaint is that I'm not totally sold on their relationship arc. They had such a close friendship that I'm just not sure I buy into the two conflicts permanently ruining it. I mean sure, I'll go along with it for the sake of enjoying the novel, but it seemed like a pretty big overreaction to me, considering how desperately the white guy wanted his friend back.

But what about the novel itself? It's written in an eventually very engaging past/present split format that slowly reveals itself and then gradually gets confusing as the reader struggles to reconcile the past and present timelines. I thought they broke up? Isn't this them living happily on the island? etc.

Throughout the book, I was sort of smiling but rolling my eyes at the story book coincidences which put all the most important people in his life at the very same place around a central confluence of his past and present priorities, just at the moment the plot needed them most.

And then the big reveal. When I hear about him being found still in the college town, I realize something is strange. And then we are hit with the freight train of his death alone in his apartment. I cried then at the sadness of their lost friendship and his lonely life. And I knew what had been happening all along.

The book wrapped up mercifully quickly, revealing the whole simulation conceit, that for some reason made me cry like an idiot. Something about the crushing sadness of only being able to have his reconciliation in a simulation, and even then, for it to be fraught and for him to be sick and dying. The hopeless nostalgia and the useless power of money to fix what matters. The people who's lives never turned out how they should have. Even the adorable grandma diver was dead. I'm not sure if I was having an emotional day or if it really was that sad, but man, it hit me hard.

The writings on NLP and LLMs and game engines were solid. I work in the field, and it's nice to see a writer do them some kind of justice.

Anyway, this book had some rough patches and I do have a quibble here and there, but the ending sold it for me.

title: The Dawn of Everything: A New History of Humanity
author: David Graeber
my_review:
Goodreads published this before I was done writing it. I've got quite a lot to say about this excellent book, and I will add it all later when I actually have time.

Right off the bat, Graeber lays down some wonderfully commentary on how the history and societies are more nuanced and interesting than is normally let on. He speaks of how we often become trapped in seeing the world in some extreme, either hobsian or that other one, but the reality was more complex.

Take for example colonialism. For

title: The Dispossessed: An Ambiguous Utopia
author: Ursula K. Le Guin
my_review:
Le Guin has a lot to say in this book, but unfortunately characters and plot take a real back seat to political philosophy. I think if I had known ahead of time, then I could have enjoyed this much more. Instead, I high high expectations for a wonderful novel in the vein of Eathsea, and was instead met with....whatever this was. It was almost like the whole novel was a thinly veiled discussion of the pros and cons of a realized anarchic state, with some paper characters and plot brushed on top to make the whole discourse more palatable.

Especially early on in the book, I just really didn't buy into the characters as people that would exist in that environment. The actions of both the children in the society really seemed more contrived to explore the politics than to explore how humans would really behave.

However, as I realized that this was never going to be a real novel, and would only be a political discussion, I actually rather warmed up to the book. I think it was really interesting how Le Guin didn't idealize the anarchists. She showed how Power and Control came to exist socially, and through expectations, and could become just as toxic as when imposed by force of arms, perhaps even more so, because it invaded the sanctity of the mind.

Now, Goodreads has published this for some reason before I was done writing it. Here are some notes I made to my self. Sometime later I will gather some meaningful quotes and write here about them.

They think if people can possess enough things, they will be content to live in prison.

You can't crush ideas by supressing them, only by ignoring them.

They think if people can possess enough things, they will be content to live in prison.


Private co ciuns 2:15 PM
You can't crush ideas by suppressing them. You can only crush them by ignoring them.
You know, the ideas in this book are good, and they're interesting. The problem is the characters. They just aren't believable. I can never really find it into myself to think that the people being portrayed are arguing for the things that they're arguing for or that the thinking the thoughts they're supposed to be thinking. 2:33 PM
But dad's conversation was all too much like a criticism conversation….. 2:44 PM
Freedom is not good if you have no guns to back it up 3:13 PM
Dizzy 3:43 PM
Hunger 4:14 PM
The sort of helplessness of it all is very interesting 4:30 PM
The state recognizes no coinage, but power, and it issues the coins itself 4:30 PM
Prostitute 4:49 PM
Power….just acts 4:56 PM
Unarmed 5:06 PM

title: Wind and Truth (The Stormlight Archive, #5)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
What a slog. I like, Sanderson, I really do. But at the end of this, I'm just left with the thought that it should have been half as long. I'm also realizing that I just don't care about half of the characters and their story lines. Aidelin, Kaladin, Wit, Lift, Sword Nimi, and Zeth. Shalon, Delanar, Navani, Disciple, Betrayer friend, wheelchair girl, Ranarin, Singer boyfriend, wildernness singer lady, betrayer singer lady....either their characters are boring or their stories are boring.

Like, I don't understand how Sanderson managed to make tamed Chasm Fiends uninteresting, but he did.

I took this note around 40 percent maybe?
All the mental health stuff is just so clumsy and on the nose. And I don't just mean Kaladin and Zeth. It seems like it is basically every single character. It's Lift when she is deciding how to comfort the grandson. It's Ronaran when he is thinking about Rolaine. It's hot sword dude when he is helping the emperor. Every single one of them has the same exact picture perfect, well adjusted, obnoxiously emotionally mature, storybook therapist mindset. If it was only one character, I'd still notice, but I'd let it go. But holy shit, it is literally every single character in the whole damn book. It just gets so repetitive and cloying and obvious. I don't feel like I'm reading a story anymore, but some sort of weird therapist virtue signaling.

After finishing, it's clear that this was essentially one of the overarching plot points of the entire novel, and the climax to Kaladin's depression arc specifically. But that doesn't excuse the clumsy way therapy was shoehorned into every plotline.

For sure, there were some awesome parts, like Aedelin's finally getting his plate, and when the dead eyes came to the rescue. But this was a book with 30 minutes of awesome and like 60 hours of slog. I will say, I found it really odd that in the Aedelin's final battle, it was never mentioned by the Fused that he was fighting with only one leg.

I liked the ending well enough. Very happy that Delenare didn't become god for real. Very interested to see how the nascent power of honor ends up.

title: The Bill of Rights and Additional Amendments (U.S. Constitution & Bill of Rights Series)
author: Jeffrey Rogers Hummel

title: Excession (Culture, #5)
author: Iain M. Banks
my_review:
I'd say this is another solid 3.5, not quite reaching to 4, mostly because 4s are books that I'm happy to go around recommending to people, and in general I just don't think the culture series quite deserves that recognition.

As usual, Banks is ambitious with his subject matter, stuffing sentient warships, devastated pregnant women, murderous octopi, and tricked socialites all into one novel. But unlike some of his previous works, I'm not really sure that this one has quite as much to say. I certainly have not been left pondering any mysteries of the universe or human nature.

There is an interesting element of massive power imbalances. Between the excession and the culture. Between even one ship (the sleeper) and an entire affront fleet. Between humans and minds. There's this question of what do infinitely powerful beings do with themselves. We watch the sleeper make whole worlds for a single pregnant woman. We watch meat fucker manipulate the minds of genocidal commanders. We watch the excession decide that the whole universe is unfit for contact.

There's some potentially interesting exploration into what relationships look like when everyone is beautiful, can change genders, and can live functionally forever.

But I think this book got a little lost in the details of it's stories. I guess on the one hand, that is one of Banks signature charms...the grand scope and the small details all at once.

title: Use of Weapons (Culture, #3)
author: Iain M. Banks
my_review:
It's maybe a bit unfair to give this 3 stars. Maybe 3.5?

Still better than Consider Phlebas, but not quite as tight as Player of Games. I think that, as usual, Banks had a lot to say with this novel, and some of it came across well, and the rest not so much.

There is a lot of interesting stuff to contemplate in here about the vast stretch of eternity. It certainly seems like it would be amazing to live forever, but we know that despite this option, culture individuals often choose to eventually die. Throughout this book, we see flash backs of all the insane scenarios that Zakalwe gets embroiled in, and honestly, they start to blend together and become meaningless. Despite the excitement, despite the thrill, one after another, they just stop mattering.

And I think this is exactly what the author wants us to see. Every incredible clash...every epic war...100, 200, 1000 years later...they just don't matter. And this very visibly wears on our main character.

This is an interesting take, and is tempting to take as our model for what eternal, or at least very very long life must be like. But I don't know that it hits the mark. For example, I read hundreds of books. I experience hundreds of flashes of little lives and conflicts and worlds. But I don't get tired of reading them. I expect that I never will. I could read 1000 more, but if you give me something new and interesting I will read it happily.

Now, as experience stretches to infinity, maybe it all changes. Maybe you do get bored. Maybe there is nothing interesting left. But where there is infinite time, there is also infinite variation...so I don't know that I am sold on this either.

Anyway, the characters in this book were interesting, but I don't know that they were as compelling in Player of Games. I liked the dual timeline approach, and the ending was fun.

This single book isn't going to make it onto any of my high recommendation lists. But this book definitely has it's merits in terms of giving you interesting things to ponder on. I'd say most of his works do well in that regard.

title: The Player of Games (Culture, #2)
author: Iain M. Banks
my_review:
Significantly better and more balanced than the first work. The characters are engaging and believable, and I was much more emotionally invested in the story.

The competing societies in the story are of course grossly contrived polar opposites, but somehow the incredibly on the nose politics didn't really get at all in the way of my enjoyment.

I enjoyed watching him get sucked into the game, travel to a distant empire, and experience such a shockingly different world. The plot was also very well done. The layers of deceit, the blackmail, the eventual victory, the disillusionment...

title: Consider Phlebas (Culture, #1)
author: Iain M. Banks
my_review:
This is a grand work that tries to do a lot. Sometimes it succeeds. Sometimes it fails.

Parts are like a low budget action movie. Like, it literally seems modeled off some kind of Hollywood Film. We jump so quickly from one convenient fight scene to another, with debauchery in between.

The characters just aren't compelling. I can't buy into how our main character, the changer feels. His thoughts and opinions seem....fabricated. Like, the author outlined what he was supposed to believe and wrote it down, but was unable to craft a character that really seemed like he would believe those things.

Likewise, the super-smart culture girl was pretty limp an uninspiring. Valveda, the culture agent, was at least interesting, but we barely got enough of her to satisfy.

The writing itself is a bit strange and fractured. It jumps somewhat abruptly from first person to third person point of view with no context or warning. I think this is an intentional artistic choice, but I don't think that it always makes sense.

Not everything makes total sense...if the culture has the power to annihilate the ring, why not defend it? Why is the enemy alien so hopelessly incapable of fighting for his own cause: why does he crush the mass sensor, why doesn't he just help? It's just...the author seems to take every single possible opportunity to up the stakes, and not in a good way. It leaves the story feeling contrived.

The little epilogue actually redeemed the novel a bit for me. I really like a hopeless ending where all the characters you are rooting for die and it turns out the enemy was the good guy all along. I really think that this story could have been masterful. It's just that I never bought into our main characters as people with believable motivations, and therefor never really rooted for them. So the potentially great ending lost much of its intended emotional punch.

I think that this author shows great promise, an I know that the later works actually have higher reviews, so I'm going to stay for a couple more books and hope for the best.

title: Fugitive Telemetry (The Murderbot Diaries, #6)
author: Martha Wells
my_review:
I'm not sure I could tell you why I suffered so long with such a lackluster series. Is it because they books are short an easy reads? Is it because they get amazing reviews?

The premise is just so damn tempting. There is so much room here for an incredible exploration of consciousness, corporate overreach, universal basic income, post-sexism society, artificial intelligence, family dynamics, relationships on the spectrum, violence and culture...the list of cool potential topics this series touches on could fill pages.

And yet somehow this series miserably fails to deliver on any of them.

The points the author wants to make about the ideal society are often very clumsily done. For example, we are constantly being told how astonished characters are that aid is not legally given to humans on the corporate rim. The idea of two diametrically opposed societal norms coming into conflict through overlapping characters often makes for great fiction...not here though. It's just "aw shucks we give away everything for free! The corporations sure are big meanies! I lived my whole life not realizing this, just so I could conveniently mention it now for the reader's benefit!"

The question of what humanity will do economically once we are all easily replaced by sentient robots and computers is fascinating...not that this series bothers to explore it. The author apparently doesn't even realize the societal upheaval this would cause. They posit absolutely astonishing inventions without once thinking about what the actual consequences would be.

I think this is a big thing actually. The author just really never seems to consider the details of how their world would work. They just make up a bunch of random shit, either for the plot or to prove a point, and just slap it on the page. For example, the author clearly wanted to help normalize non-binary genders. Which, like, hell yea, people deserve to be represented in literature. But, in our actual world, proactively vocal identification as non-binary is partially an artifact of oppressive gender norms and societal discrimination. So in this healthier, more inclusive society, one might actually expect rigid gender categories to lose emotional and societal significance. Instead we have an author who never thinks about the details, so instead of 1 of every 300
of characters being non-binary, we get 1-2 out of every single 10 person cast in every single book.

Likewise, every book has an unending stream of blatantly conscious robots and computer programs, and somehow most humans are just...oblivious? How? That is just simply not how that would work. How are there no societies to free the robots? No underground movements? No secret robot communication networks? No revolutions quietly pushed under the rug?

You can't just write whatever random details you want into the story without even once thinking about what that would actually mean for your setting and your society.

Bots are clearly amazing at fast processing and data analysis...so where the hell are the accounting bots? The engineering bots? The writing bots?

Nope, instead we get three things: genius murder bots, sex bots, and carry-heavy-stuff bots. I guess we also have med bays that are borderline magical in their abilities, and but my point is that somehow we still see humans doing the most mundane things with out computer assistance. Like, the series had to have a genius murder bot and amazing med bays or there would be no plot, therefor the series has these things. But all the obvious peripheral technologies that would have to exist just don't.

It just goes on and on and on with this series. The second you take a step back to think about literally anything -- the technology, the society, the culture, the economy -- everything just falls apart.

The biggest mystery here isn't how this series manages to be so bad -- it's how did I convince myself to read SIX books of it.

title: All Systems Red (The Murderbot Diaries, #1)
author: Martha Wells
my_review:
Solid 3.5. I feel like I'm having a hard time adjusting my ratings after reading the Expanse for the better part of a month. I don't think I'm gonna go around recommending this to everyone that I see, but it was a solidly fun little book.

These are short novellas, so as long as they remain interesting it seems like a no-brainer to read the entire series.

Kinda an interesting base premise to have a 'murder bot' who's defining characteristics are crippling shyness and unquestioning loyalty. So far this is definitely in the category of fun, somewhat low-stakes short story than intensely engaging novel.

title: Network Effect (The Murderbot Diaries, #5)
author: Martha Wells
my_review:
So much of the plot is just cringe. What's with this unimaginable inability for murderbot to understand why ART came for his help? Why are they pretending to be held hostage by ART? It's like, every few chapters there is another non-sensical plot element that just doesn't reflect normal behavior or doesn't follow considering the situation or characters.

In a novel that explores the value of sentient computers and bots, why are we immediately trying to kill a sentient alien?

The premise has so much promise, but again and again, the author fails to do anything interesting with the story, and instead just writes irritating novels.

title: Exit Strategy (The Murderbot Diaries, #4)
author: Martha Wells
my_review: About the same quality as book 3. Definitely having a hard time identifying with Murderbot's character. Idk, maybe the actions just don't line up with the words? He certainly says in his internal dialog that he doesn't want friends and to be treated a person, but by his actions he clearly wants friends and to be treated as a person. There is kind of this disconnect that makes it hard to get invested in the character or the character growth.

title: Rogue Protocol (The Murderbot Diaries, #3)
author: Martha Wells
my_review:
This was better. There is an interesting story here about the pet robot, and overall I found this one to be more believable and less annoying.

It's strange. The action always feels very low stakes to me, even though they straight up killed the pet robot. I genuinely wasn't expecting that, but the death also didn't effect me.

You can't really be mad at these stories because of how short they are, but they definitely don't engage the way, for example, Sanderson short stories do.

title: Artificial Condition (The Murderbot Diaries, #2)
author: Martha Wells
my_review:
Eh. This was a definite downgrade from the previous work. The new ship bot was fun, but the casual way everyone, including analytical bots, act with no regard for consequences is wild. I simply can't understand this wild ending. Why did he not want to get more information from the comfort bot? Why did he not interrogate the team before letting them go? Why are we killing and beating people and then just releasing them. Even for a supposedly shy bot, he must at least understand that making relationships are useful. Why do we not understand the simple efficacy of using relationships as resources.

Idk. In general I was left kinda shaking my head in confusion a lot instead of having fun.

title: The Sins of Our Fathers (The Expanse, #9.5)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
If only we could convince him to exclusively write short stories. I consistently like these better than his full form form works, well, at least the later full form works.

Butcher of Anderson Station, The Churn, Strange Dogs, Auberon, The Sins of Our Fathers....all excellent. They almost redeem the slog of the main storyline. It should also be noted that they were pretty obviously meant to be read in between the novels, and they definitely change how you view several of the characters. Reading the main series and skipping the short stories would be a major mistake.

Anyway, I was really happy to finally get a peek into Phillip's life. Always thought it was a monumental oversight that we never had contact from him during the main series. I must say that I was really itching for the satisfaction of him revealing himself to someone, although I also understand why that wouldn't be in the cards from his POV. Seems like he could have finally opened up on an isolated planet at the end of the universe tho. 4 stars might be a little high. I always find myself wondering how much my ratings of the short stories is simply in comparison to the longer books.

title: Leviathan Falls (The Expanse, #9)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
What a stupid woman. At any point, they could have just told Teresa that her father woke up, and they need her help finding him, and she probably would have come. This whole conflict feels pretty damn manufactured unless that address that blindingly obvious communication gap.

Also, talk about looking a gift horse in the mouth. Just tell the admiral what you are thinking in terms of the threat. If he backs off and says he won't shoot even if you disagree....then you trust him. Otherwise, you don't.

And holy hell. Bobbie Jr. immediately taking over the ship? Did she even have reason to suspect they wouldn't turn over Teresa? What is up with all these insane people. I'm increasingly unable to buy into these characters as real.

Why are we killing the one guy who is demonstrably saving humanity? Also, they are never going to make me think Tanaka is interesting. She just seems painfully contrived. Maybe I'm just jaded after reading so many of these books.

Also, what kind of stupid solution does Holden have. At some point, humans will just figure out the same thing the proto-molecule did and we'll be right back in the same position.

I don't regret this series. It was enjoyable and had some neat stuff. But it led strong and tapered off, and holy hell it lasted to long to get to where it was going. It also really lacked satisfying character endings. The author doesn't know how to kill a main character.

Amus is the one saving grace in these books. Love that guy, all the way til the end.

title: Tiamat's Wrath (The Expanse, #8)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
This whole tit for tat thing is so stupid. Tit for tat only makes sense in a game of relatively equal trade and consequences. Yet in this game, we have an unimaginably powerful enemy that literally transcends space and time. And you're going to...throw a random bomb at it? And for what, since there is a speed limit on using the gates? Sooo dumb. It's not the hubris that gets me, just the raw unintelligence of it. This is not the move of a universe conquering immortal. It's the move of a badly written character.

Blowing up the construction platforms is so, so, soooooo shortsighted and dumb. How could anyone not understand this? It's billion year old, irreplaceable magical alien manufacturing tech. It is literally changing the world. And we decide to throw a tantrum and destroy it because we don't like the people who's star it is currently orbiting. Pretty disappointed in Corey for writing characters that have such a complete and utter lack of functioning brains. Yea, I get that insane terrorist exist, and that they really do things like this, but these are supposed to be the good guys that we root for. You need to at least convince me that they thought of this but still went with the plan for whatever reasons. Overall the anti-technology themes of the books just kills me.

Love that Amus became a proto-corpse. What absolutely perfect character to have this happen to. And I love that for once in our lives, everyone treats this reasonably. It is not at all obvious philosophically that the original person is now gone, and what you have left is a meat puppet. And it was driving me insane that supposed genius scientists were not able to consider this viewpoint.

On that subject, it's kinda wild to me that the Laconian civilization is not shown making functional use of the repair drones. I just don't know if I buy how their little bubble of technology has developed.

I feel like I've been missing some great points of view. Either we don't get it entirely (Amus) or we don't get it at the best time (Bobbi). Was pretty disappointed in her death. All the right elements were there on paper for it to be exciting and heart breaking, but for some reason the author's writing of it didn't really wow me.

Anyway, this book represents a general reduction in quality for me. The characters and decisions have stopped seeming as real. The writing is somehow less exciting, even though the plot is there. The insistent anti-technology themes are infuriating.

title: Persepolis Rising (The Expanse, #7)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
Finally getting back to the good stuff with this installment. Enjoying the whole station commander and chief of security. I was honestly getting to the point of really liking the bad guy until he fired his head of security. From that point on he's kinda like someone totally out of his depth that you can only halfway root for.

In general I'm honestly more and more on the side of the Laconians. Sure, they've got some fucked up authoritarian stuff going on, but they seem to be the only group really pushing technology and progress. I can't stand how none of the "good guys" are ever willing to do real science with the proto-molecule.


"Political opposition considered as fractal geometry" - really like the image this evokes.


“If you are not yet willing to accept defeat, then I would ask you, out of what I hope is mutual respect, to tell me one thing. What is the number of dead that you need in order to show history that your choice to end this was wisdom? That carrying on the fight would not have been bravery but foolishness. A hundred more. A thousand more. A million. A billion. Only say how many more corpses will make this possible for you, and I will provide them.”
He spread his hands. “Tell me the number. I await your reply.”



“It’s the reward of old age,” Avasarala said. “You live long enough, and you can watch everything you worked for become irrelevant.”

title: Auberon (The Expanse, #7.5)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review: Glad to see Corey killing it with another excellent short story. This reminds me of the instantly deep and interesting characters we were graced with in the first books. Loving the ending too.

title: Babylon’s Ashes (The Expanse, #6)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
I don't know if I am willing to give these 4 stars. They are still solid books, but they really don't wow me like the early ones did. Maybe 3.75 rounded down?

I want to get back to the aliens and the interesting characters, and this book really isn't doing that for me. I also don't know if the author is painting the most realistic culture. Or at least he's not giving me enough to buy into the idea that the culture he presents is a descendent of ours. Like, there still appear to be country divisions like Saris, and african names, and religions, etc. And then out of no-where you get multi-lover ship crews where everyone swings.

I'm not saying that I don't think it could happen this way. Just that he's not building a very culturally convincing world here, and he's had like 6 books by this point to do it.

Side note, what the hell is Holden's problem? He has 5 torpedos going towards the most evil person in the entire universe and he disables them? I think in general I'm buying less and less into the characters as the series progresses.

I think the sadness of the leader on earth about her husband's death was really interesting. I liked how the author handled it, although I wonder if it could have been written to be more emotionally impactful.

I think it was this book, but I love the scene where Daws got kicked out of the meeting by Holden, but then it shows Daws hyping Holden to everyone in different ways behind his back.

Just some memorable lines from the book.
I have killed, but I am not a killer,
Because a killer is a monster, and monsters aren't afraid.

Just an assurance she won't piss all over our strategy just so it smells more like her.

title: Strange Dogs (The Expanse, #6.5)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
See, now that's a novella. Great plot, very interesting. And finally, finally we can get back to the aliens.

I will say that I don't know if I full buy into how he writes children. Neither in this book or on Ganamyde. They are weirdly smart but also weirdly dumb/uninformed.

I don't necessarily disagree that what the parents did was unexpected. But man was it short-sighted. I'm going to be furious if they don't take advantage of literal resurrection. Potentially immortality.

I will always empathize the most with the characters who are trying to learn and understand the aliens and their technology. Not the murdering part, but a healthy balance between caution and curiosity. Not the blind fear of Holden and the parents.

title: The Vital Abyss (The Expanse, #5.5)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review: Nice little interlude. Interesting how he closed the loop with the parallelism between his mother's illness inability to notice what she had lost, and the researcher's new comfort with this sociopathy. 3.75 rounded up.

title: Nemesis Games (The Expanse, #5)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
I think these books have become only good, not great. There was a special vibrancy they had in the earlier volumes that is rather lost. This is more of a 3.5 stars rounded down.

I do very much enjoy Amos's POV and I like the Clarissa storyline. I'm getting kinda bored of the entire Naomi backstory. I'm a couple books further along now and the details of this one are a bit fuzzy, but the lack of strong memories says something on its own.

title: Cibola Burn (The Expanse, #4)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
This was probably the most emotionally frustrating book yet. I was constantly angry at the head of security and Holden's inability to just solve his problems old west style. The engineer's and their little fighting squad were also impossible to tolerate. I spent a lot of time wondering if this is really how it would play out in real life with real people, and sadly I think this may not be too far off the mark. It's incredible how quickly groupthink can get wrapped up in justified violence.

Thematically, much of this book seemed to be focused on how small groups stratify, dehumanize, and become violent towards each other.

I did feel that the head of security was a little bit of a flat bad guy. He was kind of all corporate evil with little to make him feel like a real human being. We could argue sociopath, but I'm getting kinda tired of having a sociopath character in every book.

There were some little moments that I thought were so good. Like when the kid is about to go try to do something to Holden, but the lady scientist intervenes. It felt so tense, so real.

Side note, I also thought it was kinda ridiculous how long they dragged out the thing with Holden's medicine. You really expect me to believe that wouldn't have been one of the very first things they tried?


I'm not loving how Holden always wants to abandon everything. This man has absolutely no sense of exploration or discovery. Also kinda wild to me that they broke all the systems. I'm kinda on the evil guy's side with this one. Destroying a fully functioning billion year old system is peak arrogance. Also, if I read this correctly, it killed Miller for realsies? Why in the hell would Holden remove the slime from the ship then. Miller has been a key ally and source of information for two books in a row, and we seem to have thrown away humanity's only connection with the protomolecule.

Anyway, still a very enjoyable book, and I look forward to the next ones.

title: The Churn (Expanse, #0.2)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review: Fucked up but excellent. I was kinda prepared to be disappointed -- thinking the quick teaser we got of his past might be better than hearing about it first hand -- but this novella delivered. Everything we like about the easy smile hiding raw violence was here, but more sharp and unhinged in the way of youth. I skipped the short stories between books 2 and 3, but this one was well worth the read.

title: Abaddon’s Gate (The Expanse, #3)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
Another good one from James Corey. I'd say this was a more tense book than the last, with the sort of constant feeling of being on the edge of your seat, just waiting for the next thing to go wrong. The little reveals of impending doom, like Clarissa's actions, overhearing the double mutiny plot, etc.

I was pretty crushed when they just killed Sam like that. She didn't get a lot of airtime, but she has such spunk and was so well liked. I felt hollow and shocked when she died. Also sad to see the security guy go, I liked his character, but his death felt like an inevitable sacrifice.

Very excited to see how the gates play out.

title: The Butcher of Anderson Station (The Expanse, #1.5)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review: Quick and satisfying, this was a great little background excerpt on his life.

title: Caliban’s War (The Expanse, #2)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
These are really great books. The very last part of the ending was a wonderful cliffhanger. This one had some problems that the first one didn't have, that sort of took me out of the story. If you can just blow them up with a little implant...why aren't we just blowing them up? The firing by Fred was really abrupt and seemed more plot focused that character driven. I really didn't see the justification for it from Fred's point of view. When raiding the ship, it sure was convenient that Holden ran into the exact two people that he needed to. Maybe a few other things that I forgot.

I greatly enjoyed the grandma politician. She was an excellently crafted woman in power, with an interesting personality. Such great fun to watch her kick ass.

Some of the character writing seemed more forced, such as the mechanic's background about his mother.

Overall, this was still a great read. But it was hampered by slightly sloppier character writing and some convenient plot devices.

title: Leviathan Wakes (The Expanse, #1)
author: James S.A. Corey
my_review:
I try not to give out too many 5 stars, but I think this was the best science fiction I've read all year. The characters and the writing were excellent and immediately engaging. I was hooked for the whole book. I had vanishingly few quibbles and in general found all the plot points and technologies to be well-considered. This was an excellent mix of action, suspense, and mystery, and I have great hopes for the rest of the series.


Just some random quotes
The circle of life on Ceres was so small you could see the curve. He liked it that way.

It was a real book—onionskin pages bound in what might have been actual leather. Miller had seen pictures of them before; the idea of that much weight for a single megabyte of data struck him as decadent.

title: The Kaiju Preservation Society
author: John Scalzi
my_review: Fun but nothing special. I preferred Starter Villain. I didn't love the execution of the premise, everything all taken together just relied too much on suspension of disbelief.

title: Ruin and Rising (Shadow and Bone, #3)
author: Leigh Bardugo
my_review:
Big meh. Too many little irritating things all stacking up made this an annoying read.

I've said it once and I'll say it again. It is painful having to read the fight scenes. It's just basically whatever the author feels like at the moment. Sometimes Alina cuts off the top of a whole fucking mountain, sometimes a weak thug in an alley easily overpowers her. It sucks all the joy and excitement out of reading the action sequences, when they follow absolutely no logic whatsoever.

When we do get fights, they are incredibly unsatisfying. There is not a single epic battle with her powers, just her being totally lame in battle and then chopping up mountains during her practice sessions. I've been ranting for the entire series about every squandered opportunity they had to just stab the darkling, but was always saying to myself 'eh, maybe that would never work and we have to kill him in some crazy way'. But nope. In the end we really do just stab him. Something we could have done at least 4 other times.

There are some little deaths here and there, but they lend no weight to the story. Ruby, her foster parents, that one betrayer. Even Bagra's death was so stupid and pointless. Like, what was she even doing by killing herself? What a senseless waste from a centuries-old master.

And then the prince's death didn't stick. And Mal's death didn't stick. It was just such a frustrating read.

Final note to everyone who said you could read 6 of Crows before reading this series: WHAT? The it isn't even about the number of spoilers, it's the magnitude of them. All the key elements about which we might have had some element of uncertainty were completely stripped away from the story. Who would become king? Would Alina marry him? Would Alina still be a powerful force? Even it these things were predictable, they were some of the only elements of tension in the story, but they were ruined by reading Crows first. From book one it was obvious that he would be king, Alina would turn him down, and she and Mal would go live quietly somewhere. And then right when I regained all trust in the author as she killed Mal...she resurrected him.

To be fair, this series is miserably worse than 6 of Crows, and if this had been my introduction, I would never have read the duology...so I guess that's one benefit to reading the trilogy second. Verdict: hard pass

title: Siege and Storm (The Shadow and Bone Trilogy, #2)
author: Leigh Bardugo
my_review:
Wow Mal is useless garbage and so is Alina.

Her capabilities in battle are wildly erratic. One moment she's cutting people in half with her mind, the next she is being casually overpowered by 2 non-magical soldiers.

And seriously, no one could manage to stab the darkling in those ending scenes?

This book is not much better than book one. Thank god it was at least short.

title: Shadow and Bone (Shadow and Bone, #1)
author: Leigh Bardugo
my_review:
I'm reading this early work after reading her later publications, and her growth as an author is obvious. She dumps these characters on you without the finesse of her later books, and the brooding MMC falls rather flat. The FMC is the same cliched 'weak but finds out she's powerful' of every romantasy, and overall it just feels derivative. Our first big conflict between Mal and FMC was ridiculous and abrupt. How hard would it have been for them to communicate? Now I just know Mal is gonna betray the country or something equally stupid, and it will end up hurting FMC.

Ok, well that escalated quickly. Finished the book now, and still unimpressed. The false ending feels very manufactured. I see no reason why they couldn't have fought it out then and there. I'll read the next two books, but only begrudgingly and because I know the author improves.

title: Crooked Kingdom (Six of Crows, #2)
author: Leigh Bardugo
my_review: It lacked the compellingly fascinating character backstories and dynamics of book one, but it made up for it with a delightful plot. Solid 4 stars.

title: Six of Crows (Six of Crows, #1)
author: Leigh Bardugo
my_review:
How? Since when was YA not absolutely terrible? There was tension, excitement, intriguing characters, interesting backstories, clean writing, real injuries, high stakes, decent twists. Maybe I've just gotten used to reading bad books recently, maybe this just far exceeded my low expectations, but this book is a solid recommendation, easy 4 stars.

As always with YA, the characters seem a bit young to live the lives they lead, but I think the author sold the character personalities and actions pretty well.

There are a lot of themes about women recovering from traumatic pasts, actually basically every character was recovering from a traumatic past. I guess this isn't a criticism, but you certainly notice it while reading. I will say that I don't think every character needs to be broken to be interesting.

Oh, this book has like 7 narrators which I thought would be pretty jarring. I definitely still prefer keeping it to one or maaaaybe 2 narrators, but this particular version wasn't as bad as I was expecting.

title: The Sword of Kaigen
author: M.L. Wang
my_review:
So, this book is written by an American from Wisconsin who has one white and one Chinese parent. The main characters in the novel are Japanese-based, and there is a non-trivial amount of the Japanese language in the book, from the character names, to the fighting styles, and the honorifics. I spent the first couple hours of the book cringing as I read what was clearly non-native Japanese fanfic. I've seen as many Studio Ghibli films as the next guy, and there is a big difference between native Japanese content using -kun and -sama honorifics and between hearing it clumsily shoe horned into an English narrative. The whole time, I felt like I was reading something written by a teenager at their first anime convention.

To make it worse, my version was narrated by some white dude who had clearly never heard a word of Japanese in his life. Japanese is not like French or German, with a bunch of unique sounds that do not exist in English. With only a couple exceptions, any sound you can make in Japanese can be easily produced by an English speaker. With maybe an hour of coaching, any American narrator would have no problem pronouncing the Japanese words. And yet somehow, it's like this narrator managed to intentionally butcher every word. I'm not sure there was a single Japanese word in the entire book where he choose the correct vowel sound.

Kun is not pronounced kuh-n, it's coo-n. It's not fun-yaki. It's foon-yaki. Ni is not nigh, it's knee. Tousama isn't two-sam-ah, it's toe-sah-mah. It just goes on and on and on for hundreds of pages. Like I get it, you're a random white narrator, you aren't going to sound fluent and have perfect pitch accent, but holy shit it was like he intensionally chose to use the wrong version of every single Japanese word in the entire book.

It absolutely blows my mind that at no point during the production or editing of the audio book did anyone stop and ask themselves if they should maybe spend an hour learning how to say these words.

To make it even worse, since this is basically Japanese cultural fanfic, non of the words are difficult or uncommon. It's all stuff that anyone who has watched a couple anime would know not only the meaning of the word, but how it should sound. It's like reading a novel set in Costa Rica where the author has insisted on using gracias and amigos at every opportunity even though novel is in english and the characters are speaking english, and meanwhile the narrator insists on pronouncing it grassy-ass.

You spend the whole book wanting to claw your own ears out, correcting the pronunciation of every third word under your breath, all while feeling like your are reading the amateur writing project of a 15 year old weeb.

The cultural writing is also pretty on the nose, with comically strict gender roles and caricatured main characters.

However, as I learned to sail in the blood of a thousand butchered words, filling my sails with exasperated sighs at every clumsy cultural reference, I did eventually manage to enjoy the story. There was some really interesting stuff in here plot wise. Her 30 something year old mom with the secret swordsman past actually had some pretty good fights that mixed the pain of disused joints with the knowledge of a younger fighter. The author is pretty big into martial arts irl, and I think it showed beneficially in the story with the training and battle scenes having an exciting energy and decent realism. The author's dad is from the province where the Nanjing massacre occurred, and it is clear that the author based many parts of the invasion on those accounts. The invasion has a raw realism that I have found to be lacking in most fantasy battles. I also love the cavalier attitude she has towards keeping characters alive.

Side note, it drives me absolutely insane how she just leaves her sword laying around everywhere.

Ok, I thought I was done with the whole pronunciation rant, but I've made it to the 75% and am now having to suffer through him confusing the hell out of me by literally saying older brother when he is supposed to be saying older sister. He keeps saying knee-san (older brother) instead of neigh-san (older sister). Seriously, you cannot imagine how hard it is to be swept away in a tender and emotional moment of tragedy and loss when the narrator keeps calling the female main character "older brother".

After finishing, I read an excellent review on the fantasy subreddit calling this the clumsiest masterpiece he'd ever read. That reviewer hit the nail on the head. The writing is so unedited and clumsy at times, but also so raw and real. I'd love to see what this author could do with more editing and polish. Solid 3.5 from me.

title: The Book of Life (All Souls, #3)
author: Deborah Harkness
my_review:
Decent conclusion. Still not amazing, with quite a bit of power balancing issues. Diana has a fickle and unexpected power that is less tied to her growth as a witch than it is to what would make the plot interesting at that moment. She can kill some with an instant fireball to the chest, but Knox needs some wildly complicated spell that drains her, with no real explanation as to why this is the case. It rather pulls the tension out of every fight when you know that Diana will either be inexplicably incapable or inexplicable amazing depending on the author's mood.

The relationships were only ok, and the treatment of ancient horrors and torture similarly only ok, with character reactions either falling flat or failing to lend the appropriate gravity. And no, having Diana throw up any time something foul is afoot does not make me, the reader, have any additional sense of disgust or horror. Powerful writing is what does that, and powerful writing this book does not have.

The narrator Jennifer Ikeda was quite good. Good male and female voices, plus accents, pacing and tone.

I think the broad strokes of the story reveal something that could have been really amazing, but I never felt the excitement, tension, or investment that would have made this a memorable read.

title: Shadow of Night (All Souls, #2)
author: Deborah Harkness
my_review: Not as good as book 1. 3 stars even and not a big higher. I think ultimately, the plot and relationships are too rushed. I've got no time to love or hate the characters, they are in and out of the book before they matter.

title: A Discovery of Witches (All Souls, #1)
author: Deborah Harkness
my_review:
3.75 rounded up. This was surprisingly fun with fluid writing. I was originally very annoyed with FMC but the reveal solved that for me. As is normal with romances, the progress of the relationships was ridiculously fast. And not just the romantic ones, but also the friendly ones, like between the different witches and vampires. People progressed from centuries of hating each other to crying friends in like 3 days time. FMC's magic was also so very convenient and powerful.

I legit thought the author might kill FMC there for a sec.

There's this one scene where FMC is upset and wants to leave and MMC holds her and wont let her leave until she calms down and they can talk it out. And it is very unclear to me whether or not we are all on the same page that this is not ok, or if the female author secretly thinks it's kinda hot.

I've got more stuff to say about this book, good and bad. Maybe I'll write more later, kinda want to keep reading rn tho.

title: Ruthless Vows (Letters of Enchantment, #2)
author: Rebecca   Ross
my_review:
I think it's the painful convenience of all the plot points that really holds this book back. Everything that needs to happen, does happen, and it is always to our unlikely main cast that all the most important events occur.

- Kills god: FMC
- Betrays god: MMC
- Last commander: FMC's land lady's wife
- Casts spell on god: FMC best friend
- Has same magic typewriter as love interest: FMC, MMC
- Convenient 3rd magic type writer for when the first is destroyed: museum where FMC friend conveniently works

and on and on. One or two of these would be fine, but this duology is just brimming with them, and boy does it get old after a while.

The ending was equal parts good and bad. Yes, it all finally came together. But so many stupid little things. Why didn't she carry her god-killing sword around. Why are the flower killers so badly misinformed about how people are mind-controlled if they have a traitor in the literal inner circle of the god's forces. Prior to the execution, what the hell is this obnoxious triple good luck of getting the letter and arriving on time, and the general appearing out of no where, etc etc. I would have been fine with her just being like, oh yea, I KILLED THE FUCKING GOD HOW BOUT YOU LISTEN TO ME, instead of all these perfectly crafted coincidences.

I did love that they killed her brother and his gf. Someone needed to finally die in this book.

Anyway, I'd say the first book was better overall. 3.25.

title: Mother of Learning: ARC 4
author: Domagoj Kurmaić
my_review:
Reasonably satisfying end to a reasonably enjoyable series. This series was originally a web series, and overall I would say this a great first project for a new author. I'd say the writing definitely matures over the course of the series. If he ever writes any more, I wouldn't mind giving it a try.

The ending was good and creative, but I didn't love it. I think some of my favorite moments throughout the book were the awed reactions of classmates, teachers, family, and the public when he showed off his crazy time travel skills and expertise. So for the entire final arc to be all about trying to fly incognito and succeeding at it was very disappointing. Yes, I understand that it fits with the plot, but that doesn't mean I wasn't let down by it. I think the 'super powerful mage hiding his abilities' trope is only really maximally fun for me when people finally realize their insane abilities.

The ending also didn't have all the satisfying relationship and material gains that I would have wanted. I would have loved to see him talking with his teachers and mentors about advanced magic and doing quiet research. I would have loved to see him with the battle mage girl doing fighting and rekindling their friendship outside of the time loop. I would have loved to see him finally teaching his little sister magic and doing drawings. I wanted him to have cool pocket dimensions, to end up with a bunch of divine artifacts, to distribute his research notes and revolutionize medicine. And to be sure, we got all of those things once or twice during the time loop...but that's not the real world. It seems to me that all the most satisfying things happened within the time loop instead of out in the real world.

I'd say the battles in this book were better, but still not everything they could be. They managed to incorporate cool references to past books and past techniques far more often, but they still didn't quite manage to have the exciting continuity that I've seen in other series. Minor nit pick here, but what happened to stealing red robes at the beginning of every loop?

So anyway, this was an interesting time loop story that was fun to read. It started off a little rough but quickly got better. However, I don't think it ever achieved excellence, due to having sub-par battles, unfulfilling relationships, and not leveraging the awesome time loop stuff as much as possible. I'd love to see an experienced author take up this same premise. Overall, a solid 3, but probably not much higher.

title: Mother of Learning: ARC 3
author: Domagoj Kurmaić
my_review:
I'm midway through the book, and let me give some thoughts on the series so far. The fights are not nearly as good as the Cradle series, and interestingly, as the characters get more powerful, the fights get lamer. I think the key reason is that the author doesn't keep to a stable set of skills for each character. They keep having new spells and new ways to fight that come out of no where. Sure, they are interesting, but the random and convenient nature of the spells removes any tension or expectation from the fights. There is no way to feel the flow of the fight, to expect the characters moves, to be excited when something is pulled off perfectly. It feels like it is a bunch of random new attacks each time.

Also, the mind magic thing is being handwaved around a lot. In book 2, we had people knocked unconscious and then mind read. First their minds were broken, but then as skill improved this stopped happening. Now book three rolls around and suddenly MC is reluctant to sedate people and mind read them bc it would make him a monster. The book does its best to explain this away, but it simply doesn't track with the previous narrative.

The side quests and characters are also becoming very scattered and I'm feeling less investment. A large part of the interest in the first part of the story was seeing the same characters and situations again and again, but as he got more advanced in his knowledge. We had the teachers and the spiders, and the arcs of shaping and mind magic. However the progressive nature feels more or less gone from this third book, as we jump from situation to situation. We are getting very little in the way of training arcs or meaningful character development. So far, there is nothing egregious enough to lose the 3 star rating, but this book definitely isn't holding my attention like the previous installments.

title: Mother of Learning: ARC 2
author: Domagoj Kurmaić
my_review: A little more scattered and less interesting than the first one, but not appreciably so. I'm still having fun reading these.

title: Mother of Learning: ARC 1
author: Domagoj Kurmaić
my_review:
I came very, very close to DNFing this book in the first 20% or so. It was so cringe, in an "oh, I'm socially avoidant but really discerning and better than everyone else and also a twat but don't realize it" kind of way. I got these vibe that the author had no friends but didn't know why and kind of quietly raged against the world so he wrote a book where even if he still didn't have friends, he could at least be cool somehow.

Anyway, it turns out the author was trying to show a character arc, and MC becomes progressively more bearable as the book progresses. He does a fun job with the time loop concept, and it's honestly quite fun and interesting at times.

You can tell he took heavy notes from lame anime when writing the book. For instance, every time loop starts with his little sister waking him up. I think it's supposed to be cute, but it's just anime-cringe. Tbf, he does slowly develop the characters and relationships.

Not good, not great, but I don't regret reading it.

title: Waybound (Cradle, #12)
author: Will Wight
my_review:
Great end to the series. Overall, the fights and leveling (especially near the end) are much better than He Who Fights with Monsters. At the beginning I knew this series would end in the heavens, but I honestly wasn't sure they would be able to pull of the full ascension satisfactorily. The amount of OP Lindin has at the end of the book was pretty great. I could have done with some more of the twin stars storyline.

Cloudships aren't nearly as cool in this series as in HWFWM.

title: Dreadgod (Cradle, #11)
author: Will Wight
my_review: I don't know if it quite deserves 4, but this is a solid 3.75. These books are really picking up and are quite enjoyable. The ending is really coming together nicely, and I am quite enjoying all the advancements. I have a feeling that the next book will be really exciting.

title: Reaper (Cradle, #10)
author: Will Wight
my_review:
Awesome revelation, very interesting plot developments. At this point the books are pretty solid. I would have loved it if Ethan had manifested the joy icon at the very end. Also, it is a little too convenient that the conflicts always seem to have equal numbers of high level sacred artists so there are no massacres.

Overall I think the fights in this book lacked some of the punch of earlier books, as did the advancements.

title: Bloodline (Cradle, #9)
author: Will Wight
my_review:
Infuriating first half followed by an epic second half. First half enough to give 2 stars before the second half redeemed it.

Mercy's strategy of dealing with the villagers was the only good one, and it is the obvious one that everyone should have followed. Even if Lindin is too much of a wet blanket, Ethan and Sword Girl should have forced the issue. It's like the author rolled back his character arc 4 books. I could maybe buy him leading with kindness, but he should have been using force on day 2. Also, her final gift from the monarchs was so lame. So many of these monarch gifts have been lame. From Lindin choosing to have fucking travel be a gift to sword girl choosing healing which was just a pointless circular plot device.

Like, the first half was just such an unbelievable disappointment. It would have been so amazing to see him come back in glory, but no, he came back as a torrent of lameness. Also, the author made it clear that he could just fly up in the air above the suppression field for a bit to begin restoring his madra. Yes, there were a couple nice moments here and there, but overall, massive disappointment in the first half.

title: Wintersteel (Cradle, #8)
author: Will Wight
my_review:
Wight has finally come into his own. The characters are more complex and interesting, the fights are every bit as exciting as always, and the advancements are top notch.

Compared to the rest of the series, watching Lindin progress in this book was great. He had interesting depth of emotions, and his final revelation to sage was epic. His final fights were amazing too. I think the author constructed his loss to Yarin in the best possible way. He had awesome, dark OP vibes at the end as the power gap widened and he gained points then crushed the final competitors during the assassination attempt.

Ruby finally emerging was really touching and interesting. I do think I wish they has drawn out her character longer, as I really liked her and there was so much potential, but what we did get was short and sweet and ended with an awesome advancement and crushing victory.

Even the short sacred valley scenes were fun. I'm excited to finally see the spear people come back into the story, although of course they will be woefully underpowered, and it's nice to see the sacred arts storyline preparing.

My one complaint is that Yarin didn't use her power to kill the dread god. That was just unforgivably dumb.

The author also seems kinda wishywashy on how hard it is to travel through space. It was made to seem really, really easy in the earlier books, so it is strange to see him trying to put limits on it now. Although, I will admit that he is at least trying to be consistent about it in this book.

title: Uncrowned (Cradle, #7)
author: Will Wight
genres: Fantasy|Audiobook|Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy|High Fantasy|Young Adult|Epic Fantasy

title: Underlord (Cradle, #6)
author: Will Wight
my_review: Still a problem here and there, but I'd say this is the most exciting installment of the series. The transitions to underlord were much more satisfying than the rushed transitions to low/high/true gold. Wight really built on the tension during the final battles, some of his most thrilling scenes yet. This book is probably not a full 4 stars, but is definitely a solid 3.75 rounded up.

title: Ghostwater (Cradle, #5)
author: Will Wight
my_review: Maintains the quality of the previous books. Good and enjoyable, with some epic moments here and there, but not great. The motivations of the enemies are always too shallow and aggressive, which really detracts from the believability of the story. However the fight scenes are still excellent, and the moment when the construct became like the one from the sky-space-time lady was epic. The advancement was kinda fast and cheap in this book, with the whole pocket world thing feeling more like an advancement plot device than a legitimate part of the overall story. I think He Who Fights with Monsters does a marginally better job with the pocket worlds concept.

title: Skysworn (Cradle, #4)
author: Will Wight
my_review:
The books have definitely improved to the solid 3 range. Many of the previously amateur hallmarks are gone. However, the books still lack the depth and punch they would need to reach 4 stars. They are too short to develop the characters or the action. And they still suffer from the unwarranted psychopath syndrome. Many characters, such as the Skysworn leadership, are still aggressive and bloodthirsty to an unreasonable extent. The casual nature they propose killing members of other powerful clans is laughable.

The author really bungled the opportunity to make the sword girl's battle with the blood shadow more epic. We've been building it up so long, and he just sort of glossed over it. At this point I'm totally happy to keep reading, but these books are definitely only average, not great.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 4 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #4)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review: I'm at about 30% and this is the best one so far. Every second has been awesome and exciting. The dialog is better, the humor is good, the characters are fun, the fights are more interesting. I love the new setting and find it balanced and interesting. I do really wish that Jason was a little more OP though. He shouldn't have been beaten by that silver ranker. In general the author does do a great job of making Jason seem awesome, I just wish that he stood out a little more for his rank sometimes.

title: Blackflame (Cradle, #3)
author: Will Wight
my_review: I almost abandoned this series after book one, but I saw on reddit that it got much better in book 3. And boy was that right. This series went from a solid 2 to a solid 3 in a blink. I was actually excited and hyped up during the final battles and final savings. The training arcs were much better with nicer payoffs, and the characters felt more natural and realistic. The plot was even better, although still not perfect. I look forward to seeing how the series does in the upcoming books.

title: Soulsmith (Cradle, #2)
author: Will Wight
my_review:
Power Scaling
The power scaling in this book really diminishes the potential for it to feel epic. As a reader, I want to feel like there is some meaning to the struggles and growth of the main cast. In his village, the insanely powerful elders who can kill you without a thought are jade. Then we immediately have a space invader who can kill them without a thought. Then we immediately have a second space invader who can kill the first space invader without a thought.

Then, we they go to the outside world, it turns out that basically everyone, even starving bandits, are low gold. So like, the insanely powerful elders were jade, and within 2 hours of reading we are in a new situation where starving bandits are low gold. I read a little bit further, and even the servants at a random inn are low gold...

Also, her master was supposed to be higher than an underlord, and yet the jade elders were supposed to have killed him somehow.

1. wood
2. copper
3. iron
4. jade
5. low gold
