6. high gold
7. underlord

Society of Psychopaths
Everyone is competitive to a comical degree. Parents are willing to throw away their children for not contributing enough to the clan. Cousins will kill each other over a slight to honor. Higher ranked members can kill lower ranked members with impunity. It's just silly. They act like there is no such thing as normal human emotions.

The aggressive overtures of the main characters are also silly to the extreme. Whenever they interact with other people

Background Exposition
Instead of introducing characters organically and revealing their backgrounds and motivations, the author constantly has the AI read wikipedia entries on the characters. It's just lazy info dumping.

title: Unsouled (Cradle, #1)
author: Will Wight
my_review: Lame. Like reading a bad kid's show. Ppl say it gets better after book 2. These take a day to read, so I'll do books 2 and 3 and we'll see. Not getting my hopes up though.

title: The Primal Hunter 2 (The Primal Hunter, #2)
author: Zogarth
my_review:
Meh. The fight scenes really are pretty decent, but that's about it. The social interactions are just so, so cringe, and near the end of the book, when they started introducing all the secondary characters, I just couldn't handle it anymore. I guess technically I DNF'd the book, with about an hour left to go. The characters are just so overdone and lame. A boxer who's mean cousin slams her hand in the door, so she gets revenge at her wedding and goes to jail? A surgeon who becomes a necromancer because they can't distinguish saving lives from raising zombies?? It's hard to believe that whoever writes this is a real human being that has experienced actual personal interactions. It feels like they are an alien creature who went to myanimelist.com, sorted by worst isekai ever made, and then based all their characters exclusively on shows that were cancelled mid-season for underperforming.

Anyway, I'll need to find something else to scratch the litrpg itch.

title: The Primal Hunter (The Primal Hunter, #1)
author: Zogarth
my_review:
Not as good as He Who Fights with Monsters. I was almost tempted to give this 2/5, just to distinguish it, but I wouldn't really say that it is more bad than good. It does well with the classic litrpg elements: leveling and skills are fun and interesting. The fights are also pretty decent, more natural and maybe even more exciting than those in HWFWM. Primal really benefits from spending far less time on attack descriptions during fights, instead trusting the reader to remember the basics and reiterating the details organically during the action.

However, you have to wade through a lot of cringe to get to the good parts. The characters and dialogs are really stilted and lame. And not just the characters that are supposed to be socially awkward. No, all the characters are stilted, from the gods, to the healers, to the sociopaths. They read like a socially isolated, edgelord 14 year old's idea of how adults interact. The internal monologues are either cringe or unnatural.

The book has promise, and wasn't unenjoyable, so I'll read a few more and see how I feel. But the next book will need to be more impressive for me to continue with the series.

title: The Tombs of Atuan (Earthsea Cycle, #2)
author: Ursula K. Le Guin
my_review: My god these books are good. So short, but so loaded with interest. There is a really great afterward on this book that is worth reading. The book explores interesting dynamics of gender power imbalances. But more than that, this book just leaves so much to think about, in terms of lonliness, useless knowledge, the darkness of living a small and ignorant life. It fills me with deep sadness for the millenia of people who knew and saw so little outside of their own small domains. The sad impotent power of the high priestess. This book is somehow so riveting and true; I can feel the sadness of her life echoed for a thousand years. The way she casually revealed that she could not read, because it was evil.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 11 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #11)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review:
An exiting end with some good fighting and nice emotional bits. Gary dying was really nice, especially the hallway scene. The first half was really weak and boring though. This series is like reading a trashy isekei, but with moralizing instead of fanservice.

I did have a problem with how long it took Jason to get to gold rank. They say that dedicated adventurers get to it in 10 years, but he had already been adventuring for maybe 2 years, then was in a non-stop transition zone for several months, and then they expect me to believe that it took 2 solid years of literally perfect grinding to finally make gold? It just kinda trivialized how amazing the grinding was. It should have been 1 year tops. We could have had all the exact same scenes, but just replace the 2 year timeline with a 1 year timeline.

Like, he only had maybe 7 years of "dedicated" adventuring left to hit gold, and that would have been maybe fighting a couple battles a day. In his realm he literally fought non-stop, at the limits of his capacity, in perfect, manufactured conditions. When we get to the next book, he better be a freaking amazing fighter or I'm going to be pissed.

But that's a small thing. Shade finally dedicating truely was awesome, becoming an astral king was awesome, etc etc. I do have to say that the rabbit was kinda lame, but the book was long enough that I had mostly forgotten my negative feelings about him by the end.

Actually, the first half of this book was a pretty big slog for me. I was very unexcited to read about another transition zone, although the payoff was worth it. Also, who the heck is this random girl that Belinda is suddenly romantic with? Oh, it's the aura girl..? lame. She needs to either get with Sophie or with Clive.

However, I really enjoyed the accelerated pace of the second half. Leaving aside my dissatisfaction with the exact timeline of the power growth, I found it really enjoyable.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 10 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #10)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review: Still enjoying the books. By the time of writing this, I'm already finished with book 11, so this one is kinda blurry to me. I do seem to remember that I thought it moved more slowly than I wanted, but as always, I still enjoyed it. 3.5/5

title: The Wager: A Tale of Shipwreck, Mutiny and Murder
author: David Grann
my_review:
This book was a ton of fun. It's an insane true story of shipwreck, mutiny, cannibalism, legal battles, and group politics. The author deftly takes historical documents and manages to weave a coherent and captivating tale that was well worth the read.

I will say that it occasionally drags, and the author has this annoying habit of imposing modern cultural views on his recounting of the historical events, when the reader may have been better served by just hearing about the facts. I've been trying to pin down exactly why it irritated me enough to mention it in the review, but basically the judgemental tone of the author often seemed unsupported by the evidence of the character's actions. It was typically guilt-by-association with England instead of an actually morally questionable action done by the character. It was enough to make me go and read some of the primary source documents to double check some of his characterizations. I will also say that I sometimes found the primary sources more entertaining than Grann's own writing.

Similarly, when he sometimes went on tangents about the very real evils of colonialism, he did it in a sort of condescending way that hinted the reader might be too dumb to see how bad the mean english were if the author weren't here to remind us.

But anyway, in the grand scope of things that's only a small quibble. I really quite liked the book, and by the time of writing this review have already finished a second by the same author.

[edit] I have since had the chance to read 3 breathtaking books by another author, Adam Hochschild, which cover the sobering topics of slavery, colonialism, torture, and oppression. From the stance of historical journalism touching on moral topics, they stand head and shoulders above Grann's efforts, managing to contextualize the key actors within their time while still allowing the horrors of history to speak for themselves.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 9 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #9)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review:
Mid way comments: I don't love Jason Asano in disguise. Much of the charm is seeing his interactions with people, and I'm less charmed in this book than in much of the earlier franchise. The philandering sections were kinda lame and I could have done without them. They aren't really male gaze in the traditional sense (I can't think of a single female feature having been sexualized in this entire series, other than blue hair, I guess), but it still strikes me as put upon and lame. Also, he's become very uncooperative for no apparent reason, which I only hope is a character flaw he will grow past. I will say that I am enjoying the advancement of the familiars, Colin and Gordon. I think it may have actually been book 8, but I loved it when Gordon did some awesome space magic, and I wish more had been made of that. And it is really exciting to see Colin start evolving to become a voice of the astral kings.

Final thoughts: Ok, I don't know if this deserves a full 4 stars, but the ending really cinched it for this book. Awesome aura stuff, soul invasion, criminal comeuppance, diamond ranker leeching, failed house invasions, cool astral-king politics and messenger situation. I think this is a strong 3.75 rounded up to 4. This series still has some real problematic elements, especially stuff like the occasional over-explaining of the situation and characters, the cast that is sometimes a little too big to make good use of, and the often unnecessary interjections of the magic attack spec sheets...but it really is fun and enjoyable, and I don't begrudge giving the better books an occasional 4 stars.

title: He Who Fights With Monsters 8 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #8)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review: The books are slowing down a bit, but they are still enjoyable. I'd probably rate this higher than a 3 but not a 4. Much of the humor relies on knowing the characters, and although some of the jokes have gotten tired, others still hit home.

title: He Who Fights With Monsters 7 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #7)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review:
I'm realizing how much I really enjoy him impressing people. I really hated it when he passed himself off as human. And especially when he controlled his aura and didn't blast the administrator. In general I really didn't love this book. More average than anything. It started to get going in spurts and jerks, like when we had the convo at the suit shop, or when he took out the builder installation. But overall it struggled to deliver on the promise of politics and intrigue. And at the end, it struggled to deliver on epic battles. This is by far one of the most midling of the series. Only 3 stars.

I will say that the narrator Heath Miller has done a great job for the past few books. I seem to remember not being in love with him during book one, but he's been pretty excellent with his delivery and pacing for at least 4 books now. Also very easy to listen to at full speed. I've been doing 2.2 or 2.0x speed depending on whether I am multi-tasking, which makes these into quick and easy reads.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 5 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #5)
author: Shirtaloon

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 6 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #6)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review:
Not quite as good and dynamic as the past two books. Felt a little rushed at times. There were still some funny sections and good action, but I think this is more of a 3.75 than a 4.x.

I'm still really struggling with the whole tyranny of rank thing. Like, either his aura is OP or it isn't. Author generally does a good job of being balanced, so I'm not picking too hard here, but I do wish that after all his insane aura stuff he was more awesome. Ngl, pretty worried about him being mediocre when we get to book 7.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 3 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #3)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review: These books are getting better. This one is a solid 3.75, rounded up to a 4. Stuff is fleshing out and there are fewer boring sections. One thing I have to say is that I don't love the whole tyranny of rank concept. I often find myself wishing that Jason was more OP, especially with his aura. It's just kinda lame that people can get a stronger aura than him using just monster cores, when he was tortured by an interdimensional being. Tbf, the author does a pretty good job highlighting how awesome the aura is but sometimes I just feel like it is underplayed.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters 2 (He Who Fights with Monsters, #2)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review: I read this book in close proximity to book one, and didn't really distinguish them in my review. You can find my thoughts there.

title: He Who Fights with Monsters (He Who Fights with Monsters, #1)
author: Shirtaloon
my_review:
This was more fun than it had any right to be. I'm a little biased just due to enjoying this genre, but I really was pleasantly surprised. I expected trash, and was pretty horrified by the 10 or 12 book count, but I swear every single book in this series has like 4.5 stars. I definitely don't know that I would go that far, but I think this series is a solid 3, maybe 3.5. By the time of writing this review, I have already started on book 3 and book one is a little hazy to me, but let me get down a few thoughts on what has occurred so far.

The humor is often pretty good. Yes, sometimes it is cringe, but also I have laughed out loud many times throughout the series. The characters are only ok. The main character is fun, but he is also a typical isekai protagonist with basically no flaws that almost always succeeds. Of course, that is also kinda why you read these books in the first place: to watch him level up and be OP in different ways. The supporting cast is interesting, and typically discernible, but I wouldn't say that they are particularly fleshed out; it is mostly surface level.

The deaths and losses that do happen have lacked the emotional impact that I think they could have had. Similarly, the battles often lack real emotional impact, and feel more like a recitation of activities than actually exciting action.

If the fights in these books were actually exciting, then I think they would get 4 stars from me. As it is, the fights are some of the most boring parts, and I find my self more excited for the social shenanigans and plot progression and leveling up/power gaining.

The main character is somewhat annoyingly self aware and moralizing, in a way that makes you feel almost put upon as a reader. You aren't quite being preached to, but it is sometimes a bit r/iam14andthisisdeep.

I think that it is often hard to write characters that are supposed to be super smart or super socially capable. This series doesn't do a perfect job, but it is acceptable enough to be enjoyable. The social machinations are decent, if over-explained.

The length is just too long. These are long books, and there are a ton of them, and the amount of progression and plot movement often doesn't justify the length. Thankfully they can be listened to at 2.2x speed. The narrator, Heath Miller is good but not great. Some of his voices are actually quite good, but others feel obviously put on and fake. The total range of his voices is also not amazing, as you can hear him reusing voices between similar characters.

In all, this is a fun, trashy read with nothing too exceptional about it. It is not going to be on my list of strong recommendations for anyone, but if you are looking for something in the LITRPG space, you could definitely do worse.

title: Heretical Fishing 2 (Heretical Fishing, #2)
author: Haylock Jobson
my_review: Not as good as the first book. The beginning and end were very nice, but the middle was just a lot of nothing, and I got quite bored with the repetitive adding of characters and lack of plot movement. I still had fun, but would have liked to cut out several hundred pages. I still look forward to reading book 3, but this was for sure a downgrade from book one.

title: Heretical Fishing (Heretical Fishing, #1)
author: Haylock Jobson
my_review:
3.5 rounded to 4. This book had a slow and clumsy start, and I almost gave it up after the first chapter. Just some really stilted and amateur writing. But I plowed on, and I'm glad I did. I'm not sure if the writing actually got better or if I just got used to it, but it no longer grated on me after the first 30 minutes or so.

This book makes an ok recommendation for the right reader. I should start by saying that it is absolutely a low-stakes, cozy read. It's the book form of I Got Reincarnated as a Slime without the male gaze. The main character has essentially no flaws, is overpowered AF, and you know everything will work out. But it is just really relaxing and fun to see how it all unfolds.

It's got some nice elements to distinguish it from the typical isekai format, particularly its self awareness of tropes and the desire of the main character to have nothing to do with power building, essentially giving us a whole additional group of characters to follow and invest in.

Set your starting expectations correctly, and this could be a fun book. I'll definitely be quickly reading the next few installments.

title: Ink Blood Sister Scribe
author: Emma Törzs
my_review:
4.5 rounded to 4. I actually really, really liked this book. Maybe my feelings are partially due to the stream of really mediocre books that I read immediately before, but I was immediately taken in by the writing, the exposition, and the characters. They felt like real people with nuanced personalities. The author made great use of multiple points of view throughout the book.

The plot was also really nice and engaging, with only a couple things here and there that irritated me. First, I don't quite buy what the ruling family decided to use magic on. There often seemed to be no real limit to the possibilities of the magic in the world, and the actual things it got used on were often sadly mundane.

I also found the romance a little forced and fast, if not on the girl side, then definitely on the male side.

The book relied heavily on NDA spells and lack of information to drive the plot, which for the most part was totally fine, except on the FMC's part, the one traveling the world. It really made no sense for her to keep her reasons secret from her sister, to the great detriment of their relationship.

All that said tho, this was an exciting and engaging book that makes for an easy recommendation.

title: Pleasing Preceptor, or Familiar Instructions in Natural History and Physics, Vol. 2: Adapted to the Capacities of Youth, and Calculated Equally to ... More Dry and Severe Study (Classic Reprint)
author: Gerhard Ulrich Anthony Vieth
my_review: Love it. I've got an original copy from 1801, and it's positively delightful. It's an intentionally humorous and entertaining book, written towards a scientifically literate but younger (think 18-25) audience. It's an absolute blast to read all of the antiquated science, like phlogiston.

title: French Patisserie: Master Recipes and Techniques from the Ferrandi School of Culinary Arts
author: Rina Nurra
my_review:
Absolutely incredible. People who think cooking is an art not a science need to read this book. It is an absolute masterclass in pastry making with the best detail and instruction I've seen in any cookbook. I've made eclairs, macaroons, tiramasu, puff pastries, and brioche from this book, and everything was perfect.

Highly, highly, highly recommend.

title: Opium Fiend: A 21st Century Slave to a 19th Century Addiction
author: Steven Martin
my_review: It's been 5 years now since I read it, however I remember loving it. As a bit of an impulsive collector myself, I was sucked in by his journey down the rabbit hole. The whole thing felt so chilling and real.

title: A Memory of Light (Wheel of Time, #14)
author: Robert Jordan

title: Flowers for Algernon
author: Daniel Keyes
my_review: beautifully tragic

title: A Modest Proposal
author: Jonathan Swift
my_review: fantastic.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
my_review: Cutting wit matched only by a delightful mastery of the english language. Austen could tell me a 600 page story about paint drying and I would be enthalled. As it was, she told me a slightly predictable romance with plenty of intrigue and a bit of a corny ending, yet had me literally jumping with excitement at the key moments. Unless her other novels greatly disapoint, I have no doubt I will come around to reading all her works.

title: The Making of the Fittest: DNA and the Ultimate Forensic Record of Evolution
author: Sean B. Carroll

title: The Selfish Gene
author: Richard Dawkins
my_review: One of the most intellectually impactful books I have ever read. It fundamentally changed the way I thought about altruism, game theory, human and animal evolution, social constructs, morality, and society as a whole. I've read this book 3 times in the past decade and have bought countless copies for friends and family.

title: Big Bang: The Origin of the Universe
author: Simon Singh
my_review: Loved it. This book doesn't just cover the theory as it stands today. It works it's way up from ancient times, leading the reader on a delightful journey through the scientific methods and discoveries of 3000 years. The finer details of the latest research are now doubtless out of date, but you can look those up on google.

title: The Handmaid’s Tale (The Handmaid's Tale, #1)
author: Margaret Atwood
my_review:
Excellent, haunting, captivating.

I could probably have done without the epilogue, but other than that, I loved every second: the slow revelation of the world, the casual flashbacks, the stark landscape of a dark nation.

I've recently read other such works, which contemplate the lives of the oppressed, and The Handmaid's Tale shines in a way often overlooked. It presents people and society as they truely are: complicated. It does not weave some silly story where all men are sexist pigs and all women are cowed saints. It does not preach a neutered tale of good and evil and easy blame. It presents a realistic world, one of female complicity tinged with quiet rebellion, of blind male callousness mixed with secret empathy.

There are no purely evil characters, and no purely good ones. Too often do writers fall into the trap of painting in black and while, evil and good, corrupt and pure. (I'm looking at you Babel) But an evil system is not made of evil parts. It is built on the backs of a thousand small injustices. It's a picture painted in a million shades of dark grey.

In the Handmaid's Tale, there are women who weild the whip, and their are men who die to save them. We are left with hope, and we are left with despair.

This is one of the best books I have read this year, and it will stay with me for a long time. Strongly recommend.

What follows are just some quotes that stuck me while I read it.


Their heads are uncovered and their hair too is exposed, in all its darkness and sexuality. They wear lipstick, red, outlining the damp cavities of their mouths, like scrawls on a washroom wall, of the time before.


The night mine, my own time, to do with as I will, as long as I am quiet. As long as I don’t move. As long as I lie still. The difference between lie and lay. Lay is always passive. Even men used to say, I’d like to get laid. Though sometimes they said, I’d like to lay her. All this is pure speculation. I don’t really know what men used to say. I had only their words for it.


I threw the magazine into the flames. It riffled open in the wind of its burning; big flakes of paper came loose, sailed into the air, still on fire, parts of women’s bodies, turning to black ash in the air, before my eyes.


What could be done? We thought we had such problems. How were we to know we were happy?


My nakedness is strange to me already. My body seems outdated. Did I really wear bathing suits, at the beach? I did, without thought, among men, without caring that my legs, my arms, my thighs and back were on display, could be seen. Shameful, immodest. I avoid looking down at my body, not so much because it’s shameful or immodest but because I don’t want to see it. I don’t want to look at something that determines me so completely.

Holy shit, that last sentence. Rarely has objectification been so well described.


Dozens of paintings of harems, fat women lolling on divans...being fanned with peacock tails...Studies of sedentary flesh, painted by men who’d never been there. These pictures were supposed to be erotic, and I thought they were, at the time; but I see now what they were really about. They were paintings about suspended animation; about waiting, about objects not in use. They were paintings about boredom.

But maybe boredom is erotic, when women do it, for men.


Better? I say, in a small voice. How can he think this is better?
Better never means better for everyone, he says. It always means worse, for some.


But people will do anything rather than admit that their lives have no meaning.


I sit at the little table, eating creamed corn with a fork. I have a fork and a spoon, but never a knife. When there’s meat they cut it up for me ahead of time, as if I’m lacking manual skills or teeth. I have both, however. That’s why I’m not allowed a knife.

One should note this this quote is about commiting suicide to escape oppression, and when she says she does have teeth, she means the guts to go through with it.


“Nature demands variety, for men. It stands to reason, it’s part of the pro-creational strategy. It’s Nature’s plan.” I don’t say anything, so he goes on. “Women know that instinctively. Why did they buy so many different clothes, in the old days? To trick the men into thinking they were several different women. A new one each day.”

title: The Cheese and the Worms: The Cosmos of a Sixteenth-Century Miller
author: Carlo Ginzburg
my_review:
Excellent, and for the love of god do not read any of the prefaces or author's notes. This is a suspenseful story and they give away the ending.

This book was absolutely engrossing, and I can't recommend it enough. I will say that it assumes a decent bit of prior knowlege about the reformation. It's probably safe just to spend 20 minutes on Wikipedia prior to reading this.

title: The Old Man and the Sea
author: Ernest Hemingway
my_review: beautiful. I greatly enjoyed this.

title: The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
author: Carl Sagan
my_review: Fantastic. What an amazing validation of critical thinking. I've read this book several times and given it as gifts, and it will always be one of my favorite pieces of rationalist literature.

title: A Wizard of Earthsea (Earthsea Cycle, #1)
author: Ursula K. Le Guin
my_review: This book was excellent. It's immediately in my top 10 list. I was in love after 1 page. The writing style is absolutely sublime. If this keeps up throughout the series, I will gladly inhale everything this author has ever written. It's hard to put a pin in exactly what I love about the writing....it has a sort of legendary, antique quality, like a story passed down from another age. The descriptions are somehow understated--the writer captures so much of the essence of emotions and scenes without ever belaboring the point with long paragraphs. The emotional and intellectual journey of the main character strikes me as realistic and believable, and Ged is deeply likeable. I love the magic system; it so effortlessly sets up limits on the powers of the characters. The idea that as you travel from areas you are familiar with, your power wanes because you no longer no the name, the essense, of your surroundings.

title: Of Mice and Men
author: John Steinbeck
my_review: loved it.

title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi (Amina al-Sirafi, #1)
author: Shannon Chakraborty
my_review:
This book is all kinds of wrong for me. For starters, I am almost never a fan of low-stakes fantasy. It's very hard to be interested or engaged when everything is always sure to be hunky dory. This book makes it worse with a kinda childish, story-book tone and a bunch of awkward attempts at character building. It tries to build this cast of cool and quirky pirates and scary villains, but it is overdone in a way that makes them neither cool nor scary. The writing is just kinda bad. I had gotten my hopes up after finishing book 3 of the Daevabad Trilogy (and finding it much improved over the first two in the series) but this book represents a major step backwards in writing.

And then they have the whole breaking the fourth wall thing going on, which I simply didn't love. I think it was trying to be funny or interesting, but I just found it to be a crutch for providing lore exposition. A crutch that unnecessarily pulled me out of the story in the middle of the action at that.

The novel was also riddled with a lot of transparently on-the-nose commentary about social issues. There is the whole rich v poor dynamic with the grandma, the gender identity issues, condemnation of violence, etc. We are reading a book set in the religious, medieval indian ocean world, and the clearly modern commentary and handling of social issues that are delicate even in today's enlightened society was jarring at best. This sort of stuff instantly takes me out of the story.

There is also a kind of weird way that we are expected to believe she is a infamous and awesome pirate, and yet she is also living in an impoverished home, has little social influence, and is morally shocked by minor violence. It's not like she has a reputation for being a morally upstanding pirate. She has a reputation for fucking shit up and being an amazing fighter, etc.

It's also got an exaggerated female version of male-gaze that I think was supposed to be empowering but just kinda came of as insincere/unbelievable. It doesn't feel like a real human female's point of view, it feels like cringy male-gaze with the genders swapped. I read my fair share of female-written romantasy, and this book was the bottom of the barrel in terms of the lameness of its male descriptions.

Maybe in a different mood I would have given this 3 instead of 2, but I didn't really find it average, but rather a notable disappointment.

title: The Empire of Gold (The Daevabad Trilogy, #3)
author: S.A. Chakraborty
my_review:
The other two books in this series were plagued by endless annoying issues, constantly pulling me out of the story to roll my eyes. And at the beginning of this book, I had some similar eye rolls for which I will leave my original notes. However, after getting to the halfway point of the book, I realized that it had been a couple hundred pages since my last sigh of exasperation. By the end, I actually managed to really quite enjoy the ending to the series, and I'm glad that I didn't DNF at book 2. It's hard to give an objective rating, maybe 3.5 rounded down instead of up, since I felt like I had to slog through so much to get here, but overall I was pleasantly surprised by book 3. It was exciting and tied up all the plot lines pretty well.


Original Notes:
Seriously? She betrayed her daughter like that?? She met her one, single time, in insane circumstances, and her daughter was confused and betrayed, death all around her, and you expect me to believe that the mother can't understand this?

And as usual, the author has absolutely no concept of money. You're telling me that she has to trade THREE ENTIRE EMERALDS for a cart ride to Cairo? Give me a break. You could have gotten that for free. For one emerald. For asking nicely. These books would be so nice to read if I wasn't rolling my eyes every third second.

title: The Kingdom of Copper (The Daevabad Trilogy, #2)
author: S.A. Chakraborty
my_review:
Lots more promise, lots more infuriating plot and characters, however, the ending somewhat redeemed it. Overall, I'd say I spent less time in this book pissed off, but it's hard to know how much I am being influenced by the Peak-End Rule. As a rule, the author makes an awful habit of contriving events and conflicts to happen because they will be good for the plot, and not because they make sense in the story or from the characters. And so I spent a lot of time furiously rolling my eyes and being yanked out of the story by incredulity. Which really sucks, because the essence of the plot and the various conflicts really could be so immensely interesting.

As I got pissed off during the book, I scratched out some notes. I'll leave them mostly unedited here:

Time Jump
This started with a 5 year time jump, and I think the author really struggled to conceptualize this. Many character interpersonal interactions read more like a couple months had passed than 5 years. And the intellectual, emotional, and plot progress of the characters also read like only a couple months had passed. As a whole, character relationships with each other hadn't changed or grown in the ways one would expect, character's sense of the world (despair, complacency, love, whatever) hadn't change in the way they should have in 5 years, character skills hadn't grown like they should have, etc, etc, etc.

It was pretty jarring to keep reading how 5 years had supposedly passed, but to then be constantly confronted by identical characters with identical skills, identical emotional problems, and non-existent plot growth.

Silly Stuff
The book constantly has eye-rolling moments, either with how the plot is contrived or with how the characters act. Here are a couple I bothered to write down.

(after nahiri escapes with zanib) You're telling me she has been locked away for FIVE years, and then the first time she leaves the palace she meets the one highly unlikely group of people that would make the plot more interesting??

(when the prince tries to buy the slaves) He's such a child. He's the fucking prince, and he's going to solve this by buying them? And he's going to use his sword? God I hate him. Also, what is this stupid rift between Muthadir and Ali? It's just so lame and manufactured.

He's so dumb I hate him. TELL HER. Why is he too stupid to tell her that he brought it for her.

Paper Father
The bad guys often have these paper thin reasons for doing bad things. Mostly they seem to be doing bad things because the plot requires them to be idiots that do bad things, not because it makes any sense.

For instance it would not have been hard at all to verify the courtesan's identity, but instead we get this manufactured conflict. The king is not so stupid that he would threaten the stability of the city over an easily verifiable claim.

Also, the shaffit attack on the parade was so dumb. As if they would attack the one person who healed shaffit and is actively working to improve their conditions. I would buy it if they had attacked another part of the procession.

Complete Lack of Empathy
There is a recurrent theme of enemies having a mutual friend and then getting into conflict. And always, always the conflict happens anyway despite the mutual friend. It can be an interesting and heart-breaking plot device when it is truly unavoidable, but the author wears it out and uses it in cases where an easy solution seems obvious, making it lose its impact.

Interesting Points
The plot has some redeeming qualities. For instance the 3-way conflict has a lot of potential. The ancient lore being slowly revealed is really interesting. Especially finding out the past was not what you thought. Although I will have to mention that dhara could seriously just explain himself for once, holy shit. The magic is also pretty cool, though it is definitely plot-driven magic. You have it when the plot needs it, you don't have it when the plot needs you to not have it.

Anyway I think I'm bored of writing about this book. Why is it always the case that I write more about books I took issue with than about books I completely enjoyed? I'll read the next one just to see it through to the end. Thankfully it can be read at 2.2x speed with no trouble.

title: The City of Brass (The Daevabad Trilogy, #1)
author: S.A. Chakraborty
my_review:
So much promise, such spotty execution. I'm reading this because it comes highly recommended by a friend, but I swear it is pressing every plot and character button I possess. The politics and characters and lore are all interesting, and are the saving grace of this book. However the interaction of plot and character is a nightmare. I'm constantly screaming to myself, "HOW does that make ANY sense!? why would you DO that???" It makes for a pretty frustrating read when you often find the character actions utterly stupid and unbelievable.

Here is some stuff that I rage wrote near the beginning of the book. Yes. It was so bad that I had to stop and vent.

Bruh, this book is so badly written and ill-considered, I can't even... The whole premise is that MC is stuck in Cairo and wishes she could get to Istanbul to study healing. She herself blatantly has healing magic -- her wounds heal in seconds and she can heal other people with her thoughts. And yet, listen to this: she doesn't believe in magic. All the magic that happens in the book it shocking to her. And you know how her dream is to go to Istanbul? In the first few pages alone we see her earning jewelry, coins, a gold ring, and the ability to steal from a wealthy man home for 7 days straight. And we are expected to believe that this thieves purse couldn't get her to Istanbul??? Later in the book, we hear such ridiculous comments as: she had never had wine, it was far beyond her means. Yea ok. I'm sure a woman with gold rings couldn't afford a cup of wine.

So I was thinking, whatever, maybe it will just get better. It does not. She consistently makes the most ridiculous decisions, not because she is being portrayed as unintelligent or traumatized, but because the author just can't be bothered to engage in realistic writing. MC is given a magical warrior protector and is being taken to a city of magical beings to be established as the honored princess of a massacred race, and her only thought is to run back to Cairo. I'm maybe two hours into the book, and I'm already itching to write pages of criticism.

Having now finished it, there were many more similar instances of non-sensicalness, such as why is she so weak and useless, why did they have to fight in the infirmary, why is everyone incapable of simple communication, etc, etc.

Hopefully the next book gets better, as this one really does have obvious promise.

title: I Don't Want to Talk About It: Overcoming the Secret Legacy of Male Depression
author: Terrence Real
my_review:
I first heard this book mentioned in Outlive, and later had it recommended to me by a friend who found it to be very relateable to their own life. It has a good deal of interesting commentary on father/child relationships, the nature of male depression, and how men are brought up as emotional (or non-emotional) beings in modern society. In general I found it to be very well-considered and nuanced. The commentary is interspersed with anonymized stories from his therapy patients. These examples serve to give insight into actual situations experienced by real-world people as well as insight into his own methods for conducting therapy.

So, why three stars? Well, amongst the positives already mentioned, this book just kinda dragged on without seeming to have a strong organization or message. I really missed out on having sections which attempted to consolidate his views on masculinity in society. I also really felt the lack of any instructive guidance given on actions a depressed man can take. Yes, there are scattered examples from therapy sessions, but this is by no means a helpful guidebook, which is both part of what I expected and what it easily could have been. As I grew more and more used to it falling a bit short of my expectations, I grew more and more anxious for it to end. So, it won't really make its way into my core set of recommendations.

But lets step back and see what interesting topics were covered:
- toxic masculinity
- shame vs grandiosity
- illusion of tenderness and sex / mistress as medication
- masculinity, unlike femininity, is conferred. that's why it can be taken away
- performance based esteem

Toxic masculinity: This has gained many variations of definition in the almost three decades since this book was released, however here it refers to cultural norms that perpetuate idealized masculine traits, such as emotional repression, dominance, and stoicism, to the detriment of the individual and society. The author gives many examples of how boys are expected not to cry, to not be momma's boys, and many other small societal nudges that ultimately discourage men from expressing vulnerability, or seeking help. Personally I find myself convinced by the premise that this core difference in male and female upbringings has impacts for emotional well-being in later life.

Illusion of tenderness: The author further posits that many toxic traits he comes across in therapy sessions are simply twisted medication. That a man with a mistress is engaging in the illusion of tenderness.

This is all somewhat tied in with performance-based-esteem. He posits that male esteem is often not fully intrinsic, but is derived totally or partially from personal and societal perceptions of his performance. I think of myself as an emotionally consistent and stable individual, but if I'm introspective, I realize that I absolutely have performance-based-esteem...I've simply been lucky enough to almost always perform well. I feel this explains so much about depression and culture. How losing your job causes depression. How incels go through a downward spiral. How men gravitate to competition, be it in the workplace, video games, chess, etc. Hell, it might even be useful to keep this in mind when considering the wage gap.

He has some interesting things to say about the conference of masculinity, whether it be in tribal rituals, on the football field, or in a stock meeting. I don't know how true it is to say that femininity is not conferred, but I can certainly see how the conference and retraction of masculinity effects myriad aspects of our culture.

title: Morning Star (Red Rising Saga, #3)
author: Pierce Brown
my_review:
Solid end to a solid series. It has some flaws here and there, specifically with a melodramatic main character and a tendency to seesaw between absolute victory and absolute defeat, but overall I definitely enjoyed it. I plan to read a few books in the interim and then pick up the rest of the series. Might wait until the 7th comes out in 2025, idk.

Speaking of seesawing, here is something I wrote at the beginning of the ending, which totally had me, hook line and sinker:

"Cassius gut punched the shit out of me. I did not see it coming. I probably should have, but I didn't. I almost rage/sad quit right then. It was one thing when it was book two, but I'm pretty tired to be this far along and have victory snatched from our grasp by the betrayal of a friend. There is just always all this false build up, just seems to unnecessarily prolong the series. At some point, I want it to end and have resolution. It's just so bipolar, from victory to tragedy. And I just KNEW that the second Sevro got married one of them was gonna die. Such a death flag."

I was actually pretty crushed at this "ending", and so relieved when it went the other way. I also must say that I really enjoyed Sevro's hanging with Cassius. Such an epic scene, and a cool throwback to the whipping in book one.

title: Golden Son (Red Rising Saga, #2)
author: Pierce Brown
my_review:
You know, I'm usually really picky about the technical details making sense in a novel. It bothers me endlessly when all the facts don't line up, and this novel has some obvious silliness going on. Like, why do golds always need to lead the charge and be involved on the ground? Could they really have kept the reds in the dark all these centuries? Why are human soldiers still relevant in this age of space travel? Why would that EMP be set of by a human and not a radio signal? Why won't he just tell the damn girl?

But for some reason, most of these things never manage to bother me as I read. I think it is a combination of three things:
- for most of these it's easy to come up with my own head canon even if the author doesn't directly explain it
- non-sensical elements never really ruin the plot for me
- the book is simply too fast paced for me to dwell too much on anything amiss

In terms of head canon, the EMP thing seems ridiculous. Why would you have a living human set off an EMP when radio, wifi, and bluetooth exist. But then you remember that they spend half the battle talking about jamming signals, and it makes a sort of sense. Why do golds charge into battle? It's ridiculous. But then you can say to yourself that at least among the elite golds, who grow up on stories of battle and conquest and pride and glory, it makes a certain cultural sense. And it's pretty easy to come up with a reasonable explanation like this for most of the problematic areas.

In terms of ruining the plot, the questionable element is rarely something integral, like when there is a massive conflict underpinned by simple communication error, and I'm forced to be stressed out while the characters make obviously ridiculous decisions. Instead it's more like, sure, he won't tell the girl, but their relationship is only a little strained, not destroyed, and there seem to be pretty damn good reasons for not telling her. To take another example, yes, I find it hard to believe that the reds would have never found out the truth after centuries in the dark, but it's also easy to imagine the brutal murders of entire towns if word ever emerged...maybe it's not that unlikely after all.

As for fast paced, I think that speaks for itself. At times, I think that this book might even be a little too fast paced, with the action overwhelming the chance for character development.

On to the actual review...overall, this book was a fast-paced and exciting sequel to Red Rising. I think I may have liked it a little less, but not enough to downgrade the 4 star rating. The ending was marvelous.

title: Red Rising (Red Rising Saga, #1)
author: Pierce Brown
my_review:
Surprisingly good. Exciting, interesting characters, good plot. Easy 4 stars.

It took me a little while to really get into it, but it has some really exciting and fun battle scenes by the end. It also had a pretty nice leadership character arc for the MC.

The narrator, Tim Gerard Reynolds, was excellent. Delivered some very powerful lines.


You do not follow me because I am the strongest. Pax is.
You do not follow me because I am the brightest. Mustang is.
You follow me because you do not know where you are going. I do


There is one key necessary suspension of disbelief, mainly regarding MC's improbably high intelligence and test performance. I think it is mostly explained away by the test being of lateral thinking and not necessarily of knowledge, but one still wonders why the rest of the golds couldn't get some body and brain mods to do better at the test, and how we ended up with such a brilliant kid being chosen to be plucked out of the slums. I can't say that it bothered me much during the story, mainly because I think we all know how these stories are supposed to go, and it's fun to just go along for the ride with a prodigy. The author also balances it out with failures along the way and the fast pace and engaging writing.

title: Assassin's Quest (Farseer Trilogy, #3)
author: Robin Hobb
my_review:
Overall, this was a good series. Good plot, interesting magic, strong characters. It has a few minor problems which I have mentioned in the previous reviews -- mainly that it isn't as exciting as many modern works, the characters are sometimes stupider than the reader, and the author often inserts needlessly clumsy reminders of past details. For all that though, I enjoyed it.

Here are a few jottings I made throughout when things annoyed me.

Hear the beginning, I found myself getting pretty annoyed here and there with Fitz's refusal to allow any kind of help and his insistence on keeping secrets, but at least it tracks with his history of dumb decisions.

As the end approached I was repeatedly aghast that they couldn't figure out obvious plot points, such as needing to wit to the elderlings, which, if it wasn't obvious enough from the fools prophesies, was painfully obvious as soon as they found the elderlings. The author really wanted me to stretch my imagination at the end to believe the characters so stupid as to not realize the "statues" were the elderlings, and the wit was the secret to waking them.

And then the fool suddenly asking about Molly could not be more suspicious. This is one of the few times I felt that Hobb let the desire for a certain plot muddle the actual expected actions of the characters. There is no way this sudden questioning could have gone unnoticed, as it was clearly telegraphed to the reader the moment it was done.

And to compound on all this the silly refusal of the party to understand Verity's actions...there at the end the author really leaned into how utterly blind all the characters were in order to have the plot work out in a certain way.

And of course I disagree strongly with Fitz's silly refusal to be acknowledged. It's hard for me to say whether I think it is bad character writing or I just disagree with the choice, maybe more of the latter.

Oh, and it's like every new female character immediately wants to get into bed with Fitz. I wouldn't say this series has male gaze, and as we all know this series was written by a woman, but somehow it still sticks out like a sore thumb. I think it is partially how the author handles it. Sure, I know that even in the real world, there are some men who are effortlessly attractive and have a disproportionate amount of partners. But they don't attract every woman.

I probably wouldn't hesitate too much to recommend this series to a fantasy fan, however it would come with the caveat that it reads like an older series and has a slow burn and shouldn't be expected to be fast page turner.

title: Royal Assassin (Farseer Trilogy, #2)
author: Robin Hobb
my_review:
For starters, I hate these intros where he is an old man and he tells you things about the overall plot. What is this weird desire to spoil things for me??

Secondly, I hate, HATE this ridiculous romantic conflict arising from miscommunication trope. It's almost enough to make me put the book down.

It's also pretty annoying dealing with the intellectual incompetence of the characters.
- fool clearly saying the wit is how to contact the dragons
- queen having the wit
- bastard fighting the white magician with the wit, and no one understanding
- the forged not being detectable by the wit

And by god, could it be more obvious that Molly is pregnant? Just exactly how stupid is our main character??

It also seems pretty off to me how little is made of Fitz's battle prowess. By all accounts he should be loved and respected by his fighting peers, and his reputation should spread throughout the keep. Yet somehow the author never makes anything of this. I don't think I've ever seen the bond of fighting men treated so casually in all of literature.

Sometimes it just gets a little too ridiculous how none of the common folk can see Royal's constant betrayals. How he abandoned the queen to die but no one mentions it. How he abandoned the raided town but everyone acts like it was he who sent out the message, despite many witnesses. And on and on. I don't mind having his conniving manipulation of the rumor mill be a plot point, but sometimes its effects are exaggerated further than I can believe.

How in the fuck do all these morons maintain this incredible ignorance?

The writer has this extraordinarily clumsy way of pointedly reminding you of who characters are and what happened a couple of chapters ago. She'll bring up a character we haven't seen in a while and proceed to give a little book report on them as if we had not a single neuron in our brains to remember anything. Truly, I often struggle when a book has too many characters to remember who is who, and I can certainly appreciate a gentle reminder here and there, but by god this writer goes overboard with it to an almost insulting degree.

For all this though, the book has an interesting an unique plot with a wonderful magic system. The characters are strong and 3 dimensional, and even if the book doesn't exactly turn pages, you still can't help but plow on.

I think this second installment impressed me more than the first, but I still struggle to give it a full 4 stars. 3.5 rounded down, as I still don't know that this would be my strongest recommendation.

title: Assassin's Apprentice (Farseer Trilogy, #1)
author: Robin Hobb
my_review:
A fun and enjoyable read. This book sort of has an old, dated feel, especially in the pacing and the action. It is certainly slower and less of a page turner than its modern fantasy contemporaries. However after suffering through the endlessly ill-considered plot and characters of Rothfuss, this book is a breath of fresh air.

It has interesting and distinct characters whose actions make sense, and a plot that is driven by logic rather than the random whims of the author. Had this book been a bit more exciting, I would have given it 4 stars, but as it is, I'll give it 3.5 rounded down to 4, since I although I would mention it as interesting fantasy, it's not something I'm itching to recommend.

title: The Wise Man's Fear (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #2)
author: Patrick Rothfuss
my_review:
In general, this is similar to the first book; a self-indulgent male fantasy with weak characters and a plot that is more concerned with aligning to the author's grand plan than in actually making sense. It must be admitted that it is fun to read, but its flaws in plot and character writing are overwhelming.

I don't know if I have the desire to fully enumerate all of its shortcomings, and this review will be rather low effort, but I'll list a few things as they come to me.

God, the section with the malfeasance was so dumb. 1) the writing. it's just so convenient that MC supposedly can't go to the masters about it. The author is always setting up too-convenient sequences like this. But even setting up this supposed rationale, the whole sequence was miserably considered. First, lets say that I buy that he can't go officially to the masters. What is to stop him from going to a single master he trusts? At this point the author is just looking for reasons to have him do illegal things. And then there is how he makes constantly unintelligent decisions. Why the hell would he go to buy the plans instead of just going to the library first. And in what INSANE world would he think that making a doll of her would be a good idea. And all the secrets he keeps for no reason from his friends. The whole thing is just badly written and makes no sense.

The romance scenes. So gross, so much cringe virtue signaling. From the disease section to the 'not all men' section, it just never stops. It's like reading a shitty harem anime. And what romance scenes that aren't cringe aren't even spicy, they are just boring and self-masturbatory. You could write pages on what's wrong with the 'romance' in this novel.

I mentioned this in the review for book one, but Rothfuss is constantly shoehorning the story into his grand vision for the plot. It's like he wrote an outline that said: MC needs to be poor, really poor, and did I mention destitute. But then when he starts actually writing, the story and the characters and simple logic make it clear that he should be able to casually make money, so the author is forced to either ignore logic or to make up silly plot happenings to ensure that we have a shitty explanation for why MC remains destitute. Like when he saved the mayor's life, got him a brand new wife, eliminated the bandits, AND took care of a murdering and raping troop, and the mayor tells him he is hopelessly in debt to him, and yet MC still manages to barely capitalize on this. Whether it is from MC's unexplained sudden inaptitude or a contrived hatred for the Ruh, he manages to never get any decent reward.

I don't know. It's honestly a bit hard to understand how TWMF gets such glowing reviews, considering its flaws. This book is so well-liked that I'm tempted to put more effort into seriously criticizing it, but I kinda just want to move on with my life.

title: The Name of the Wind (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #1)
author: Patrick Rothfuss
my_review:
I was very lulled into the first half of the book. I've always been a sucker for living vicariously through the life of a prodigy, especially magical ones. For some reason it's just great fun to watch a young student kick ass. So I found a lot to like in the first section of the book, with the broodingly powerful innkeeper, the traveling troop, and the hijinks at school.

However, there are some constant flaws that underly the writing, specifically with consistent portrayal of character decision making. We are presented with this MC who is an undisputed prodigy in every possible field he tries his hand at. He is wickedly intelligent, creative, picks up languages and mental techniques fast, is a beautiful singer and musician, can hold a conversation with the best of them, and is even easy on the eyes.

And yet somehow, after 6 months or so of mourning in the forest, when he enters the city, he somehow manages to be a useless twat for three entire years. At no point does he juggle for money, tell stories, sing, use magic, or even use his intelligence in any way. He just lives in abject miserable poverty with barely a hint of explanation from the author as to why the reader is suddenly expected to completely ignore the MC's immense innate talent, his prodigal existing skills, his ridiculous ability to pick up new techniques, and his already vast knowledge on seemingly every subject, from math to medicine

Oh sure, there's a hand wave here and there about traumatic memories, but this in no way explains his miserable state as a starving, helpless street urchin.

The school section seemed to finally get us back on track, but then the story started to fall apart for me again during the journey to explore the blue fire. All the conversations seemed lame and stilted, and the plot was silly. This author really seems to gravitate towards this plot device of accidental or malicious drugging, and it's always weakly implemented.

It is also worth mentioning that the writing of female characters is very weak, despite some rather off-putting virtue signaling by the author about consent and violence. Every female character is either beautiful or mysterious or incredibly talented. In short, every female character manages to be the object of one male fantasy or another.

I certainly don't mind reading about smart and beautiful women, but there is a difference between beautiful women as people and beautiful women as plot devices. As a quick tally, we have the gorgeous library girl who exists to be gorgeous and saved in the fire. Then we have the cute but crazy rooftop girl, who exists to be cared for like a stray cat. Then we have stunning but flighty Dana, who exists to be tragically unobtainable...and on and on.

Then there is the weird virtue signaling. I must mention here that the virtues being signaled are obviously commendable, however the awkward signaling of them was just...weird. Like we have that one scene where Dana has been drugged and is crying and telling MC how she knows he would never beat her, even if he had to. And instead of the writing feeling like an honest exploration of violence it was instead somehow cheap and pandering. I should also note that at the time of writing, I'm halfway done with the second book, and there is a similar weird scene when MC has the anti-inhibition drug.

Anyway, this book had a lot of promise, and had a significant head start by being from a genre I am almost guaranteed to enjoy. But it was consistently held back by weak character writing and contrived plots. Obviously I liked it enough to read the second one, but it won't be at the top of my fantasy recommendation list.

title: Crazy Rich Asians (Crazy Rich Asians, #1)
author: Kevin Kwan
my_review:
Not great, but a solidly entertaining book. I was reading some dry non-fiction and needed a break and picked this one up. It's cringey and predictable, but in a way that makes you look forward to the next scene instead of wanting to put it down.

The writer definitely struggles to show and not tell -- you can especially see this with characters like Astrid, who are written to be amazing and perfect and incredible and awesome and wonderful but are mostly shown being materialistic and weak.

I think a big part of the enjoyment is vicariously living these wild lives through the story -- the idea of buying the hotel where the manager snubs you, or casually taking a private jet to a private island of debauchery.

I do think it was pretty interesting that even the best of the characters were still incredibly shallow and materialistic at times, like Astrid with her $200,000 dresses and Araminta with her island shopping spree and awful friends. I think we are meant to like both of these characters or at least sympathize with them, but they are nonetheless often shown in a decidedly mixed light.

I could definitely have done with some more resolution on the ending, but I guess that is what the rest of the series is for. I won't read the next books immediately, but I wouldn't mind picking them up if I wanted a light read.

title: A Separate Peace
author: John Knowles
genres: Classics|Fiction|Young Adult|Historical Fiction|School|Coming Of Age|High School

title: The Ashes & the Star-Cursed King (Crowns of Nyaxia, #2)
author: Carissa Broadbent
my_review:
For a romance novel, the action and the plot were actually pretty enjoyable and fun. Although I definitely spent the first half hating the fmc mmc conflict. Like, ugh. Why does book two of every romance series have to be frenemies. I'm so bored of it; just make up your mind. Once our main characters finally reconciled it was such a relief. I will admit that the author provided very convincing reasons for the conflict, so at no point did I feel like it was manufactured.

The romance in this series is notable and somewhat trauma oriented. The author's emphasis on constant, vocal consent is noticeable in the first book, but by the second book it is almost fetishized. And consent is not just a romantic thing. For instance in the first book, you see it in a lot of little scenes, like how fmc will shy away from any vampires, and subsequently it is presented as a big deal when mmc allows her to have physical space. There is also that one blood drinking scene in the first book with the knife and mmc being so careful to make sure fmc is "in control".

By the second book, it's kind of a constant background note in all romantic scenes, and a non-trivial part of the romantic development is fmc feeling more and more comfortable with mmc. There's one scene in particular where the mmc makes a huge deal about getting consent for missionary, since unlike when fmc is on top, in missionary she would be "trapped", and fmc has an internal monologue talking about how surprising it is to feel safe with him, etc.

Mmc has been through intense trauma for 70 straight years, and fmc had a traumatic first experience, and had grown up as a weak human in a world of vampires, which is presented as its own trauma. These themes of trauma and how they affect the platonic and romantic relationship are frequently explored.

The romantic scenes themselves are pretty well-written, better than A Fate Inked in Blood, I think. Although I will say that this author does not hold back on the whole vampire thing. She manages to make blood sucking a very sensual part of the romantic scenes.

Anyway, there were a few plot points that bothered me. Septimus was presented as extremely calculating, and based on the socio-politic landscape the author showed us, I saw no real reason for him to betray the main characters. It made for an interesting plot, but didn't make much sense. Additionally, the power scaling sometimes seemed off. Vincent razed whole cities with his power, but sometimes our main characters, even with their combined strength, will struggle against far lesser enemies. We are simultaneously shown terrifying power and unexplained inadequacies, depending on what the plot requires.

Finally, the coreatus bond was not perfectly justified. Clearly the vampire god can casually bring people back to life, based on the ending to the first book. So in the second book, bringing mmc back to life would be a trivial thing. She wouldn't have needed to ruin the bloodlines with a heart bond to do it. But for plot reasons, we needed this special bond. It was fun to have it end that way, but it didn't make logical sense.

I also had some problems with the pacing. This whole series kinda seems like big battle, almost die, miraculous recovery, BIG BATTLE, ALMOST DIE, MIRACULOUS RECOVERY, again and again and again. They kinda stop being exciting when they happen so often and everyone always miraculously recovers no matter what.

To sum up, if you are willing to slog though the frenemies bit, and a plot complaint here and there, this is a fun continuation to the first book in the series.

title: A Tale of Two Cities
author: Charles Dickens
my_review:
Another beautifully written work by Dickens, this is not the sort of thing you can listen to at 1.7x speed. I managed to get this one narrated by Anton Lesser, who was excellent, as always.

Even more so than Great Expectations, this book is absolutely packed with quick historical references. I had a good time on this site afterwards, learning about some of the references in the first couple chapters. https://dickens.stanford.edu/tale/print_issue1_gloss.html

It is hard to say whether I simply wasn't in the mood, or if the book really was worse, but I certainly enjoyed myself less in this novel than in Great Expectations. It is true that it moves at a faster pace, covers an interesting subject matter, and has an engaging plot. However, as with Great Expectations, I often found all the character connections to be rather contrived, and some key elements to be rather predictable.

Overall I think this is a 3.5 on enjoyment rounded up to a 4 by virtue of the writing and the fact that I probably would recommend it to someone wanting to read some 1800s works.

title: The Shadow of the Gods (The Bloodsworn Saga, #1)
author: John Gwynne
my_review:
There is a lot of non-sensical stuff in this book. Why was the escaped thrall abandoned on the beach and then saved? Why do the blood sworn need to kill the jarl instead of talking? Why doesn't that bear thing they captured turn into a bear first in order to fight them instead of being captured? Why does the psychopath thrall have to kill the dad?

Sure, the setting and mythology are cool, but so much of this book reeks of manufactured action, and not of well-considered plot. The violence just makes no sense.

The characters do not act like real people, with motivations and strategies and a healthy concern for their own lives. Instead they fight and kill and die for no reason. Individuals jump into fights with impossible odds. War bands enter large battles with no planning or strategy. The violence isn't realistic, it is simply used by the author to make the book seem exciting and drive the endless revenge plots.

Speaking of plots, holy lameness. Depending on how you count, there are 3-6 main characters in the book, and FIVE of them are driven by a one revenge plot or another. Is this author incapable of writing anything unique or interesting??

Ugh, I'm tired of writing this review. This book sucked and I googled the rest of the series. Hard pass.

title: The Serpent and the Wings of Night (Crowns of Nyaxia, #1)
author: Carissa Broadbent
my_review:
Ok, hear me out. Yes I know, it's full of cliches, and sometimes the plot can be a little silly. Like, what are the chances that her only friend in the world just happens to get teleported in and brutally murdered right in front of her? But the book is just so fun.

All the characters feel far more adult than the usual romance fare. It was nice not to have to slog through a bunch of whining and second guessing and pointless miscommunication. I also found the MMC FMC dynamic to be somewhat fresh. I mean, yes, he was tall, dark, and quietly dangerous, as always, but unlike the moody, frowning buckets of darkness that we usually get, he had a constant, playful positivity in his interactions.

The whole, I-murder-a-vampire-every-night plotline wasn't the most believable thing in the world, but at least it actually gave some credibility to our FMC's battle prowess.

I should probably clarify my 4 star rating by saying that this is not a book I would recommend to just anyone, but if you are in the market for a fun romance read with some definite spice, there are definitely worse options.

title: Drawing Dimension: Shading Techniques—A Shading Guide for Teachers and Students
author: Catherine V. Holmes
my_review:
Perhaps one star is a little harsh, however I had high expectations for this book of which I was rudely disabused. I own several books geared towards beginners that reference shading here and there, and I expected this to be a book-length treatment of the critical sub-topic of shading. It was not. I expected to learn advanced and interesting shading techniques. I did not.

This book was a weird mix of far too basic and extremely complicated with no explanation. The horribly explained contouring section comes to mind. Additionally, it was text heavy with very few exercises or unique examples. Most of the content of the book is shown on the front cover. I don't necessarily mind a text heavy art book so long as the text is insightful and supports sufficient examples. 'Human Anatomy for Artists' by Eliot Goldfinger is a good example -- volumes of useful text explanation coupled with hundreds of brilliant illustrations. Unfortunately this book was a major disappointment.

As another reviewer mentioned, significant space was dedicated to milquetoast QA between the author and students that was usually unhelpful and often contained useless, self-congratulatory praise for the instructor's lesson. It seemed like a poor attempt at copying the style of Mark Kistler in his superior 'You Can Draw in 30 Days'.

I read this book in Kindle Format, however my review is of the contents of the book. I did not remove any stars for how pathetically the Kindle version was rendered. If for some reason you still wish to buy this book after reading my review, I would recommend purchasing a physical copy.

title: The Complete Costume History / Vollständige Kostümgeschichte / Le Costume Historique
author: Auguste Racinet
my_review:
This is an absolutely gorgeous reproduction of the 1888 Le Costume Historique. It was originally published in 6 leatherbound volumes spanning a combined 3224 pages with over 500 plates, and a complete copy can set you back a couple grand. There are some excellent scans of the original work in the French here https://library.si.edu/digital-library/book/costume-historique.

This reproduction is massive, with images 3 to 4 times bigger than in the original copy, and it is wonderful to look at. As it comes in at less than 700 pages, much attention has been placed on reproducing the plates, at the cost of sacrificing a huge amount of the original text. What space that is given to the text is done so in usual Tachen form, it English, German, and French, further reducing the available real estate.

I find the work rather suffers from this choice, as there are countless instances where I have been flipping through the plates, found a particularly interesting numbered figure, gone to read the description, only to find that it has been excluded for brevity.

The publishers themselves mention this lack, and I understand its reasons, but it is unfortunate. Truth be told, if they sold this in a version twice as long but twice as expensive, I probably would not have bought it.

However, there is one missing element that I find inexcusable, and which is the primary reason I could never countenance giving this Tachen edition 5 stars. The book completely lacks any reasonable table of contents or index. If you come to this masterpiece hoping to look up a particular country or time period, you will be sorely disappointed. Although the book is loosely organized by historical period, and segmented within by the region under discussion, actually finding the region you are interested in is nigh impossible. I have spent ages flipping through the pages looking for a plate I had lost or a time period I wanted to explore without success.

If you have an interest in clothing, art, world culture, or in late 1800s books, then this is an easy recommendation.

title: Great Expectations
author: Charles Dickens
my_review:
My first introduction to Dickens, this was a truly lovely novel. I listened to the Anton Lesser narration, and he did a wonderful job, nailing the various accents and manners of speech.

The writing is lovely, and the plot is fun and engaging, with lots of nice twists, even if they are sometimes predictable. The characters are quite interesting at times; Dickens felt no need to have the main character always be likeable.

It's perhaps a little cliche by modern standards, or perhaps I mean to say that the plot is at times contrived, but I still think that it holds up very well.

He's got some lovely turns of phrase:

The sergeant took a polite leave of the ladies, and parted from Mr. Pumblechook as from a comrade; though I doubt if he were quite as fully sensible of that gentleman’s merits under arid conditions, as when something moist was going.


There are also many instances where you have to really pay attention to catch references which would probably have been much more transparent at the time or writing. I shudder to think of how many I must have missed entirely.

There were carved garlands on the panelled walls, and as he stood among them giving us welcome, I know what kind of loops I thought they looked like.


Loops here, is of course in reference to the hangman's noose.

By the time of writing this review, I am almost done with Tale of Two Cities, and I think that Great Expectation is a gentler introduction to Dickens.

title: For Whom the Bell Tolls
author: Ernest Hemingway
my_review:
This is a hard rating for me, and sometime in the future I might turn this jumble of thoughts into a real review. I liked the book, especially Hemmingway's sad endings. And I liked the deep subject matter and the philosophical and political musings.

However I often felt the characters and the dialog to be forced, and I found the philosophy to be rather on the nose. I also found commentary on Pilar's descriptions to be self congratulatory.

Regarding the writing style, I preferred it to A Farewell to Arms, but didn't love the 'direct' spanish translations. The way 'thee' and 'thou' were used and molested instead of bothered, ect. I speak enough Spanish to get what he was going for, but I can't really fathom why. Robert Jordan was meant to be a professor of Spanish, with only a bit of an accent noticeable to a native speaker. So he would not have made these sorts of clumsy translations. And I find they harm the reading experience.

Furthermore, it is completely unclear to me what the pattern of usage for thee and thou was. Whenever I paid close attention, it neither lined up with usted and tu, nor with plural and singular, so I struggle to understand his intent.

A real shame to about all the 'I obscenity in the milk of thy mother's'. What a stupid world that censorship keeps authors from writing what they'd really like.

Anyway, I have some temptations to give this a 4, but the book really was a mixed bag for me, so it'll get a 3 for now. I read the Campbell Scott naration, and it was in a rather lovely, mid atlantic accent.

title: A Farewell to Arms
author: Ernest Hemingway
my_review:
I loved The Old Man and the Sea, but was initially very disappointed with A Farewell to Arms. The terse style that did so well in the mostly two character book struggled to convey the same emotions for me in the character and dialog dense Farewell to Arms.

From a historical sense, I loved reading all the dated references. The constant drinking, even while pregnant to 'keep the baby small'. Walking everywhere and not knowing where people were. Food not being available past lunch time. The attitudes towards marriage and the baby. It strikes me that fantasy writers really should read more written during the 1800 and early 1900s, as I rarely see these types of elements mentioned.

There were times while reading this book that I was sure I would give it two stars. It wasn't average, I felt, it was actively failing to meet expectations. But having finished it, and thinking over it, my opinion seems to grow and grow. I find myself fondly remembering the way I felt, living the lives with the characters.

And the ending. Holy shit what an incredible ending. If there is anything to say for Hemingway, he nails the feeling of deep loss, without ever needing to over sell it.

I think this may have been a 4 star read under different circumstances, maybe I'll revisit my rating if I end up recommending it to a lot of people, but for now I'll give it a 3.5 rounded down to a 3.

title: The Sunlit Man
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review: Another enjoyable book by Sanderson. I don't know if I would call it low stakes, like Tess of the Emerald Sea, but it is definitely a somewhat cliched, story-tale kind of novel. I certainly had fun reading it, and enjoyed all the cross-references to Stormlight, but I'm not really itching to reccomend this to anyone, so I can't justify giving it higher than 3 stars.

title: Shadows for Silence in the Forests of Hell
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
Short and fun, an excellent introduction if you want to get into Sanderson's writing. I'm certain that I have read this before as a part of some collection, but I was told I needed to read it before reading Sunlit Man, so I gave it a reread.

I feel like I've been giving away too many 4 stars lately, but I can't really find any reason to fault this story. It's compact and satisfying and quickly builds an interesting world.

title: Warbreaker
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
Pretty wild to read this after plowing through all of the Stormlight archive. The difference in pace cannot be understated.

I had a few minor problems with it here and there, such as Vasher being overwhelmed a bit too easily in fights every now and then, but overall this is a really solid addition to the cosmere. I think this would be a perfectly good entrypoint to Sanderson's writing, and is of course worth reading before book 2 of the stormlight archive.
