Though the first princess definitely took some time to grow on me, I enjoyed both of their stories and thought it had a nice, engaging plot.

Spoilers ahead. I don't totally know how to feel about the two deaths in the book. They both took me by surprise, which is excellent, and I'm tempted to find them very moving, but I can also see that they were somewhat manufactured for maximum emotional impact by the author, as opposed to feeling like a natural part of the plot.

At the end of the day though, this was a fun book with an interesting magic system and premise, and would be an easy recommendation for a quick fantasy read.

Apparently it is hard to get ahold of, but I listened to the Michael Kramer narration, which was excellent.

title: Rhythm of War (The Stormlight Archive, #4)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
The fight scenes are still great and the interplay of the characters and their motivations is wonderful, but man this book plodded along. At over 1200 pages, it's the length of some trilogies, and I certainly didn't feel like I got a trilogy's worth of plot in this book.

The whole 'am I a scholar or am I not' plot seemed kinda forced, with the character 'growth' being more told than shown. Dalinar's plot was particularly underwhelming; almost nothing happened, and that which did occured in only a few pages.

I'd definitely say this was the weakest of the main series for me.

title: Dawnshard (The Stormlight Archive, #3.5)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review: Fun book bringing us some interesting new characters and lore. Nothing really particularly amazing though, and a bit forced at times.

title: 羊と鋼の森 下 [Hitsuji to Hagane no Mori 2]
author: Ai Mizutani

title: Oathbringer (The Stormlight Archive, #3)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
Another great installment in the series, with some epic moments and awesome battles. I really like the structure and pacing of the book. It's broken into 4 parts that focus on a handful of main characters. However at the interludes, he'll give quick glimpses into minor characters that provide context to the overall narrative. The pacing is also really interesting. It will often be a normal sort of chapter per character, but when the action gets intense he will often jump almost frantically between viewpoints, in a way that really contributes to the storytelling.

The final battle was really well-done and exciting, and overall there were some really great scenes. Definitely looking forward to the next couple books.

title: Edgedancer (The Stormlight Archive, #2.5)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review: Quick and fun interlude, and a chance to learn about some interesting side characters.

title: Words of Radiance (The Stormlight Archive, #2)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
This is everything that epic fantasy should be. Now that the characters and their powers and personalities are maturing, there are some really epic scenes. I was shouting with excitement during some of the better scenes. The politics are fun, the action is great, the budding romance is tantalizing, the writing style is fluid, and the multi-pov/flashback structure is engaging.

I will absolutely be reading the rest of the series, and regretting that the fifth book has not yet been released.

title: The Way of Kings (The Stormlight Archive, #1)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
Excellent. This is entertaining epic fantasy with action, intrigue, and captivating stories.

It's narrated by Michael Kramer and Kate Reading. Kramer is ok, but not great: his inadequacies really show during action scenes. Kate Reading is horrible. I almost DNF'd when I realized she would be reading significant parts of this 45 hour book. Her normal speech pattern has this unnatural rise in tone at the end of every couple words, and it grates painfully on the ears, making it hard to focus on the story. Meanwhile, her accents for fictional foreign characters are the worst I have ever heard, out of approximately 200 audiobooks.

Narration aside, this is a very enjoyable book with interesting and novel fantasy concepts that satisfies in its own right and promises an epic story to come.

title: Spinning Silver
author: Naomi Novik
my_review: Surprisingly good, this is a fun and easy fairytale read. There are two narrators, and I much preferred Lisa Flanagan.

title: Tokyo at Night - The Artworks of Mateusz Urbanowicz II
author: Mateusz Urbanowicz
my_review:
Massive disappointment, this book in no way lives up to its predecessor, Tokyo Storefronts. Where that book was full of delightful art, interesting commentary, and careful details, this book is has only mediocre paintings, masturbatory art commentary, and no fun details to speak of.

I liked basically every page of Tokyo Storefronts, but I struggled to find even 2 paintings that I liked in Tokyo at Night, both from the section on rain. Everything about this book is worse, all the way down to the mediocre dust jacket and soulless cover. This is the kind of book I would return if I had bought it on Amazon.

title: Tokyo Storefronts - The Artworks of Mateusz Urbanowicz
author: Mateusz Urbanowicz
my_review:
Positively lovely. This is an easy 5 star coffee table book. The attention to detail is extreme and the art is delightful.

It contains 50 or so paintings of Tokyo store fronts, typically in a two page spread. One page gets the full storefront painting and the opposite page gets 4 detail insets with fun facts, descriptions, and artist commentary, written in both Japanese and English. Every 10 stores, there is a dedicated 2 page spread that summarizes the last 10 stores and gives some more facts, dates, and addresses. Starting the next section you get an artistic map of where the next stores will be. And at the end of the book there is an illustrated section with the artistic tools and supplies the author uses.

The book itself is great. It's a soft cover with a book jacket, and the publisher added some fun details. The book jacket shows a completed painting of a storefront, but if you take it off, the physical cover shows the same storefront in the original pencil sketch with perspective markings. The inside of the cover has a map of tokyo with all the stores drawn on their location as cute tiny versions of themselves.

It's a great book to flip through, and a great book to sit down and read. Each of the storefronts is interesting and unique, and this is one of my nicer coffee table books.

title: Red Side Story (Shades of Grey, #2)
author: Jasper Fforde
my_review: A delightful read that lives up to the original. It's probably important to know what tone to expect -- it's a dystopian novel that nonetheless doesn't take itself too seriously. Keeping that in mind, it's an engaging book with a creative society and fun plot. And it manages to wrap up all the mysteries of the previous book and give a satisfying ending. A definite must-read if you read the first book.

title: Clockwork Angel (The Infernal Devices, #1)
author: Cassandra Clare
my_review:
I made it 5 hours into the 14 hour audiobook before giving up, and my only regret is that I didn't stop sooner. This book has excellent reviews, so an hour in I was rather surprised, at 3 hours I was becoming deeply worried, and by the 5th hour I could no longer stand the weirdly fake and stilted interpersonal interactions. This author writes about human emotions as if she's a newly sentient slime mold whose only knowledge of humanity comes from binge watching jersey shore.

I'm tempted to give a bunch of examples of characters completely altering their emotions and behaviors simply because the plot demanded it, or quoting some of the robotic dialog interspersed between unrealistic plot points, but I honestly don't want to spend anymore time thinking about this miserable excuse for a book.

The top negative review for this book was from Kat Kennedy, and man do I wish I had read it before starting, "...so I can go back to imagining a world where authors like this are forcibly chained to their desks and made to read their own stories over and over again until they’re sorry."

title: Genki Japanese Readers [Box 1] (Japanese Edition)
author: Eri Banno
my_review:
I have been dreaming of a graded reader to go with the Genki textbooks, and these are perfection. I have listened to the free audiobook version of these on the OTO Navi app probably a dozen times, and will probably listen many more. They are a decent length and go perfectly with the grammar and vocab in the textbook. I'd give a full 5 stars, but the print copy is insanely expensive, and I've not convinced myself to fork over the money to see how the quality is.

One should note that although the print edition was apparently not published until 2023, the audio was out at least a year before that.

title: Am I Small? Watashi, Chisai?
author: Philipp Winterberg
my_review: It's about Genki 1 level with some common phrases genki doesn't teach but you really ought to know by that point thrown in. It has hiragana and english, as well as an english transliteration of the hiragana. I actually kinda didn't like having the transliteration, since if you've gotten to the point where you know this grammar and vocab, then you certainly know hiragana, and I found myself straining to read the japanese before my eyes would dart up and read the transliteration. For the ~30 sentences you get, it is not a cheap book. Probably I need to abandon children's books and do graded readers.

title: うえとした/ Up and Down
author: Catherine Hnatov
my_review: This is good practice at the Genki 1 level; you should be able to read almost every word, with only a couple to figure out through context. Additionally, it has both english and hiragana, which is very helpful. So, why 3 stars? Well, it's a board book with literally 10 pages and two tiny sentences per page. Near the end you get some mildly complicated stuff, like　黒い猫は白い猫の上にいます。but mostly it's just at the level of 犬は外にいます。So basically you are paying for 20 short sentences with pictures. It also loses points for having no kanji, which would have been great since a reader of genki would have known most of them.

title: なまえのないかいぶつ
author: Naoki Urasawa
my_review: Delightful book and the perfect companion to the show. The front has this wonderful hologram, and the interior drawings are great. They've wonderfully reproduced the supposed publication dates of the original stories and have the handwritten pencil marks over the printed Japanese. In addition to the stories, there are also some lovely pencil character reference sketches of the children and mother.

title: Breaking Rockefeller: The Incredible Story of the Ambitious Rivals Who Toppled an Oil Empire
author: Peter B. Doran

title: The Universal Penman (Lettering, Calligraphy, Typography)
author: George Bickham
my_review: Incredible collection of penmanship. It's wonderful that this is available as a reprint on amazon. This book is a must-have for any calligrapher.

title: The Hike
author: Drew Magary
my_review: Unique and interesting; I quite enjoyed it. It was a little too low-stakes to get a 4 out of me, but I might recommend this to people looking for something unconventional. It's playfully symbolic in an unpretentious way.

title: A Fate Inked in Blood (Saga of the Unfated, #1)
author: Danielle L. Jensen
my_review:
This was fun. The magic system was interesting and the action was surprisingly good. Plot was pretty entertaining too, even if I couldn't stand the main character sometimes, especially near the end. Seriously her reaction during the ending was the worst.

SPOILERS ahead. It's been obvious since page 5 that Bjorn hates his dad, and obvious to everyone except Freya, apparently, that he was the "traitor". And yet for some ridiculous reason she freaks the hell out at the end, refusing to listen, let him explain, or realize the blatantly obvious. And then right when I thought she would have had a chance to get past the initial shock and have an adult conversation, SHE JUMPS OFF THE FREAKING BOAT. ugh.

Anyway, although the flirting was pretty corny at times, I did think some of the earlier frostbite intimate scenes were better than Fourth Wing, which is currently my only other romantasy to compare with. The build up was definitely not as good though.

Overall a fun and quick read, although not quite good enough that I'm itching to recommend it to anyone. I'll definitely read the next book when it comes out.

title: Morningwood (Everybody Loves Large Chests #1)
author: Neven Iliev
my_review:
Have you ever wanted to read a story about Runescape written by a porn-addicted 13 year old boy? Then holy shit have you found the right book. The writing is on a 3rd grade level, the erotica is terrible, and the "humor" doesn't even deserve the name.

The premise sounded so promising; a dungeon chest monster that eats unwary adventurers slowly starts leveling up and accidently becomes super powerful. The reader would get to watch as shapeshifting chest got more intelligent and learned to exploit the world in unique ways. Based on the cover art and subtitle, obviously we were going to have to put up with some fanservice, but this book has crazy high ratings on amazon and goodreads, so it's probably going to be funny and interesting?

No. Absolutely not. It was miserable. The female characters were clearly written by a 31 yr-old incel licking doritos off his fingers while his mom screamed down into the basement that his hot pockets were ready. And the cool level-up story line was borderline boring. I mean yea, I did finish the book to find out how it would end, but holy shit was it a chore. If you are the kind of person who enjoyed I'm a Spider So What? or That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime and you think I am just being harsh because I didn't know what to expect from the genre...no. I enjoyed both of those shows, despite their flaws, and by comparison this book has almost no redeeming characteristics whatsoever.

Like, I don't need a 10 page tutorial on how hp works. And when that tutorial is over, I don't want to read a poorly executed plot full of weak characters, rampant sexism, and flat humor. If you want to get into litrpg, try Dungeon Crawler Carl instead.

title: City of Stairs (The Divine Cities, #1)
author: Robert Jackson Bennett
my_review:
After reading The Tainted Cup, I was very excited to read more by Bennett, but lord preserve me, this book was mediocre. The dialogue was stilted and silly, the characters didn't resonate as real people, and the narration by Alma Cuervo was abysmal. It's as if Recorded Books grabbed a random lady from the Target checkout line, handed her a book and a mic, and wished her the best. Her voice acting had the fake intonation of a middle school play, and it often didn't even bother to be appropriate to the lines being read. Her ability to perform different voices is nonexistent, and the editors managed to leave in the sounds of every cough and page turn.

Although the world building was often unique and interesting, the themes the author explored quickly wore thin. The characters were constantly struggling to understand "deep" philosophies that I had grown tired of hearing of 100 pages earlier. And someone should tell Bennett that plot twists don't deserve the name if they've been obvious for a dozen chapters. Even the political machinations and character behaviors were often weird and unrealistic to the point of yanking me out of the story to shake my head in disbelief.

Looking at the publication dates, this book was written ~10 years before the first one I read and liked, and it certainly reads like a young author's early attempt at writing. Supposedly the second book in the series gets better, so maybe I'll pick that one up at some point. Anyway, this had enough problems to be a 2.5 rounded down to 2, since it definitely doesn't deserve a spot with some of my recent 3s.

title: The Tainted Cup (Shadow of the Leviathan, #1)
author: Robert Jackson Bennett
my_review: Entertaining and creative. The worldbuilding is really fun and unique, and you are just kind of thrown into it blind. Probably one of the cooler worlds I have read since Perdido Street Station. Definitely enjoyed this, and will try to check out more from this author.

title: Circe
author: Madeline Miller
my_review:
So. Good. This is not some romping adventure. It is a book about loneliness. About womanhood, and motherhood, and longing. About living in last place, but struggling to live anyway. About walking through an unfair, uncaring world and seeking out the meaning in it all. It's about the happiness that you can find in life, if only you look for it, and the painful joy of being mortal.

Circe is a minor goddess, born just short of beautiful and just short of brilliant. Her tale is of being shunned by the gods and abused by mankind, but also about the isolated islands of fulfilment she finds along the way. The story and the characters held me, and the ending was perfect. It's an easy 5 stars and a strong recommendation.

Quite a few powerful quotes in the book, these two on traditional perceptions of womanhood.

Humbling women seems to me a chief pastime of poets. As if there can be no story unless we crawl and weep.

it is a common saying that women are delicate creatures. Flowers, eggs...anything that may be crushed in a moment's carelessness. If i had ever believed it, I no longer did.

This next one is little lost out of context, but basically Circe's companion is finally going to the island, however Circe is longing for company, for true companionship, and she can only pretend to be happy about this and everyone knows it. Some authors would spell this out. But Madeline doesn't bury our faces in this sadness, rather she lets it wash over us with the the unspeaking sorrow of things unsaid. She does this often throughout the book, and I treasured the author's willingness to let emotions rest, writhing under the surface of quiet words.

I spoke briskly. "You should take the boat of course. It's charmed against sea-disaster ... it will let you leave as soon as you are ready."
He was silent for so long, I thought he had not heard.
Then he said, "that is a kind offer, thank you...Then you will have your island back."
I heard the crackles in the brush. I heard the sea distant on the shore. The sound of our breaths vanishing into its ceaseless wash.
"Yes", I said. "I will."

title: Starter Villain
author: John Scalzi
my_review: Fun, inventive, satisfying conclusion. 3 stars is probably a little harsh; I'd say it's above average in its execution, but I can't think of anyone that I am itching to recommend it to, so 4 seems a little generous. Did a pretty great job of having no plot holes or annoyances and a nice, lighthearted tone. This is the sort of book you pick up for a quick and fun read, and I wouldn't mind reading another from this author.

title: The Eye of the Bedlam Bride (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #6)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review: I enjoyed it and have no regrets. Narrator is still amazing, and the story is still fun, and I still look forward to finishing the series. However, the excitement is a little gone for me. Maybe it's because I made the mistake of binging 6 in a row, or maybe the quality really is a little less. To be fair, I have really been enjoying the larger storylines play out. And there were definitely some sad parts and some very exciting parts as well. I guess this is really a 3.5 from me, but it doesn't feel quite right to lump it in with the other 4 stars on my list, so I'm giving it a 3.

title: The Dungeon Anarchist's Cookbook (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #3)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review: started really bogging down a bit in the middle, but really ramped up with the katya storyline, and the ending was excellent

title: The Butcher's Masquerade (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #5)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review: I think this has been the weakest for me. I didn't care about the storylines as much, we really didn't get to see much cool stuff from Donut based on her skills, and I wasn't as entranced by Carl. It got better near the end, but I found myself not caring about the deaths. It was, of course, really nice to see Carl killing all the hunters, but, idk, I still felt like it lacked some excitement from the previous books.

title: The Gate of the Feral Gods (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #4)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review: The outside storylines are getting excellent. The admin part was simply awesome.

title: Carl's Doomsday Scenario (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #2)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review: Also great, although maybe not as funny as the first book

title: Dungeon Crawler Carl (Dungeon Crawler Carl, #1)
author: Matt Dinniman
my_review:
When I saw the cover, I was immediately worried. Sure, it has insanely high ratings on goodreads and amazon...but so did Legends and Lattes, and that book was terrible. And the premise is so easy to mess up: you could make it too cheesy, spend too much time on mechanics, have too many easy outs for characters or bad power balancing. Turns out, I was worried for nothing.

This book is everything I could want in a light-hearted lit-RPG. It's got the humor of Portal and the absurdity of Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, all wrapped up in a nostalgic RPG setting. It was funny, fast-paced, engaging, and I thoroughly enjoyed myself.

Reading it is very much like playing a video game, and I expected the author to struggle with pacing and implementation details. However, by the time of writing this review, I have already read 5 of the 6 books in the series, and although there have been a couple slow spots here and there, overall the series is a real page turner.

The author is slowly building a complicated world both inside and outside the dungeon, and I'm very excited to see how all the pieces will come together.

Also, the narrator is amazing. This is one of the few books where I am confident I prefer to listen, as the narrator Jeff Hayes adds so much to the experience.

title: The Five People You Meet in Heaven
author: Mitch Albom

title: American Midnight: The Great War, a Violent Peace, and Democracy's Forgotten Crisis
author: Adam Hochschild
my_review:
It's tempting to view history through the lens of linear progress, with America as the stalwart bastion of liberty, shining her bright light for all to see. I mean, maybe we had slaves for a little while, but we totally freed them in the civil war, and after that we were one big happy melting pot. Right?

Sure, everyone in school is taught that the south was racist, Andrew Jackson was mean to the Indians, and maybe even that we had Japanese internment camps in WWII. Maaaybe there is even a lesson on the Pinkertons. But these things have a feeling of being contained, and, well, ancient history. But Hochschild takes the reader on an awful ride through a time period where you could be hated just as much for being the wrong kind of white as you could be for being black. Where the US Postal system actively shut down newspapers it didn't like and engaged in a wide-spread censorship campaign to suppress free speech. Where blacks trying to make a living after moving North to the safety of Illinois were nailed in boxes and burned alive. Where you could be fired just for taking driving classes from a dirty German. Where making a film about the American revolution, which showed the Brits in a negative light, would land you in jail for 10 years and with the modern equivalent of a $90,000 fine.

Hochschild shows us a world where pastors had their churches burned to the ground for giving sermons on the wrong subject in the wrong language. Where labor organizers were jailed en mass, on false charges, with local, state, and even federal government officials complicit in the intrigue. Where United States senators could be characterized as being, 'ardent defenders of lynching', and a constant worry in the hearts of many Americans was that blacks would get too uppity after serving in the military. After all, first the black man gets his expectations up after meeting French women, and then "it is but a short step to the conclusion that his political rights must be respected" (actual quote from a pro-lynching Senator). Women, who still couldn't vote, were also getting dangerous ideas. This was a world where among the many terrors of Bolshevism was the horrifying prospect of women divorcing their husbands and having freedom and autonomy.

God help you if you were pro-labor and anti-war. Frank Little, a white man who held both of these dangerous positions in Montana, was dragged alive behind a car before being lynched. Surviving evidence indicates involvement by the local mining company and the local police's chief detective. After the murder, the Vice President of the United States quipped that, in solving labor problems, "A Little hanging goes a long way."

If you had rewritten this book so it seemed that all these things were taking place in some foreign dictatorship, I would have shaken my head sadly at those sad souls living sad lives in their sad country, then saluted the nearest bald eagle before reciting our glorious constitution. But no, all this happened here, in America, 50 years after slavery ended and almost a century and a half after the drafting of the Bill of Rights.

It's wild to read about how political figures knowingly used forgeries such as The Protocols of the Elders of Zion to push anti-foreign, anti-jew, and anti-bolshevik agendas. It's tempting to think that in the modern age, we are somehow beyond this type of manipulation, yet people today seem no less willing to believe obviously fake content, whether it is anti-science dogma or transparently manufactured news stories. It's tempting to think we are somehow beyond all these toxic feelings, yet we still live in a divided country swamped with anti-immigration sentiment. One could imagine that we are impervious to such miscarriages of justice, yet it seems to be a monthly occurrence that I read about another police officer who killed someone with no consequences.

I think a core message in Hochschild's writing is that our democracy walks a delicate line. Just how far are we today from the society that we have clearly been before? The time period in the book was one marked by intense external stressors and deep uncertainty about the place of each human in society. We have certainly made a lot of progress in the past 100 years on human rights, but if American Midnight is anything to go off of, the wheel of progress can be turned back swiftly and resolutely.

In terms of content, this book was excellent. In terms of narrative and engagement, this is the weaker of the three books I have read so far by Hochschild. Chains and Leopold also covered broad swaths of information, but Hochschild carried you along on the backs of individuals with fascinating stories, whose lives tied together the narrative. Midnight certainly tries to accomplish this same feat, but I think it is ultimately too scattered to accomplish it. I also couldn't stand the narrator, Jonathan Todd Ross; he has the fake inflections of a 3rd grader trying to sound like a news reporter.

The book is definitely a fact-laden slog -- I haven't even come close to encapsulating it in this short review -- but if you are willing to put in the effort, I think it is well worth the read.

[edit] It's been about a week since writing my review, and I've had this nagging feeling that I failed to capture some of the real import of the book. Crucially, how Hochschild highlights the interplay between related tensions, and how I worry that this is important in our time as well. As an example, take racial and labor tensions. He often highlights how tensions between european countries, or between natives and immigrants, were leveraged by companies during strikes, or how black strikebreakers would later be lynched. Then there is the relationship between anti-bolshevik sentiment and anti-feminism. The actual, or imagined, freedom of women in bolshevik society, to divorce, freely choose partners, and live independently was often lumped in with its other supposed negative aspects. I think it's important to realize both ways this was played; bolshevism is bad because we presuppose that women's freedom is bad, but also that women's freedom is bad, because of its association with bolshevism. It seems to me that society often struggles to parse out the pros and cons of a viewpoint; we want to paint a thing as entirely good or entirely bad, without empathy or discretion. Anyway, I've just kinda word vomited this, and should probably come back later and tighten it up. [end edit]

I've left a few quotes that struck me below.


White rioters tossed a Black child into the fire. When the crowd discovered a Black man who had tried to hide in a large wooden box, they nailed it shut and threw it, too, into the flames.



A rival politician once called Harding’s verbiage "an army of pompous phrases moving over the landscape in search of an idea. Sometimes these meandering words would actually capture a straggling thought and bear it triumphantly, a prisoner in their midst, until it died of servitude."



A worried psychologist bemoaned the disturbing new times when “spinsters can support themselves with more physical comforts and larger leisure than they would have as wives; when married women may prefer the money they can earn and the excitement they can find in outside employment . . . when they can conveniently leave their husbands should it so suit their fancy” and, worst of all, when “men . . . must compete in the market with women.”



Over several days, looking for victims wherever they could find them, the mob killed at least 13 Blacks, one of them a farmworker named Hayes Turner. The next day, his wife, Mary, eight months pregnant, made what a Georgia newspaper called “unwise remarks . . . about the execution of her husband.” The mob strung her up to a tree by her ankles, doused her with gasoline, and set her on fire. As she screamed in pain, a member of the mob knifed open her belly, and when her unborn child fell to the ground and gave a cry, men stomped it to death...
The mob included the foreman of the county’s grand jury. No one was ever prosecuted

title: Dune (Dune #1)
author: Frank Herbert
my_review: Meh. Flat characters, weak plot, and unengaging action. Our main characters are met with convenient resolutions at every turn. Absolutely no death was remotely emotional. The villains are boring and the heroes are boring. The author has an irritating tendency to rush through the most interesting parts. Doesn't matter if it is a character growth arc, a romance, or a fight scene...if it seems interesting, Frank Herbert will find a way to skip it. Transparent philosophy and underdeveloped politics. First book really should have been a trilogy or at least a duology. I really struggle to understand the hype.

title: The Yellow Wallpaper
author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
my_review:
Excellent and moving. Considering its length, this is an easy, easy recommendation.

I've listened to two versions, an annotated one read by Jessica Renfro (which was terrible) and an unadorned original read by Jo Myddleton. The Renfro version was overwrought and haughty, with an annotated introduction that seemed more intent on explaining modern views on the subject than on revealing the context the work was written it. However, in the Jo rendition the main character absolutely leaps from the page, perfectly narrated first as timid, and then descending into unaware madness. I would say that Jo's reading is even superior to what I would have done in my own head.

title: Snow Crash
author: Neal Stephenson
my_review:
Fantastically imaginative, yet often painfully over-explained, Snow Crash is a book that rarely trusts the intelligence of its reader, and one that often has the reader wondering about the intelligence of its author.

The society portrayed is a fascinatingly fractured, post-capitalist anarchy where the Mafia is a friendly franchise and US government is a parodied enclave. It features a what laughable mix of technology, where software has apparently only progressed 10 years and materials science has progressed 100. It's a world where a 15 year old girl's skateboard has enough nanotechnology to make a US General drool, AI is advanced enough to carry on a conversation but not to summarize a document, and hand knapped glass knives are powerful enough to slice through military-grade bullet proof armor.

There's no doubt that it is a fun book to read, but if you know even the first thing about the scientific or historical concepts being discussed, then by the last chapter your face will be left in a permanent rictus of astonished cringe. For every new topic he explores, it's like he overheard the least important 30 seconds of a one hour lecture on the subject, and then proceeded to expand on his shallow knowledge for a book length treatment. God help me if I have to hear that binary is the universal computer language one more time.

Binary provides an illustrative example. One of his core plot points relies on the premise that binary is the deep language of computers, and that over the course of years of hacking, software engineers internalize it in a meaningful way. Which is ridiculous of course. Yes all computers technically share binary, but nothing approaching a language happens until you get to assembly code, and that will be different for every processor. In biological terms, he's saying something like, atoms are the deep code underlying all life on earth. Technically true, I guess, but the example he was really searching for is DNA. And just like no zookeeper will ever meaningfully internalize the language of DNA, much less atoms, no hacker will ever meaningfully internalize binary.

I mentioned it earlier, but he really, really does not trust the intelligence of the reader. All of his world building is excruciatingly explained, instead of shown through the plot, and every little joke or pun is painfully spelled out. To be fair, he did build a really interesting world full of satire and hijinks, but he's constantly ruining it with his overbearing explanations. I would have loved to have this world revealed organically in the manner of Perdido Street Station. And also to be fair, his does interperse his explanatory expositions with some really wonderfully subversive, off-the-wall descriptions, like his camera case/lingerie comparison that I'll leave at the bottom.

On a more generous day I might have given this book a 4, but I don't think it's the sort of thing I would go around recommending to anyone. There is more to be said about the pacing of the plot and the action, the elements of surrealism, and the book's historical place in the sci-fi canon but I'm sure other reviewers have all explored these elements better than I will.


The top surface of the computer is smooth except for a fisheye lens, a polished glass dome with a purplish optical coating. Whenever Hiro is using the machine, this lens emerges and clicks into place, its base flush with the surface of the computer. The neighborhood loglo is curved and foreshortened on its surface.

Hiro finds it erotic. This is partly because he hasn't been properly laid in several weeks. But there's more to it. Hiro's father, who was stationed in Japan for many years, was obsessed with cameras. He kept bringing them back from his stints in the Far East, encased in many protective layers, so that when he took them out to show Hiro, it was like watching an exquisite striptease as they emerged from all that black leather and nylon, zippers and straps. And once the lens was finally exposed, pure geometric equation made real, so powerful and vulnerable at once, Hiro could only think it was like nuzzling through skirts and lingerie and outer labia and inner labia. . . . It made him feel naked and weak and brave.

The lens can see half of the universe—the half that is above the computer, which includes most of Hiro. In this way, it can generally keep track of where Hiro is and what direction he's looking in.

title: River of Stars (Under Heaven, #2)
author: Guy Gavriel Kay
my_review:
There is a lot to like in this book, in terms of the graceful writing style and legendary atmosphere. However, I often struggled to buy into the characters and their decisions. The main character's decisions, especially, never seemed to fully line up with the way the author was writing his personality. I'd be a real fan of the ending if I felt like it lined up with the previous character arc, but I really didn't, so I hated it. Overall, I'd definitely say that I liked Under Heaven better.

3 stars is a little harsh...if goodreads offered 3.5 then I would do that. But I've been giving away 4 stars reviews like candy recently, and they feel like they are starting to lose meaning.

title: Under Heaven (Under Heaven, #1)
author: Guy Gavriel Kay
my_review: Lovely book. I was totally enamoured in the first half, and loved the characterizations and the writing style. The author does a great job with POV shifts. The romances were a little cliche, but they were still fun. The ending was wrapped up a little too quickly and neatly for my taste, but I still liked this well enough that I'm already looking for other books by this author to read.

title: Bury the Chains: Prophets and Rebels in the Fight to Free an Empire's Slaves
author: Adam Hochschild
my_review:
Hochschild is excellent as always. Truly fascinating to read about this pivotal moment in history. I won't spend too long on the review; the book was great, everyone should read it. I wrote some thoughts on Hochschild's exceptional historical contextualizing in my review of King Leopold's Ghost.

However I did learn quite a few unexpected things during the reading of this book which I wanted to write down so as not to forget.
- I already knew the journey across the ocean was deadly for slaves, but what I didn't realize was that the journey across africa to the coast is thought to have been even deadlier
- I'm from the American south, and I always had the view that the southern states in America had by far the most slaves and the worst conditions. Apparently this isn't even remotely true: orders of magnitude more slaves were shipped to brazil (5 million compared to only a quarter million), and slavery in the Caribbean islands was far more deadly, necessitating constant shipments of slaves just to keep the population from declining. Even the Netherlands, of all places, shipped almost double the slaves as America.
- when slavery ended in the US, 0.25 million slaves had grown to a population of 4 million. When it ended in the British West Indies, a imported population of well over 2 million slaves had died off to only leave 670k. In the words of Hochschild, 'The Caribbean was a slaughterhouse.'
- the literal Church of England owned murdering slave plantations, and the Bishop of Canterbury was fully aware of the death rate and chose to do nothing about it
- a country-wide abolition movement in Britain was casually halted by war with France. It was absolutely horrible to read how such a popular and beautiful movement was crushed so easily by the government and society during a time of panic and war. Hochschild has an entire book on a similar period in America during the 20s, and I am anxious to read it. I feel that far too little time was ever spent in my own education on understanding how an entire population gets caught up in a populist fervor with often dismal consequences.
- I had never previously put 2 and 2 together to understand how big of an impact press ganging sailors must have had on British sentiments towards slavery
- the amount of casual rape and murder committed by all countries and all peoples will never cease to astonish me, no matter how many historical narratives validate it as the status quo in almost all places and all times. When I was younger, I used to read of lurid scenes in historical fiction and shake my head at an over-excited author. However the more history I read, the more I think that most authors are actually underselling the horrors of the past

title: King Leopold's Ghost: A Story of Greed, Terror, and Heroism in Colonial Africa
author: Adam Hochschild
my_review:
What an incredible book. Hochschild unpacks this devastating period of human history in a way that does great credit to his background as both a journalist and historian. He crushes you under the weight of the atrocities in the Congo while still giving a full picture of the political, societal, and personal contexts. Where historical documentation allows, he delves deep into the fascinating stories of all the main characters, and the historical narrative often reads as interesting as a novel.

Complete understanding of the actions and beliefs of individuals in the far past is often obscured by the mists of changing times and social norms. It is the responsibility of any decent historian to use their deeper knowledge to contextualize the past for the reader's benefit. Today, the mindsets of the colonizer and the oppressed may seem so far removed as to be incomprehensible. Yet Hochschild carefully explains the past, in a way that lets us judge characters by both the standards of their time, and our own.

What results is a riveting account that feels balanced and full bodied. He'll read you the sappy love letters of the villains to their wives while revealing the myriad failings of the heros. And the book is so much the better for it.

There was apparently much recorded as to the many atrocities committed in the Congo, via the numerous letters and investigations of the time, and although Hochschild certainly gave them their due, I would not have minded even more time spent detailing them.

Overall I was quite impressed, and by the time of putting this review to paper, I have already read a second book by Hochschild and intend to read at least one more.

title: Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood
author: Trevor Noah

title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
author: Matthew Walker
my_review:
Absolutely excellent. This book is a tour de force on sleep which should be a part of every school curriculum and required reading for every legislator.

Dr. Matthew Walker effortlessly walks the line between keeping the book interesting and readable while still cramming it full of science. He consistently covers the known mechanisms by which sleep and its associated processes operate and effect the body, considers both correlational and causal meta studies, and gives actionable recommendations for your own life.

Amongst a sea of bad health recommendations, poorly considered studies, and a general lack of understanding of the underlying mechanisms, Why We Sleep stands far above the rest, with its clear science and engaging writing. This is the kind of book that I'm already itching to read a second time, just to make sure that I fully absorbed all of the material. Highly, highly recommend.

title: A Land So Strange: The Epic Journey of Cabeza de Vaca
author: Andrés Reséndez
my_review:
This was by no means a bad book. But it was solidly average when it comes to non-fiction. Interesting enough to read fully and good information, but I really felt like it left a lot of potential excitement on the table. It did a great job of contextualizing the adventure narrative (probably half the book was contex), but when we got to the adventure itself, it just felt like a dry recitation of facts, instead of an epic journey.

To be fair, this wasn't that long of a book, but I still almost wish that I had read the Wikipedia page instead, and used my time on something else.

title: The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II
author: Iris Chang
my_review:
Heartbreaking. This is a soul-crushing account of the Japanese invasion and massacre of Nanking. It's told with clarity and impact, and the atrocities it details left my stomach churning.

I read a fair bit of non-fiction, and not all of it well-written, so I was worried that this book received high rankings only out of respect for the subject matter and not for the writing. But no, this is a 5 star book in every category. Iris Change deftly guides the reader through the historical landscape, contextualizing the social environment of the Japanese military in the years building up to WWII. In a concise and devastating volume, she takes us through every important aspect of the atrocity, covering the civilian, military, and global reactions, as well as the then current (late 90s) political and social response in Japan. At no point does the book bog down in the details, and you are always itching to turn the next page.

She clearly gives all the facts, and this is in no way a hit-piece on the Japanese people as a whole. She is just as eager to reveal the original atrocity and the subsequent government coverups as she is to highlight the Japanese who lost their jobs trying to publicize the massacre.

In all, this is a magnificently well-crafted and unbiased accounting of a relatively unknown period of rape, torture, and murder on the scale of 100s of thousands of Chinese civilians. It will break your heart, and it should be required reading in every school.

title: The Wisdom of Crowds (The Age of Madness, #3)
author: Joe Abercrombie
my_review:
Exciting, decent twists, great action. Great end to a great series.

I wish I had read it closer to the First Law Trilogy, so I could evaluate which one I liked more. I really like the way that he slowly disintegrates relationships for genuinely good reasons. Fiction is full of authors who seem to think that a small miscommunication is enough to doom a romance, and Abercombie never falls into that trap. Relationships are ruined by deep resentment, lies, self-pity, jealousy, and violence.

I really loved some of the final character revelations. Some I saw coming, and others totally surprised me and were perfect. The same was true of the plot twists. Some were predictable, others were literally predicted, but others caught me quite by surprise. I think a real power in Abercrombie's writing is that even if I felt like I had predicted the outcome, I was nonetheless very excited to see how it would come to pass.

title: The Trouble with Peace (The Age of Madness, #2)
author: Joe Abercrombie
my_review: Excellent ending, and a blast to read. It's so refreshing to have Abercrombie back on his game.

title: A Little Hatred (The Age of Madness, #1)
author: Joe Abercrombie
my_review:
Excellent. So refreshing to have Abercrombie back on his game after reading his much less enjoyable stand alone novels.

The characters are good, the action is wonderful, the ending was great, the politics are developing nicely, and he even works in some romance. I will say that he definitely has a fixation on morning breath.

I found myself exited for the battles, excited for the romance, and excited for the plot twists. It maybe deserves more than 4, but I can't say that it's a 5 star book.

title: A Psalm for the Wild-Built (Monk & Robot, #1)
author: Becky Chambers
my_review:
Look. I love the idea of an idyllic natural utopia as much as the next guy. What I don't love is clumsy writing, aborted character growth, manufactured personal trauma, awkward character interactions, and transparent sermonizing.

Instead of crafting an immersive world whose tender beauty needs no salespitch, Chambers seems to have made a big neato list of all the bestest utopian ideals which she proceeds to shove into every available paragraph. It reminds me of Huxley's The Island, where characters, plot, and philosophy all take a back seat to thinly veiled evangelizing.

Consider the lifetime computers


It was a good computer, given to them on their sixteenth birthday, a customary coming-of-age gift...and Dex had only needed to repair it five times in the years that it had traveled in their clothes. A reliable device built to last a lifetime, as all computers were.


I mean, yeah, I also think the right to repair act is neato and planned obsolescence is a blight on society. But what does this have to do with our story about an emotionally conflicted tea monk? Can you at least pretend that you are world building and not just checking cool things of your utopian checklist?

The problem isn't all the cool details of the utopia. It's how the reader learns of them. The universally accepted ideas of your world should not be carefully laid out in fabricated internal monologues. They are ingrained in society, and should be naturally revealed through the actions of the characters.


Disturbing these lives (plants/bugs) through digging was a violence—though sometimes a needed one...the human residents of this place were judicious about what constituted actual necessity, and as such, disturbed the ground as little as possible.


Imagine if I wrote the following:


Punching other subway riders in the face was a violence—though sometimes a needed one. The human residents of NYC were judicious about what constituted actual necessity, and as such, punched as few of their fellow citizens in the face as possible.


Imagine the character who has this internal monologue. They've got a screw loose, right? Is that how the author means for us to think about Dex? As a possibly disturbed and weirdly reflective outsider? Absolutely not. Dex is meant to be a functioning and conforming member of society with a mild crisis about their life's meaning. These kind of internal dialogues are wrong for Dex's character. This is the author preaching to us, not Dex thinking things in their own head.


Fifty percent of Panga’s single continent was designated for human use; the rest was left to nature, and the ocean was barely touched at all. It was a crazy split, if you thought about it: half the land for a single species, half for the hundreds of thousands of others. But then, humans had a knack for throwing things out of balance. Finding a limit they’d stick to was victory enough.


Sigh. Let's move on to character development and conflict resolution.

Wait, conflict resolution? What conflict resolution? In the two key conflicts, it is external events that conveniently conspire to force the characters to get along. When first fighting with the robot, a bear comes. When next fighting the robot, Dex falls off a cliff. In both occurrences, the unexpected external event forces Dex to change their mind and accept the robot. There is no actual growth and understanding that comes from inside Dex.

And character development. Oh the character development. Our MC is supposed to have felt a vague dissatisfaction with life that led them to become a tea monk and then to travel into the wilds. Except, we don't get to see any of that. As soon as we see the first tea ceremony's failure, the author just hand waves two years and now Dex is the best tea monk on the entire moon? And is mildly depressed for some reason?

This next point may have bothered me more because I listened to this as an audiobook, and there is no reasonable way to glance back or ahead a few words with the ease that is possible when sight reading.

For starters, let's all agree that respecting people's pronouns is a basic human courtesy and it's not up for debate. I don't want to see a bunch of weirdos in the comments saying that 'they' shouldn't be a pronoun. Singular they has a long history in formal writing, and I dunno, how bout we just respect what people want to be called?

However, 'they' is often a harder pronoun to use unambiguously, and when you're an author who can plan each sentence and you have an editor to proofread each sentence, I don’t want to constantly wonder who exactly 'they' is. Just...use 'they' when it's obvious and use 'Dex' when it's not. As an audiobook listener, I was constantly having to wait four or five words after hearing 'they' before I could figure out whether 'they' referred to Dex or if it referred to the group of people mentioned in the previous sentence.

Anyway, what about the book's core philosophy? That there is no inherent meaning to life and we should accept this and forge our own meanings?

Well, that's basically my life philosophy too, but again, like with the utopia, it's not enough that I agree with you and like the world you're presenting. Books need to be fun to read. They need to engage me and seem natural. They need to make me feel stuff. This book did not do those things. It just felt like a bland recitation of agreeable ideas with a thin veneer of characters and plot painted lazily on top.

title: Red Country
author: Joe Abercrombie
my_review:
Good, not amazing. 3 stars is maybe too harsh, considering I did enjoy the book, but I just wasn't blown away, and I'm not aching to recommend it to anyone.

It brings back some old favorites, like Logan Nine Fingers and the mercenary leader, and I think that one merchant lady, and maybe some others that I missed. Really disappointed with the mercenary leader, his character lost the nuance and spunk that made him likeable in the first series.

As usual, the fight scenes were excellent. The grim dark was ok, but felt a little forced at times. The characters in general felt kinda weak.

title: Iron Flame (The Empyrean, #2)
author: Rebecca Yarros
my_review:
Halfway through this book I was very frustrated. Book 1 was better, I though to myself, a lot better. The second half improved a bit, especially the ending, but it still wasn't as good as the first.

Sometimes it's complicated to tease out exactly what was wrong with a book, especially when the outline of the plot is so promising. I honestly think that with a better editor this book could have been great. But somehow what used to be exciting is now just eye-rolling. And the amount of weak writing with characters and plot was painful. Especially since it would often have been simple to leave out the offending portions.

It's hard to remember every element I didn't like, but let me just hit some of the highlights. For starters, evil characters who are evil just for sake of evil. There are better ways to create conflict in a story than simply postulating an evil character. It would have been so easy to give the Vice Commandant a meaningful backstory, but instead we got this one dimensional, lame villain.

And then there is the artificial tension. Every small thing doesn't need to be life or death for no reason; it gets old and boring after a while, especially when there are obvious reasons for there to be no death. Like when that girl died jumping across a trap...so preventable. We could have cut out that entire scene and the book would have improved.

And everyone's least favorite character being alive? In the plot outline, it's a great idea, and really sets us up for the ending. But like, from a continuity and world building sense? It's terrible. It really reads like she hadn't planned this in book one, and added it as a cool idea when book two came around. Not to mention, how the hell does this fit into the whole idea of the wards? Why haven't there been centuries worth of people taking the same choice as Jack?

And the 7 dragons thing... Hiding younglings was one thing; it had a plot-justified purpose. But hiding the 7th dragon was just meaningless. And why the hell did Andaurna let every one fail at ward 1, and then continue to keep it a secret for ward 2? This just reads like ill-considered plot that a competent editor should have cut out.

The romance was definitely not as good. To be fair, I'm usually far more interested in the chase than in the actual relationship, but even accounting for this, their relationship just lacked pizzaz. Definitely no lip-biting from me in this book.

There was some good stuff. Definitely still liking the non-glorification of toxicity. Like when Xaden wants to be all weird and protective and Violet is like, fuck that. Most of his flaws seem to be correctly called out instead of being portrayed as standard or desirable. Additionally, the secrets conflict felt pretty reasonable and true to how YAs actually behave. The battles were ok, but I think they needed some work. And the ending was pretty great. Really liked the death and the conversion.

Overall a mixed bag. It's a fast read, so it's worth it to continue the series. Just don't expect it to live up to book one.

title: Fourth Wing (The Empyrean, #1)
author: Rebecca Yarros
my_review:
I've spent at least 6 months seeing this book everywhere, and ngl, I came in with really low expectations. Frankly, I was prepared for Twilight with dragons.

But wow, this was actually not bad. Yes, it was predictable at times, but I always found myself excited when my predictions came true, instead of rolling my eyes. Yes, there was an overprotective, overstrong male interest, but he wasn't always saving mc physically. He gave her better daggers, made her a saddle, in short, showed that he cared in healthy, intentional ways. Yes, male mc occasionally does creepy protective things. But mc never glorifies it; she tells him to stop. Yes, there was communication as a plot device, but it always seemed real to how actual teens behave. Yes, there was silly plot stuff here and there, but I actually found myself getting excited at parts. Yes, the quietly dangerous male mc smoldered from his towering height as the sharp edge of his jaw threatened to cut his rippling abs. But I still found myself biting my lip in the casual interactions as their relationship sparked.

If I read more romantasy, maybe the "totally platonic

title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
author: Merlin Sheldrake
my_review:
The scattered cool facts were overwhelmed by the speculation, philosophizing, and shoe-horned personal anecdotes. It the subject wasn't enthralling and relatively unknown to me, this would have been an easy DNF.

There were a couple cool topics covered that I would like to not forget:

The role of fungi in root systems acting selfishly for their own benefit as resource distributors in a way that appears altruistic at the level of the plants.

The idea of fungal and plant GMOs, engineered to work better together or more widely across geographical regions.

Fungi as computers.

title: I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life
author: Ed Yong
my_review:
So fascinating. This is a book that is kind like a huge collection of fun facts with connected by a common theme. You won't really learn a ton of new basic core science concepts, but there are still so many neat real world examples of microbes. When I got to the end, I was really wishing that I had written more of them down.

Stuff like, breast milk has special chemicals that we don't usefully digest, but are rather specifically tailored to feed our microbiome. Or that there are bacteria which change the sex ratios of their hosts. Or that toilets are actually the most susceptible to harboring dangerous pathogens recently after being cleaned.

A very important core topic is that a robust microbiome is typically the enemy of pathogens. This is as true in the gut as it is in the hospital air. Additionally, the stomach microbiome is very vulnerable to food diversity and antibiotics.

Overall, this book has a refreshingly positive take on bacteria as a fundamental part of our worlds, and even if it isn't the best book I've ever read, it is definitely worth a read.

title: Chip War: The Fight for the World's Most Critical Technology
author: Chris   Miller
my_review: Super interesting overview of the semiconductor industry. Totally fascinating to see how the supply chains have developed over time, and to see the absolutely insane amounts of money and time required to develop a state of the art fab.

title: The Hidden Beauty of Seeds & Fruits: The Botanical Photography of Levon Biss
author: Levon Biss
my_review:
For some reason, I expected more. Sure, the photos are very high quality and they are accompanied by thoughtful paragraphs for each seed. The quality of the book itself also left me with no complaints...but it also didn't wow me. I don't feel excited to show this to my friends, and I would never let it sit prominently on a coffee table. I have literal shelves of books that would be better suited.

Are you after high-res closeups of diverse seeds and fruits with short descriptions? This book is for you. But if you're looking for something with some artistic punch, maybe look elsewhere.

title: Immune: a Journey into the Mysterious System that Keeps You Alive
author: Philipp Dettmer
my_review:
Holy cow, what a fantastic book. Dettmer effortlessly communicates the science in a clear, enjoyable, and accessible manner. He absolutely nails the science communication, always going into just the right ammount of detail while still being entertaining. And he's always careful to do occasional reviews to cement the information. Despite the depth of the subject, this is the sort of book that I can easily recommend to my grandma, who is enjoying it as I type this review.

Highly, highly recommend; this is one of the best science books I have read in years.

title: Empire of Cotton: A Global History
author: Sven Beckert

title: Fermat's Enigma
author: Simon Singh
my_review:
So good. I've never been disappointed with a Simon Singh book, and this one is no exception. He knows just how to tell a scientific story without grossly simplifing it, and he deftly builds your interest in the characters and their stories. He does this while going deeper than other authors, and uncovering details that I'd never previously heard of.

If you don't already know how the story ends, do yourself a favor and don't read the intro first.

title: Longitude: The True Story of a Lone Genius Who Solved the Greatest Scientific Problem of His Time
author: Dava Sobel
my_review:
A 200 page masterclass in making the interesting boring. Sobel takes the fascinating progress of early science, the flaming vitriol of of men competing for the Longitude Prize, and renders it devoid of all intrigue and suspense. If there were instead a prize for neutering great stories, Sobel would handily win it.

Every page reeks with untapped potential. Because even an educated reader has only a vague idea of the exact happenings in the 1700s fight for the longitude prize, a blow by blow retelling could easily make a book of great suspense and scientific interest. Yet Sobel consistently robs her work of any semblance of excitement by spoiling every great moment hundreds of pages before its narrative conclusion, constantly insisting on telling key events out of line.

Blessed with an abundance of first hand literature and documents, she could have regaled us with the pointed words of the original combatants. And yet instead she chooses to dully recite the facts in a dry wikipedia summarization.

I was so excited to read a book-length treatment on this fascinating topic, and so let down by the actual experience.

title: No Country for Old Men
author: Cormac McCarthy
my_review: The movie was better.

title: The Road
author: Cormac McCarthy
my_review: One of the better and more realistic apocalyptic novels I have ever read. Very grim and monotone, and you could really believe that this is how this world would function. I loved the author's refusal to use names. I gotta say that I absolutely hated the ending though, and it somewhat spoiled it for me. For such a bleak, realistic, and hard-hitting book to have such a forced, unbelievable, and happy ending was just too out of place and silly. However, I would still easily put this above other works such as The Parable of The Sower and Station Eleven.

title: The Shack: Reflections for Every Day of the Year
author: William Paul Young

title: The Lost City of the Monkey God
author: Douglas Preston

title: The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich: A History of Nazi Germany
author: William L. Shirer

title: The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair That Changed America
author: Erik Larson
my_review:
This book has it ALL. Murder, intrigue, engineering, catastrophe, death, economic collapse, sickness, and name dropping you wouldn't believe.

I get the impression that a lot of people are miffed that there wasn't more serial killer stuff, and that they grew tired of the world's fair. I heartily disagree. I would have loved another 100 pages on the exibits of the fair and the inventors and products that came of it.

Upon finishing, I was pretty tempted to give this a five stars, simply by virtue of how interesting I found it on every page. SO MUCH STUFF that I had no idea about happened in this time frame. There's an endless parade of names that leaves me constantly exlaiming, "that person was there too!?"

But anyway, I think the author did an excellent job of picking the most interesting tidbits and weaving them into a cohesive multi-thread narrative. There was once or twice when I thought he took some liberties with explaining people's thoughts during a murder, but listening to the audiobook, I'm not sure if he actually had quotes here from letters or whatnot.

Similar to The Wager, with this amount of source material (Holmes wrote several confessions) I might have wished for more frequent straight regurgitations of old info. It really is a shame that the several dozen witnesses were not allowed testimony at the trial.

This book was a ton of fun, and I'll be promptly combing through his other works to find something intersting to read.

title: Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI
author: David Grann
my_review:
Fascinating and horrifying. I sometimes had a little trouble keeping track of the huge cast of characters, but overall I was swept away by this insane story of the calculated murder of entire families of Osage indians.

Obviously I learned about the trail of tears and indian reservations and whatnot in school, but I can't say that I really understood the scope of the mistreatment that occurred after they got on reservations. Reading about the system of guardianship was sickening. To think that you would have a grown human being worth millions of dollars and they would have a white 'guardian' that would prevent them from spending any money to save their sick children from dying is disgusting.

Grann makes a convincing case that, not only did Hale mastermind the murder of dozens of people to steal their inheritances, but also that unknown swaths of conspirators murdered indians in secret for the better part of two decades and covered up the evidence. It's insane to think that you would have the doctors, the coroner, and the law agent in cahoots as you brought a drunk man in, executed him with morphine, and then classified it as alcohol poisoning. Or that you would systematically poison people's moonshine and never get caught.

Anyway, this was a wild tale, and I plan on seeing the movie when it comes out. Also kinda interesting, the book was in three parts and a different narrator read each one.

title: Kafka on the Shore
author: Haruki Murakami
my_review:
It's strange. Objectively speaking, there is so much to dislike in this book.

The random preaching, the weird fixation on music, the way Murakami's writing makes me wonder if he has ever had adult relations with a human female....and yet somehow, I really quite enjoyed myself.

It's a weird thing. The plot is just plain silly, and there are constant Deus ex Machinas, but it's just so pleasant to vibe with the story as it flows along.

I can only imagine how good Murakami's books would be if they weren't littered with weird problems. Anyway, to sum up, I'd say Wind up Bird was better.

Side note: if I have to hear the narrator Sean Barrett butcher one more perfectly easy to pronounce Japanese name or city, I'm going to rip my own ears off. I mean sure, if it were something in Arabic that's legitimately hard for an english speaker, I could understand. But this sociopath pronounces Takamura, as "TACK-eh-MURE-ah". How this narration made it through multiple human beings with internet access is beyond me.

title: The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle
author: Haruki Murakami
my_review:
what a strange and captivating book. i'll need to come back and write a more serious review, but for now let's just say that I plan on adding a few more by Murakami to my reading list.

One could hardly accuse this book of having a clear plot-line, what with the constant interjections of historical war stories, accounts of girls off in rural wig factories, and a persistent blurring of reality, magic, and dream. However, I nonetheless found myself turning page after page, desperate to know how the stories would unfold.

Flashbacks often prod the bored reader into wishing for the renewal of the main storyline, yet in this book, one might almost call the flashbacks the most interesting part. Or, if not the most interesting, certainly the most action filled.

Is this just a story? Or is Murakami saying something deep about the human condition? Is his book filled with strong female characters? Or are they persistently sexualized vessels for the plot?

Before reading this novel, I was given the impression that it was a high-brow read, and I can certainly understand how it might achieve that reputation.

title: The Crystal City (Tales of Alvin Maker, #6)
author: Orson Scott Card
my_review:
pitiful end to an increasingly mediocre series.

especially in the first 4 or so books, the characters were woefully one-dimensional, like a moralizing children's tale that is required to have clear delineations of right and wrong, good and evil. This makes for a tepid read, where even if there's technically action or plot, it somehow manages to bore.

And as the series reached it's end, long built-up relationships and conflicts just fizzled out pitifully. The supposed great conflict arc between the two brothers had no climax, much less a conclusion. And the way the two used their powers was consistently lame. The first couple books were great, as a young Alvin explored the limits of his skills. But grown-up Alvin was such an unbelievable bore. And writer Orson Scott Card completely lacked the ability to wow the reader with the scenes that were certainly intended to be amazing.

A shitty bridge across water is the coolest thing Alvin ever does? Um, you mean like ice? As a maker how just tells molecules how they should be, and they carry on the instructions, the basic fundamentals of the magic system make it clear that creating an ice bridge should be trivial. And yet for some silly reason we are asked to be amazed by this "crystal" bridge he builds. Not to mention this lame-ass plow he carries around everywhere.

I suspect that much of the lame plot stemmed from a need to maintain some type of symmetry with Mormon myths and "symbolism" in early books.

I've recently recommended some other Orson Scott Card books to people, like Speaker for the Dead and Xenocide, and I shudder to think that childhood may have clouded my vision, and in fact these books are as bad as the Alvin Maker series.

In summary, Orson managed to take a freaking awesome premise -- magical realism in early 1800s frontier america -- and bore the reader to tears with one-dimensional characters, lame mormon shout outs, characters that refused to use their magic in interesting ways, and a weird absence of a meaningful climax or resolution.
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Alternate History|Historical Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy|Science Fiction|Audiobook

title: Heartfire (Tales of Alvin Maker, #5)
author: Orson Scott Card
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Alternate History|Science Fiction Fantasy|Historical Fiction|Science Fiction|Historical

title: My Best Friend's Exorcism
author: Grady Hendrix
my_review:
Vampire book club was better. It wasn't a bad book, but I got kinda bored, and didn't love the simultaneously mercuial yet supposedly deep and eternal friendships, although maybe that really is how teenage friendships are, idk.

oh, so after reading all three, my ranking was vamp > house > exorcism

title: Alvin Journeyman (Tales of Alvin Maker, #4)
author: Orson Scott Card
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Alternate History|Science Fiction Fantasy|Science Fiction|Historical Fiction|Historical

title: Prentice Alvin (Tales of Alvin Maker, #3)
author: Orson Scott Card
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Alternate History|Science Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy|Historical Fiction|Historical

title: Red Prophet (Tales of Alvin Maker, #2)
author: Orson Scott Card
my_review: you know, there's nothing wrong with these books. i certainly enjoy them. and I can absolutely see why I must have enjoyed them as a child. I would have adored all this indian and magic pioneer days stuff. Actually, I have a very rare memory of selecting this series in the library, while looking for another book altogether. And I remember loving the magic, the way he crafted the stone and healed his own body in book 1. It's pretty rare for me to remember stuff from that long ago, much less something only in a book, so this must have left quite the impression. But despite the death and the torture and the grown up characters, this nonetheless feels like a child's tale. Hard to say what it is, exactly. Maybe it's overly moralizing? Hard to say. It's not like I bristle at the moral message, it's just that it has the kind of message an intentionally-crafted children's movie would have.
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Alternate History|Historical Fiction|Science Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy|Historical

title: Seventh Son (Tales of Alvin Maker, #1)
author: Orson Scott Card
my_review: read this as a kid, so it's kinda nostalgic. it's a good enough and interesting book for sure, definitely a really cool premise that I'm unsure I've ever seen elsewhere. but I can't say that I'm aching to recommend it to anyone.
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Alternate History|Science Fiction|Historical Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy|Audiobook

title: Reaper Man (Discworld, #11; Death, #2)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review:
I think I need a break from Pratchett. This is my 8th pratchett book in 9 days, and I've gotten to the point where the guaranteed low-stakes can no longer hold my interest.

This was good, certainly better than Mort, and I think the narrator came a little more into her own, although she still does not do nearly so well as Indira did. I kinda zoned out during the last hour of the book tho. Hard to say whether I'm just burned out on Pratchett or if the book really would have otherwise failed to keep my interest.

I have been thinking that I need to go and read some books out of the main wizard series, maybe starting with Sourcery and then reading a few in chronological publication order.

title: The Southern Book Club's Guide to Slaying Vampires
author: Grady Hendrix
my_review:
I'm having way too much fun reading this. The way her friends turned on her felt a little unrealistic after 5 years of book club, but other than that, her isolation was genuinely enraging. That moment when her husband contrived to have her tied down in the hospital...damn.

Ok, finished the book. A little too gory for me there at the end, but I enjoyed it. There were some plot points here and there that I thought were silly, like, they definitely could have handled the dead body better...but overall I had fun, and might read a couple more by this author.

title: How to Sell a Haunted House
author: Grady Hendrix
my_review: This was actually pretty fun. Don't expect gripping horror, this book is definitely a bit campy, but the plot was good, the characters are fleshed out, and I felt some real emotions while reading it. I think I got teary eyed at a couple death scenes about mothers, and I felt a real tightness in my chest when she lost the will. It was just crushingly unfair. It was a pretty fast book; I listened to it at 2.2x speed.

title: The Bourne Identity (Jason Bourne, #1)
author: Robert Ludlum
my_review:
Holy info-dump batman! The thinly disguised info-dumps are painful, the instantaneous lovey-dovey relationship stretches belief, and certain details really bothered me. Especially during the beginning, I found myself wishing I'd just watched the movie 3 times instead of reading this book.. It did get more engaging near the end, but I don't think it made the slog worth it.

Ludlum over-explains everything. Every super-mega-cool-WOW spy detail needs it's initial Ph.D. dissertation when first introduced, and then at every subsequent occurrence needs a little ELI5 just in case the reader forget how it works during the intervening 20 pages. Yes, I understand that the neato spy details are part of what makes it a fun spy novel, but at some point the author needs to give the reader's intelligence some credit.

And the downfall of the fashion shop was just plain silly. What a lame climax. Carlos and the fashion lady both know that Bourne has compromised the shop, and it didn't scare them a bit. And then he terrifies the organization by....by making the shop seem compromised? What the hell is this plot point??

And not just that, but Carlos is built up as having this far reaching organization of disconnected tendrils, and then I'm suddenly supposed to believe that there's some kind of need for the fashion shop to be a base of operations which is even possible to compromise? Yeah, tldr, I could have done without this plot point.

Bourne's and his lady's emotional interactions were also pretty weird. He was always flying off the handle, she was always perfectly loving and composed. Even setting aside the datedness of the relationship, it's just not good character writing.

title: Mort (Discworld, #4; Death, #1)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review:
I think this is the worst of the past 7 discworld novels I've read, even including Equal Rites. Both the characters and the humor were lacking. Pratchett, who is usually so excellent at crafting unique and interesting characters, just kinda disappointed. The personalities of the two female co-leads were shallow and tepid. I didn't find either to be engaging, and I certainly wasn't rooting for any romantic pairings...a huge letdown after the strong characters of the Witches sub-series. And death had some really strange personality shifts that didn't make sense to me. The way he acted after coming back from the kitchens was very out of character, or at least, not backed up by good narration.

I guess this makes sense, seeing as I'm moving from reading the 23rd discword book to reading the 4th. I'm still somewhat undecided as to whether this reading order I've got going makes sense. But I think it's probably nice to mix in the older (and less refined) books with the newer and better ones. Otherwise, I'm not sure that I would be able to plow through a bunch of these tepid books in order to get to the better, later works.

Also, I was really enjoying the narrator Indira Varma from Witches, and her replacement, Sian Clifford was very disappointing by comparison. Whereas Indira's voices feel genuine, Sian's feel fake and put-on, with stage emotion instead of true feeling.

title: Carpe Jugulum (Discworld, #23; Witches, #6)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review:
I think this was my favorite of the Witches. It wasn't wildly better, but it felt more balanced, in terms of plot and action. I enjoyed the interactions between granny and the priest, and the vampire coven was tremendous fun. I loved the count and his modern ideas and reluctant children.

I will say that it was a pretty busy book, with a lot going on, which might tend to make it seem unfocused, as Pratchett books tend to have a place for everything, and everything in it's place.
