I enjoyed the humor, particularly the stuff about vampires, igor, and religion. Some pretty decent quotes in there about sin, iirc.

title: Maskerade (Discworld, #18; Witches, #5)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: Keeps up the same level of quality as the previous few. A little disappointed that agnus never got a chance to shine.

title: Lords and Ladies (Discworld, #14; Witches, #4)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: The last couple in the witches series have been really fun. I'm sort of thinking that a timid newcomer might start with witches #2 instead of Equal Rites, since there is a definite quality difference.

title: Equal Rites (Discworld, #3; Witches, #1)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review:
Another fun Pratchett book. It's an earlier work, so maybe not as sophisticated as the later ones, but I rather enjoyed it. I don't know that it really deserves as low as 3 stars, but I'm not quite ready to put it up with all the 4 star books, as it's not a particularly strong recommendation unless you are already a Pratchett fan, or are looking for something light and fun.

It was written in the 1980s and is a criticism/satire of the unequal way that witches and wizards are historically portrayed in fantasy. It’s about a girl that wants to grow up to be a wizard, but everyone wants her to be a witch instead, cuz, you know, wizards are all strong fireballs and dragons, and witches are all weak herbs and potions or whatever.

Of course, it rings a little less true in 2023, when it's probably easier to find badass female fireball magicians than it is to find stereotypical, looked-down-upon herb-hags. But it was still fun, and I'll enjoy reading the rest of the series.

If one was very worried about introducing someone to pratchett, maybe they could start with Wyrd sisters instead? This one really doesn't have too much in common with the other books that I've seen.

Oh, and the narrator, Indira Varma, was *excellent* especially when she starts doing voices in the second book

title: Witches Abroad (Discworld, #12; Witches, #3)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: Are these the most amazing books? No. Are they fun and funny? Definitely. I think the humor really shone in the first part of the book, and I enjoyed the plot well enough. As usual, the narrator was absolutely excellent. I can't imagine that the characters would have shone as brightly in my own mental narration.

title: The Bands of Mourning (Mistborn, #6)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review: I liked these, but I remember getting burned out after reading them.

title: Guards! Guards! (Discworld, #8)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: It's a pretty interesting book. It's intentionally humorous and doesn't take itself seriously at all. Has a fun, light plot, where you know everything will work out, but are interested in staying along for the ride to find out how. It's peppered with occasional deeper bits of philosophy and introspection, and has a nicely varied vocabulary. The style of writing took me maybe 20 pages to really get immersed in, but ultimately it became natural and I enjoyed it. It relies very strongly on the social and political dynamics of the specific city that it is based in, and the unique personalities of its inhabitants, in order to drive the story forward. Overall, I enjoyed reading it, but it doesn't make my list of strong recommendations, and I wouldn't consider reading it a second time.  I have this vague feeling that the author wasn't making full use of the characters, but this could very well be because it is book 1 of an 8 book series. It has a very clear and satisfying story arc, with an ending that nicely concludes the plot while still allowing more to be written

title: Feet of Clay (Discworld, #19; City Watch, #3)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: Don't have as much to say about book 3. More world building, more character development, good plot, enjoyable. However, it lacked the tense excitement of book 2, and fell more strongly into feel of book 1. The author is careful to grow the world with each book, so you always are learning and experiencing new aspects of the universe, while he incorporates all the elements with which you are already familiar. It still has the characteristic humor mixed in with deeper musings about the nature of man and society. Interesting topics are naturally and organically explored through the characters like femininity and gender bias through dwarves, well-intentioned prejudices through werewolfs, and the nature of self and religion through golems. I never feel brow beaten by any particular musing. In terms of enjoyment I rank it similar to book 1, maybe a bit higher?, and noticeably less than book 2.

title: Men at Arms (Discworld, #15; City Watch, #2)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: This really hits its stride. Races and world-building that were previously only hinted at are now fleshed out wonderfully. You get an entirely new understanding of the city and its guilds and political machinations. The main character's personality explodes onto the page, satiating every unfulfilled desire I had in book 1. The story artfully brings in new and interesting characters while progressing the stories of the old favorites. It maintains its humor, but gone is the comfortable feeling that everything will work out in the end. The story features tense action, and real suspense. Cold dread washed over me at certain points, and I found myself excitedly cheering on the action. It nicely builds little plot points which are hinted at in the early stages and then revealed to effect during the climax and conclusion. Overall I was much more engaged, and I enjoyed the read thoroughly.

title: Jingo (Discworld, #21)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: no review, similar to book 3

title: Night Watch (Discworld, #29)
author: Terry Pratchett
