title: The Fifth Elephant (Discworld, #24)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: no review, similar to book 3

title: The Magician's Land (The Magicians, #3)
author: Lev Grossman
my_review: I can't help but feel that plum was a sadly underdeveloped supporting character, looking back, I know we spent a lot of time with her, but I don't feel that I know her at all. I really liked Alice's emotional journey after coming back from being a niffin, how she was still alien and furious at the transformation. It was handled quickly in terms of page count, but it was solid and satisfying. I like the idea of the flesh taking over with the food etc, as smells and desires came back online after the 7 year hiatus. It's really nice to see how characters develop in our abscence, asmo with the blade, Poppy and his legion of golden-handed followers in the library, Julia on the other side of fillory. All of this was handled well and believably. As with book 2, there was much less emotional exploration, but perhaps that's what is is like to be a mostly stable adult instead of a turbulent teenager. The stuff with Alice more than made up for it. I enjoyed the plot, the robbery, and the trip to see the artic professor, and the school hijinks, and Q becoming god. I think it would have been easy to fall into the trap of an unanbiguously happy ending, and I'm glad that wasn't the case. Interesting, though, that I can't think that this book contained any real loss. I appreciate it ending with Q and Alice still reservered and distant, still figuring things out. Overall I quite enjoyed it, and it was an excellent conclusion to the series. I don't think I'll be raving about this series and recommending it to everyone I see, but it will be high on my list. Books 1 and 3 were the strongest; book 3 was easily the most polished, and book 1 stands out for it's excellent emotional and character content. Side note that I am very very bothered by how it was never really mentioned that the children should have been many years older than they actually were supposed to be on earth. A brief note about growing an inch taller, but nothing more. I felt like it should have been brought up in reference to their often mentioned ages, which should have been much more difficult to calculate due to all the time spent in Fillory.

title: The Magicians (The Magicians, #1)
author: Lev Grossman
my_review:
I remember finding the writing to be very captivating when I opened the book. The writer makes heavy use of similes and metaphors in a way that I thought I might get tired of, but I stopped noticing as the book progressed. I was originally a bit put off by what I felt was a self-pleasuring, self-referential inclusion of a fantasy story about magicians within the fantasy story about magicians, although this feeling, too, faded with progress. The greater part of the book is somewhat jarringly episodic, bouncing from scene to scene through the years unexpectedly, sometimes skipping details that I would have quite liked to know (like what happens after the water jump with Alice). In this way, it managed to lack a cohesive narrative thread, while perhaps instead focusing on the emotional journey of Quentin et al.

As a whole, I found the interpersonal relationships to be very complex and satisfying, and perhaps even realistic. Maybe I don’t read enough anymore, but I think it is uncommon to write in such detail about such interactions. The fantasy and narrative of the novel took a real backstage to the often strained, and complicated human relationships. Group dynamics, in particular, were very interestingly portrayed, whether it was uncomfortable in-group tension or the various feelings you have as part of a clique. Constant sexual noticing of breasts really stood out, but then again, this was exactly what it was like to be a teenage boy. There were some points when Q reflected on leaving college that left me with panging nostalgia.

And of course there is the climax in fantasy land. It had a sort of hurried, overwhelming feel, with the changes coming in faster than the descriptions, very possibly intentionally done by the author. The end fight was great with the shock of Penny’s hands, the uselessness of Q, and the absolute bad-assery of Alice, and I was left with a deep and perfect crushing hollowness when she horrifyingly died right when she seemed at the cusp of victory. Important characters were tossed aside in a way that felt very real to actual meaningless disasters.

The two training montages, the first during the arctic and the second during Fillory were really excellent, and everything I love about training montages. But they had absolutely no payoff after their little story arc. I never had any sense that in the following narratives, Q had grown as a magician. He didn’t seem to have outpaced his classmates after the arctic, and honestly he almost never uses magic at all. In the fights following the arctic, he was uniformly outclassed and useless, worse than his peers who it would have seemed that he should be better than. And the aftermath of the Fillory montage was just pathetic. I expected him to be a badass magician afterwards, but instead, nothing. He can’t manage to fly across the water or anything. It was really disappointing. The book ended somewhat abruptly, definitely not the sort of thing that has good closure, very much feeling like part of an uncompleted series.

Overall, I enjoyed the book and will read the next ones with interest.

title: When Everything Changed: The Amazing Journey of American Women from 1960 to the Present
author: Gail Collins
my_review: I read this at the recommendation of a friend's girlfriend, and it was well worth the read.

title: Thud! (Discworld, #34)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: no review, similar to book 3

title: Snuff (Discworld, #39; City Watch, #8)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review: This is definitely the weakest book, by far the worst of the series. It's been a little while since I read it, but I remember being disappointed in the akward and unrealistic behavior and interactions between the characters. I think the plot was lacking too, but I forget why I thought that.

title: The Magician King (The Magicians, #2)
author: Lev Grossman
my_review: I didn't enjoy this as much. The narrative flow was much smoother and less episodic, and it tracked two story lines instead of one, Julia's past and Q's present. Julia's past was the more engaging of the two stories, and the plot was really great. However, the heavy emotional scenes, such as the final murder of her witch family, lacked the emotional punch of Alice's death in book 1. There were deep parallels between the two scenes. For Alice, Q realized right before her death just how much he loved her, and he experienced true clarity about his life/their relationship, only for her to almost immediately be taken from him. With J, as the final spell was being cast, she finally had clarity and understood that the witch family was everything she had been searching for, only for it to be immediately destroyed before her eyes, and for her self to be ravaged and destroyed as well. But Alice's death left a cold chill on my heart, and J's friends death just read like so many words on a page. The author just didn't manage to build the necessary emotional connection. This problem plagued book 2 in general. I rarely felt that social relationships and emotions were as nuanced and well-explored as in book 1. Honestly the outline of the plot for book 2 may be even better/more enjoyable than book 1, but the details of relationships and emotional exploration and my personal investment in the plot and characters were fundamentally lacking. I do think the overarching details of the plot were good. I love the unfairness of it all, Julia's family being massacred, Bennidict dying, Q being kicked out of Narnia, etc, I just wasn't as engaged with the characters and their emotional journies.

title: Wyrd Sisters (Discworld, #6; Witches, #2)
author: Terry Pratchett
my_review:
i may have actually liked the plot less than Equal Rites, but the writing and characters were better, and iirc there was more humor

well, idk. on paper the plot was better. but sometimes pratchett’s books are so lighthearted that it can be difficult to be too invested in a plot that you know will absolutely work out in the end

title: Shades of Grey (Shades of Grey, #1)
author: Jasper Fforde
my_review: That was actually shockingly good. It's got the whimsical humor of Hitchhiker's mixed with the dystopian world of the Giver. I actually quite enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone looking for something lighthearted, unique, and slightly funny.

title: Demon Copperhead
author: Barbara Kingsolver
my_review:
You ever read a book that leaves you hollowed out inside, too numb at the gnawing pain to feel the tear crawling its way down your face? That's Demon Copperhead.

I honestly struggled a bit in the beginning to lose myself in the story, but by the second half I was in a constant struggle to hold back the tears as I plowed through the pages, desperately wishing for the trainwreck to end.

After reading Poisonwood Bible, I had every confidence in Kingsolver's ability to write female characters, but I was honestly shocked at how effortlessly teenage boy Demon flowed onto the page. Having been a hormone addled teenage boy myself, I can vouch that she nails his character.

And the setting. Demon grows up in Lee County (Lee was a confederate general) going to a high school with a highly winning football team called the Generals, despite their ancestors fighting for the Union (due to having no plantations), located somewhere in the rural Virginia mountains, a little north of Knoxville. Meanwhile, I grew up a little south of Knoxville, nestled in the Tennessee mountains...and despite our city fighting for the Union, our highly winning high school football team was the Rebels, complete with the confederate flag that, like Demon, we mostly found to be a weird mixture of familiar and acutely embarrassing.

To be fair, there are some major differences between our childhoods and towns, but I've lived close enough to all this to say that holy mother of god does Barbara nail the small-town, rural Appalachian setting. I've been to the impossibly huge family gatherings, where food is laid out on every truck bed. I've watched the foster-care family members have so much promise, and then lose their freedom to bad decisions in a world that doesn't give a shit how young or broken you are. I've known the girls with the babies that end their education at 16, and the girls who would rather forget they ever had anyone called father.

In short, I guess I've scribbled a bunch of words to say one thing: this book is heartbreakingly realistic, with complicated, captivating characters, and a plot that will rip your soul out.

Goodreads kinda sucks at quotes, so I leave anything that struck me here.

I wanted to tell them it's not just girls that end up inside four walls of hate, with knuckles for breakfast.


Girls my age seemed young. More heavily into showcasing the goods than to backing up the inventory.


I was high on wanting. Now I had her, and all the air hissed out. I was living life as a flat tire.


Dory crying. Saying I hated her. It broke me to pieces. All she wanted in the world was to be loved. I had to think of her as my baby doll. You don't blame a doll for slacking. You watch the pretty eyes open and shut.


One of those hot rainy days you feel like you're breathing your own breath out of a paper bag.


A fallen hero shatters into more sharp pieces than you'd believe.


The well-oiled machine he'd worked so hard to keep, a long time after it really mattered. What a waste, a dead body. With most of its parts still eager and ready to work. The final humiliation of a man. The last layoff.
genres: Fiction|Book Club|Historical Fiction|Audiobook|Literary Fiction|Contemporary|Coming Of Age

title: The Autumn Republic (Powder Mage, #3)
author: Brian  McClellan
my_review: excellent conclusion. the female writing improves, tho we still have to suffer through carpol being captive all the time. definitely a good series if you are looking for action fantasy.

title: The Crimson Campaign (Powder Mage, #2)
author: Brian  McClellan
my_review:
Had a ton of fun, couldn't put it down. There was a thing here and a thing there that I didn't love. Pol was sometimes conveniently weak for the sake of being saved by Taniel, and the army at large was grossly ignorant of her powers to an unbelievable extent. The whole generals-hate-tamil sub-plot seemed just slightly unrealistic (I think he would have garnered more respect), but I went with it. And there were some key fights prolonged for the sake of making the fight cooler (Tamis vs the handless mage, when he should have just shot him from the shadows). But in general, the good far outweighed the bad. It was exciting, kept multiple interesting plots going, and satisfied all those fun magical-gun-fight itches. Very much looking forward to book 3.

Does a pretty decent job of balancing all the different genres. Criminal underworld, military campaign, magical mysteries, political investigating, hot-shot-fighting mage, etc.

I'm always kind of prepared for male-written fantasy to have a certain kind of male gaze, but I think this book is pretty acceptable in that regard. The female character writing isn't particularly strong, but this isn't one of those breasted boobily down the hallway books. You can tell the author put some attempts at strong females, even if he doesn't always nail it. The harems contain beautiful women AND men, the officers in the army are casually female, many of the villains are female, one of the best powder mages is a woman, but we do still end up with some damsel tropes.

title: Promise of Blood (Powder Mage, #1)
author: Brian  McClellan
my_review: god, what a breath of fresh air. this is the kind of book that makes me wish goodreads allowed half stars. action, adventure, magic, guns, vengeful gods, lecherous priests. this is HBO-worth, modern fantasy. plenty of interesting characters to follow, but never a moment of confusion as to who's who. plenty of fights with magic, guns, and swords, but i almost always felt that the characters abilities and limitations were well-defined and signaled by the author. no power balancing problems like I often see in magical fighting books. this book tends more towards abercrombie than anything else I've read, although I'd say the characters aren't quite as well-written and interesting as in the first law series.

title: The Republic of Thieves (Gentleman Bastard, #3)
author: Scott Lynch
my_review: meh. the writing is finally better, but the story got boring. the whole acting troupe plot line was weak and flaccid. and the election plot was mechanical and lacked intrigue and fun. the mage stuff was pretty fun though; I wish the whole book had been about that instead.

title: Red Seas Under Red Skies (Gentleman Bastard, #2)
author: Scott Lynch
my_review: better than the first one, probably deserves 3.5 stars instead of 3. the plot's often kinda silly, and the characters and their conversations frequently lack any realism or believability. They feel like what you might write if you'd seen plenty soap operas but neglected to actually speak with another human being. Conversations and character interactions seem to be contrivances by which the author achieves plot points, and often don't have any bearing on how one would expect the characters to talk and behave.

title: The Lies of Locke Lamora (Gentleman Bastard, #1)
author: Scott Lynch
my_review: fun at times, but often cringe. the dialogue frequently verged on positively painful, the setups were often kinda lame and ill-considered, and it was more than a little predictable. The characters interact with each other and react during conversations is consistently fake and stilted ways.. Definitely not something I would ever recommend, but it was kinda trashy fun, I don't regret reading it.

title: How Jesus Became God : the Exaltation of a Jewish Preacher from Galilee
author: Bart D. Ehrman
my_review: Another solid Ehrman book, with some interesting perspectives not explored in the others I had previously read. Commentary on Pauline Christology was particularly new and interesting. Definitely a good read for anyone interesting in early christian theology, 30-400 AD.

title: Station Eleven
author: Emily St. John Mandel
my_review: this was good, almost artistic, a kind of lovely, flowing plot. annoying use of gender ambiguous names like Charlie (as a girl) made it confusing at times. also, a pretty unrealistic portrayal of apocalypse. food, internet going out, all seemed dumb. liked it but always had to shove down my annoyance at the technical details.

title: Perdido Street Station
author: China Miéville
my_review:
Captivating. An absolutely sublime method of world revelation. Some authors spoon feed you the details of the world through info-dumps or long descriptions. Not Miéville. You see the world through the character's eyes, and if it isn't something they would have thought to comment on, then they don't. The details of the world are casually and naturally concealed from the reader until suddenly you're like, holy shit, wait, she's a fucking insect!?. It's rare to read a world so artfully revealed (Handmaid's Tale comes to mind) and it is always a pleasure.

The fantasy world itself was quite interesting, and hardly derivative. I think if the book failed anywhere it would be plot, which was maybe a little drawn out and cheesy? This is definitely the sort of thing I would recommend to the right reader.

title: The Scar
author: China Miéville
my_review: Not as good as Perdido. Probably a 3.5, but we'll be generous and round up to 4. I will say that it had lots of nice thematic tie ins at the end of the novel. I don't regret reading it, but it's not a strong recommendation, as Perdido was. Despite the new setting and the vast world, the environment just didn't feel fresh and crazy and new and overwhelming, which was a non-trivial draw for Perdido.

title: Iron Council (New Crobuzon, #3)
author: China Miéville
my_review: Easily the weakest of the series. The whole train concept is neat but ridiculous. It defies even the natural suspension of belief to think that people with arbitrary transportation couldn't catch our protagonists while they spent every day laying god damn train tracks. Sure, the look into politics and intrigue was neat, and I don't regret reading the book for more of the world, but it is definitely not a strong recommendation like perdido is.
genres: Fantasy|Fiction|Science Fiction|Steampunk|New Weird|Weird Fiction|Science Fiction Fantasy

title: Island
author: Aldous Huxley
my_review:
Sermon masquerading as a narrative. The worst part is that I rather liked some key messages in Huxley's sermon, but see, I was hoping to read...you know...a book. Huxley could have given the world a much more engaging piece of literature if he had only revealed this utopia in true narrative form, perhaps from the viewpoint of the lifetime of the two children, the island girl and the prince. We could have followed them as they grew, felt the depths of their worldviews, seen the pain of their conflict. We would have identified with both of them, and had to really think and feel about the different systems.

Instead we got a lecture on how to live thinly disguised as a story, and tepidly weak writing as a result. The lecture was a bit too anti materialism and contained a sort of naive positivity towards lifelong drug use, but it had some wonderful stuff about physical activity, adoption clubs, thoughtfulness, teaching. styles, and sexual positivity.

Anyway, I think a prospective reader would do better to read a bullet point summary of Huxley's key propositions on Wikipedia.

title: Children of Time (Children of Time, #1)
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
my_review: whoa, so good. good story, interesting characters, good plot, nice resolution, real sense of danger, all the things. highly recommend. (insertion of badly understood prisoner's dilemma kinda lame. it's way more complicated than let on)

title: Lords of Uncreation (The Final Architecture, #3)
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
my_review: nice conclusion. <spoiler>i like that idrids becomes part of the unspace and i LOVE tha ollie becomes the unspeakable. </spoiler> felt maybe 30% longer than it needed to be

title: We Are Legion (We Are Bob) (Bobiverse, #1)
author: Dennis E. Taylor
my_review: opening premise is really cool. the books don't always live up to the coolness of the premise, but still enjoyable reads. see book 2 for more details

title: All These Worlds (Bobiverse, #3)
author: Dennis E. Taylor
my_review: weakest of the books. won't keep reading on number 4. it wraps stuff up, but it gets scattered and fails to really keep you invested.

title: Sabriel (Abhorsen, #1)
author: Garth Nix
my_review: this was good and fun. maybe a little weak handling of the romance, but then again they are teenagers so maybe it's actually accurate lol. i'm definitely continuing on the series. I like the magic system, very unique. it uses bells and sound to control the spirits and there is a big divide in the world where much of it doesn't even believe in magic because it doesn't work there.

title: Lirael (Abhorsen, #2)
author: Garth Nix
my_review: 2 and three are more like one mega book, as opposed to 1 which is kinda like a prequel i guess. anyway, i think 2 is even better than 1. the dual story and the feeling of young exploration is really neat.

title: Abhorsen (Abhorsen, #3)
author: Garth Nix
my_review: good solid conclusion. I enjoyed the series. Apparently there are a bunch of other books, a 3.5 short story and then some later novels. Greg has read book 5 iirc, and he didn't like it as much. so for now i've stopped with this series to read other things.

title: The Black Prism (Lightbringer, #1)
author: Brent Weeks
my_review: interesting premise. author is weaving action in with subtle mystery and I'm already doubting who I should be rooting for. There is obviously a complicated backstory which would make me feel very differently about everything happening, but most of the characters aren’t privy to the truth and neither am I. If it can carry on this promise for the whole book without letting me down, it’ll be very good indeed. (i wrote this 1.5h into a 22h book) Ok so now I'm finished and the verdict is in... SO GOOD. yes there is a flaw here and there, but overall i'd say this is the best thing I've read in this current 34 book spree. hard to choose between a 4 and a 5, but I do need to acknowledge that it had some flaws.

title: The Blinding Knife (Lightbringer, #2)
author: Brent Weeks
my_review: another 4.5, rounded up. great follow up. There were some parts that put actual dread in my chest and I felt physically uneasy even after stopping reading. this guy really knows how to write cliffhangers and put characters you like in positions of vulnerability or moral ambiguity. I'm still not really sure the characters I'm rooting for the most are actually doing the right thing. so far, this series is a strong recommendation.

title: The Broken Eye (Lightbringer, #3)
author: Brent Weeks
my_review: excellent. another 4.5 rounded up.

title: The Blood Mirror (Lightbringer, #4)
author: Brent Weeks
my_review: weaker than the other books. this is more like a 3.5 rounded up. the pacing was off and I don't buy that kip would have married that girl.

title: The Burning White (Lightbringer, #5)
author: Brent Weeks
my_review:
actual 4, unlike the other 4.5s in this series. It loses points for me on the ending, which got kinda lamely religious.

40h book, holy cow. man, this book really does emotionally engage me. I feel real disappointment, like how tia reacts to carrise's feelings about gavins death. i understand both character's viewpoints, and hate to see it tear them apart. lost count of the number of actual emotional scenes. teared up several times, not just for deaths but also for emotional reunions. also was super excited for some parts, like when gunner showed up. I love the ambiguity of not having a single hero, and how the characters try to reconcile this. and characters we love killing each other, like cruxer and iron fist. Final verdict. Absolutely excellent, highly recommend. A little religious at the end, but oh well.

title: The Shadow of What Was Lost (The Licanius Trilogy, #1)
author: James  Islington
my_review:
It had potential, but it just failed to deliver on it. In a word, it was clumsy. It's been kinda hard for me to define what exactly clumsiness is, but I'll give a go at a couple examples.

It had good mystery, but it gave you too much mystery too fast, so it felt like it was cliche. It had that fun trope of, "hidden magic no one knows about" but it gave you too much, too fast, so it felt cliche. There were no realistic slow parts. For example, as soon as you saw from the shadow's point of view, she's immediately taken to the secret lair, and then she immediately gets approached by the crazy guy noone has ever approached before, then he immediately kills her brand new friend that idk why i'm supposed to like after only 5 minutes with him. and ofc she is immediately brought into the closest circle of trust of the most important people.

idk, the whole thing was just too constantly cliche, like it was sadly aping better fiction. It knew what it was supposed to do, and it tried its best, but it could neveractually pull it off.

And it REALLY failed to have any plot or emotional investment from me. and jesus, that doesn't even mention that everytime there was the potential for suprise or suspense, it's like the author went out of their way to ruin it completely. gross forshadowing that leaves no one in doubt that the unobtrusive character is really the prince. a character "dies" and then instead of letting us think that for a while from the viewpoint of their friends, instead the author immediately takes of to the viewpoint of the dead character so we can't possibly have any suspense. there are 3 books, but I won't bother with the next ones.

title: Logo Modernism
author: Jens Müller
my_review: This is a rock solid book on logos. Page after endless page of cool logos in typical high-quality Taschen fashion. However, I bought it alongside Logo (revised edition) by Michael Evamy, and I can't help but notice that even though the print quality is worse and it has only 1.6k logos to this book's 6k, I somehow like it more. Logo has significantly better organization and a short snippet about every logo, compared with Modernism's date, country, and industry metadata. I had originally thought that I would buy the other books in the Modernism series, but at a price of ~$60, I'll be refraining.

title: Theft of Swords (The Riyria Revelations, #1-2)
author: Michael J. Sullivan
my_review: good, clean fun. a little cliche here and there, but when it is, you get the sense the book knows it's being silly. I think this book was originally two books combined into one, and the first one is more lighthearted and ridiculous while the second one tightens up a bit. the plot is fun, and the magic is fun, and I liked it.

title: Logo
author: Michael Evamy
my_review: Excellent. I bought this book alongside the much larger and well-stocked (6k logos vs 1.6k logos) Logo Modernism, however I can't helped but favor Logo by Michael Evamy. Logo has a much better organizational system and an interesting snipped to accompany each logo.

title: Rise of Empire (The Riyria Revelations, #3-4)
author: Michael J. Sullivan
my_review: another 2 books combined into one I think? anyway the first book was good. not sure I completly love how it handles the female characters. they are often introduced as being smart and capable, but are then promptly useless when they need to be a damsel for plot, then they are made awesome again as the story grows. girls are always having weak emotional stuff and quietly crying while guys, instead, get to have weak moments where they doubt their purpose in manly fashion. but, after reading book part 1 of 2 i am definitely enjoying myself.

title: Heir of Novron (The Riyria Revelations, #5-6)
author: Michael J. Sullivan
my_review: Good end to a good series. Wraps everything up really nicely. This wasn't the best thing I've ever read, but it's any easy recommendation for a fantasy lover.

title: Prince of Thorns (Broken Empire, #1)
author: Mark  Lawrence
my_review: Somewhere inbetween 'im14andthisisdeep' and legit good. I started with a bad narrator that I abandoned, and switched to Joe Jameson, who was excellent. This book has more than a few really witty and fun insights/sayings, that I wish I had written down. It's a really short book, only 9 hours compared to the 20-30h of other books that I've been reading, so I feel like it's honestly a bit too soon to even review the story. I did enjoy it, and I will definitely read more. The words flow nicely off the page, and are captivating as they come.

title: King of Thorns (Broken Empire, #2)
author: Mark  Lawrence
my_review:
This book really comes into it's own. If anyone has trouble getting through the first book, they should definitely power through. A constantly captivating plot with fun surprises that are exciting and harrowing. An evil bastard as the main character who you nonetheless can't imagine not rooting for, and maybe he just isn't so evil after all. I really liked the ending, got super excited at some bits. ...the way the bad brother killed the good brother so casually. literally *never* saw that coming. magic is definitely there as a plot device but somehow i can't manage to begrudge it, it's done well, and so if feels natural. The whole dual plot as you slowly learn the past and the present, side-by-side, was very well done. exciting and interesting throughout.

Probably even more quoteable than the first book, lots of really nice turns of phrase: I wrote down a couple of them, but many wouldn't make sense out of context so I didn't bother. *talks about the beauty of the countryside before finding a tick* öh well. even eden had a snake problem" "reich couldn't make an omlette without wading thigh deep in the blood of chickens and wearing their entrails as a necklace." There is an absolutely excellent part about decapitation, too long to quote, it can be found at: 7:20 in the Joe Jameson version, if at 1x speed. It must be said that Jameson does some real magic with quotes that would otherwise seem try-hard or trite.

title: Emperor of Thorns (Broken Empire, #3)
author: Mark  Lawrence
my_review: weakest of the three books. I didn't mind the ending but it was quick and I felt could have been better. series is still worth reading.

title: Fairy Tale
author: Stephen  King
my_review:
dnf'd at 12h into the 25h book...it just, wasn't interesting. The book was always telling you what would happen next, and not in an intrigue building or 4th wall breaking kinda way, but in a lame suspense killing, putting-on-airs kinda way.

After struggling through page after page of our protagonist's obsession with a dog, I finally got to the fantasy world only to discover that it was crushingly lame and boring. There were all these horribly disfigured people, but instead of catching my emotions, the author somehow couldn't make me care.

I actually read Stephen King's On Writing a while back and though it had some excellent advice, so I was honestly shocked by how much I disliked this book.

title: American Gods (American Gods, #1)
author: Neil Gaiman
my_review:
I quite liked this. I listened to the full cast version with the author's preferred text, and it was quite good, better than the first single-narrator that I tried. It flows well, keeps you interested, and has a great premise. The ending refrains from being overly happy while still giving you good satisfaction. It's nice to see all these myths and gods and the immigrant experience. It makes me think, as always, of how silly believing in religion is, with all the evidence of history to the contrary.

There's a TV show, and I have no idea how they could possibly do the book justice. Reading this makes me want to read Good Omens.

title: The Housemaid (The Housemaid, #1)
author: Freida McFadden
my_review: I actually liked this way more than I thought I would. It's got cheesy romance with an unobtainable, sexy, rich, perfect older man, mystery, murder, all the things. There was a great twist that took me the perfect amount of time to figure out, and even though the book didn't have some kind of devastating ending like it could have, it still finished with a real zinger (the revelation from the husbands mom about teeth). This is probably an easy recommendation to mom/sister/grandma

title: Parable of the Sower (Earthseed, #1)
author: Octavia E. Butler
my_review:
meh. it just...wasn't engaging.

On the surface, this was a book full of intensity and action...and yet I can't say I felt a single strong emotion while reading it. Books often make me cry, but here, when central characters died, I felt nothing. We are treated to a world brimming with rape, murder, arson, and endless horrors...that is somehow made endlessly boring.

The world Butler paints is disjointed and often silly. You're telling me there's a functioning government that acknowledges property rights, levies taxes, maintains a functioning police, a national guard, and a fire department, and yet on these same streets there is constant arson, idle rape, and rampant cannibalism?

It's like Butler wanted to make sure we had all the bad things, and thus shoved them into the story without worrying whether she could craft emotional impact or maintain believability. Government corruption? Well, we'll need a government for that. Loss of property? OH, let's invent a totally believable drug that turns people into arsonists! Resourceful heroine who can be conveniently weak sometimes for plot reasons, but not because she's literally weaker because that would be sexist? Maybe we'll manufacture a supposedly debilitating ability to empathize with people? God forbid we give her an actually interesting reason to be an impotent wielder of violence...like morals. The whole religious earthseed subplot could have deftly weaved this in, but no.

Instead we are treated to the dismal silliness of the 'feeler' defect. It had no meaningful impact on narrative or character development except to artificially weaken the main character whenever the plot required, and to be quietly forgotten when not convenient to the story. And lest you suspect that it allowed us to see the world through the emotional eyes of an empathetic narrator...it did not. Our "highly empathetic narrator" maintains an unfeeling stoicism throughout.

And the characters. The characters? Endlessly forgettable. The people they collected on the road didn't have their own interesting personalities, I couldn't even tell who was who. Someone would die, and I'd have to wrack my brain for an identifying characteristic.

And on top of all that, the audio book started by spoiling that her community was going to be destroyed (which doesn't happen until literally the halfway point, 5 hours into the book). yeah, I can't think that I would recommend this to anyone.

title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
author: Gabrielle Zevin
my_review:
This book was like plunging my hands into a bag of shit-covered diamonds. There were parts that stuck me to my core, but also parts that struck me as ridiculous. Some deep insights, and some deeply unrealized potential.

It relies heavily on this theme I hate where characters never understand each other's feelings...not because of irreconcilable differences, but because they are too stupid to talk to each other. I suppose this happens occasionally in real life, but frankly in literature I view it as the sort of lazy writing only resorted to when genuine character interactions are incapable of creating plot and tension. It's just so dissatisfying to read a book that is otherwise very serious and deep, dealing with complicated human emotions and dynamics, and yet insists on basing every conflict and major plot development on misunderstandings that could easily be resolved with a quick chat.

I recently read another book where there was this deep secret threatening to tear apart a friend group. But then lo and behold, they talked it over liked regular freaking people...of course, it turns out their friend group was still destroyed, but it was for legitimate ideological differences between the characters, and not in service of the made up plot device of miscommunication.

But anyway, I did enjoy much of the book. It has its fair share of deep and cutting insights into the human condition that seem real without being trite. It's the kind of book I would maybe recommend to my emotionally contemplative friends (@Mononita?), but I'm not sure who else.

In the first half of the book, it squeezed some true emotional involvement out of me. Once, I remember just shaking my head miserably as I foresaw the train-wreck of a character's choices. I was excited to be miserable, because the bad choices were not plot driven, but rather character driven, and made sense and gripped me tightly. However, as stated before this stops being true in the final quarter of the book, and is a big part of why I struggle to go higher than 3 stars.

Emotionally, it does a good job with death. After a car wreck, there's a passing line about his mother, where the narrator casually says 'her body was cooling' which somehow hit me way harder than any explicit mention of death would have. And in the hospital where the estranged husband and wife are making cranes for their comatose son and the narrator says, 'this is marriage'. There were quite a few parts in there where I slightly teared up.

I found myself feeling a growing nostalgia for my youth, a longing for the relationships that I might have had, a remorse for the years that have passed me by. "It's about first chances and second chances, fleeting chances and only chances, and the fear that time is running out."

However, although I definitely felt some real feelings during the book, this is not a solid recommendation from me. plot-wise, I don't buy this ridiculous gap of 5 years. it's just weirdly inhuman after all of Sam's efforts to reconnect.

The author was absolutely using this book as a chance to talk about her personal politics, which, if you can weave it into the story without me noticing, then I don't mind at all. For example, the author's political feelings on gay marriage were reasonably integrated and felt like a touching part of the story. However, the book was anti-gun in a preachy way that distracted me from what was otherwise an emotionally devastating act of gun violence. A talented author could have let the horrible nature of gun violence speak for itself, using emotion to make a point that thousands of pages of argumentation could never achieve. But instead it's like she was worried we just really wouldn't get the point, so she made sure to write the character's internal dialog in a fake and stilted way, inserting a blithe fear and unrealistic ignorance of firearms that no actual gamer who played first person shooters would have, thereby breaking immersion in the story.

On that note, the author seemed to have a general lack of understanding of the sorts of things a casual gamer would know. I found some of the video game references to be forced and fake...it was like she googled "best games ever" and then made sure to have a character randomly mention each title in passing so we the reader would be pleased at seeing our favorite game written on the page. Also...burning out multiple graphics cards? um what? callous on his finger from playing games? um...what?

Anyway. I did like this book. It made me feel things, it made me think, it almost made me cry. But then it kinda spoiled it forced references, bad plot, and politics at the expense of immersion.

title: Babel
author: R.F. Kuang
my_review:
It enthralled me; the premise, the setting, the characters, the initially deft handling of pervasive systematic prejudices. I absolutely loved the magic system. I stopped halfway through the book to write that it beautifully handled sexism and racism in a realistic and haunting way that never felt forced or shoehorned, just true and heartbreaking. But ultimately my enjoyment was marred by the author's damaging message that the privileged and the oppressed can never become allies.

Spoilers ahead.
Colonialism
The main characters are a Haitain woman, an Indian man, a Chinese man, and an English woman who are all struggling with being second class citizens and outsiders on their college campus. It's the 1830s, and there is casual and pervasive systemic sexism and racism that quietly, and at times loudly, colours their otherwise charmed lives. However over the course of many years, these four bond irrevocably and form a deep friendship.

Then the foriegn born characters get involved with an underground movement resistenting the force of colonialism and a hidden plot by the faculty to start a war with China. When the Englishwoman finds out, she initially can't understand, but ultimately she is able to compare her own struggles with those of her friends, and she joins their cause as a true ally. Except she doesn't. The author instead uses this beautiful moment of people coming together to fix the world as a backdrop for a suprise betrayal. The Englishwoman betrays her friends, killing one of them and imprisioning the rest, in order for the author to show the reader that the privileged will never join the oppressed to change the world for the better.

This message is repeated when the surviving foriegn friends stage a takeover of the college, and in a spectacular demonstration are able to prove once and for all that the college faculty has been manipulative and lying and is planning a war. Any college in the real world would have students who are itching to defy authority and be part of something bigger. However in the book when it comes time to choose sides, the author is careful to let us know that not one single traditionally privileged student or faculty joins in with the cause.

To be fair, the tradespeople eventually 'ally' with the babel students. But I think the author is careful not to show this as an act of allying with the cause of helping the colonized countries, but rather an act of two enemies temporarily holding hands to fight a common enemy.

There's also the ridiculously unnuanced portrayal of all the bad guys (colonial administrators) as exaggerated comicbook-style villians cackling maniacly as they plunder the subhuman nations of the world.

Technology
I'm getting a little tired of writing, but I'd also like to mention the author's not-so-subtle anti-technology stance. There are clear parallels between the book's silver magic created by the universities and our own worlds upcoming LLM revolution, and I would have loved to see a nuanced examination of the issues. Instead I got an infantile, 'technoglogy bad' chorus.


Conclusion
There was so much to like in this book. It had some absolutely awesome commentary about translating and the nature of understanding. The magic system was innovative and fascinating and perfectly complimented the plot and the central themes. But the author's weird insistence that people who benefit from opressive systems are indistinguishable from the system itself, and can never break free of it's clutches to understand and partner with the oppressed...I think this is just an incredibly damaging message to be preaching to a world that still has so much room for understanding.

title: Cats by Kuniyoshi: Ukiyo-e Paper Book
author: Kuniyoshi Utagawa
my_review:
Excellent little book of high-quality cat prints. There are ~60 total, and they are designed to be removed. I actually have two copies of this book, one for the shelf, and one where I pulled out my favorite 24 prints to make a giant cat collage.

When evaluating art books, I want to see high quality pictures big enough to do the art justice, accompanied by text that interestingly contextualizes the art. This work does great on all counts. As a Japanese learner, I was also delighted that it contains both Japanese and English translations.

title: Divergent (Divergent, #1)
author: Veronica Roth
my_review:
Exciting and fun, but RIDDLED with problems. It's so strange to enjoy reading a book, barely noticing the hours fly by, but to look back and be mortified by the inconsistencies and bad research.

Training/Weapons
There's a deep lack of understanding of fighting, training, and weapons that even cursory editing could have fixed.

- muscle growth: 16 yo female main character becomes too muscular to fit her old clothes after 1.5 weeks of working out
- injuries: 16 y/o female main character is brutally beaten, punched, and kicked into unconsciousness by a 16 y/o male who is a foot taller than her, and after an ~hour hospital stay only suffers some minor bruises
- knife throwing: when learning to throw knives, every character has trouble hitting the target...not having the knife stick, just having it hit the target at all
- guns: It's hard to even know where to start with guns. There were so many: "the bullet clicked into the chamber" or " looked down into the gun to see how many bullets it had left" to convince me that the author's knowledge of firearms seems to have come from an intense study of guns illustrated exclusively using Rorschach ink blobs

Plot
- mercurial emotions: I certainly accept the notion that a teenager might have confused emotions that flit between hot and cold for their romantic interest. But instead of the situation or character actions showing why the Triss switches randomly from thinking Tobias was scary to sexy, instead the author just switched the MC's viewpoint whenever the plot most demanded it
- mind control: I don't buy for a second that the Dauntless would mind control their entire population. It gives away too much power and is COMPLETELY against everything someone with a Dauntless personality would stand for. We could have just as easily had a plot where the Dauntless were greedy and cooperated with the Erudites, but were lied to and tricked into the mind control.
- mother's sacrifice: um, what the hell was that random and useless "sacrifice" by the mother? and why did she start it off by uselessly shooting three bullets into the air after she had just finished killing a bunch of guards?
- killing Will but not Eric: you're telling me Triss shoots someone she hates in the foot, and then shoots one of her best friends in the head? ok.
- drowning chamber: you're telling me that in the middle of a military takeover where political leaders are being casually shot in the head, the people in power take a quick break to build a drowning box to execute a 16 y/o girl so she can conveniently be saved by her mother?

So yeah, I had fun reading it. Enough fun to give it 3 stars instead of the 2 stars it probably deserved. But for the love of god it would be nice if this author could be shown even a crayon drawing of what a gun looks like, or have someone inform her that having your plot compared to swiss cheese is not a compliment.

title: Fireborne (The Aurelian Cycle, #1)
author: Rosaria Munda
my_review:
Flawed and only mildly engaging. The goodreads ratings for books 2 and 3 are even lower, so I will definitely not continue.

The whole premise is this conflict of birth between the two main characters that eventually gets resolved, set on the backdrop of dragons and war. In another writer's hands, the premise may have been good. But then, they would have had to have written characters whose conflicts actually made sense, instead of this ridiculously manufactured nonsense that we get instead.

On the one hand, he's supposed to be this borderline perfect human being that has supported her through her entire life, helping her through all her most difficult moments. Excepting a single outburst when he was a child, he is universially gentle and kind. Not to mention smart, charismatic, and always able to say the right thing at the right moment...and of course he is always, always thinking about her well-being.

And you expect me to believe that she's still hung up on who his murdered parents were? That she holds some deep resentment that her murdered parents were peasants and his murdered parents were royalty? Um no, because I don't buy it. They were raised together in the same orphanage where literally 90% of the flashbacks are about how much he cared for her. He's endlessly thinking about her.

The plot idea of two young kids at odds because of class and history is neat, but you can't write them as best friends and expect me to believe one secretly resents the other, especially not when they've had all the same life opportunities and experiences.

There was other stuff like this, character actions and emotions seemingly manufactured for the sake of the plot. This marks my 3rd try at a YA series in the past week, and I can't say I have any desire to continue the trend.

title: Lost in Time
author: A.G. Riddle
my_review:
Time travel? I'd like to travel back in time and stop myself from reading this sorry excuse for a 5th grade writing project. It was like shoving my head into a bag of rotting milk and taking deep, gulping breaths. Somewhere near the 25% mark of this book, I was done, ready to DNF, but through some disgusting quirk of masochism I decided it might be fulfilling to read the whole thing just to write a savage review at the end...And here we are.

International scientific megacorp Absolom is harboring a dark secret. A secret that knits together the small band of scientist-founders and will lead our main character on a daunting journey... You see, before discovering how to transmit matter through space and time, they were originally researching how to transmit matter just through space!!!!!!!! It is a great secret that they must keep from their children...and the world!!!!

I'm sorry, what? Why the hell is that even a secret? Scientists serendipitously discover related technologies all the time. I mean, sure, if you forced me to, I could come up with some reasons and let the author know about them, but in the actual book, they act like it's this huge deal in order to create mystery and suspense when it clearly isn't, and in the process, I, the reader, am left wondering where all this supposed mystery and suspense was.

And holy hell the ridiculous premise. They invented the groundbreaking ability to travel through time and transport matter to another dimension and the thing society decided to do with it was to...transport criminals??? And this super neato new punishment that only applies to the worst criminals eliminated almost all crime?? First, yeah right. Second, in America alone, we spend 10s of billions of dollars every year disposing of nuclear waste. Even a minimally creative person would understand that something more mundane but necessary/profitable such as trash disposal or nuclear disposal would be more likely. (tbf, the author does mention this in passing around the 90% mark of the book, but, like the rest of his fiction, his explanation isn't even a little convincing.)

The author's gross lack of any scientific or common sensibilities shows at every turn. It's a hard number to pin down, but there are estimates that as few as 5% of species that exist leave a fossil record. So if you were a world renowned expert and knew every single fossil ever discovered and then you went back 200 million years, then you might recognize maybe 1 out of 20 of the animals walking around. Not our main character though. This megagenius had a couple chats with his biology-literate financial advisor before being transported to the Triassic and he confidently gives the scientific name for every single species he encounters.

Reviews made a big deal out of the twists and turns and surprises but I swear to god the author revealed every single twist chapters ahead of time with a convenient "hint". Nora isn't dead is revealed by the organ company phone call. Adaline is going to the past revealed by diamond ear rings. etc etc. And don't even get me started on how stupid our main character's adventures in the Triassic were. 'Painfully cringe' is about all I have the energy to write.

I don't know if this is real literary advice, but after reading this book, if it isn't, it should be. "Show, don't tell". This author is seemingly incapable of communicating a character's thoughts, feelings, emotions, or personality through anything except bland and stilted information sessions. In a better book, you might follow along with a character's journey and witness their raw intelligence, or the way they blossom into a confident adult. In this glorious work, we are treated to such brilliant prose as:


Adeline was discovering a whole new side of herself. There was a fighter inside of her, a person she never knew existed and wouldn’t have if not for Nora’s death and her father’s exile. She marveled then that one never knew what they were made of until their back was against the wall.

and

The name of the dinosaur he had seen occurred to him too. It was a Coelophysis. Daniele had pronounced the C like an S, the first part of the name pronounced like “seel,” the middle like “oh.” He was amazed that his mind worked like that—he could remember the tiniest details that fascinated him (like dinosaurs), but most days he could barely remember what he did the day before.

He decided to call the dinosaur a “seelo.” If he ever saw one again.
...
That’s how his mind worked: he liked to name things and order them. That may have been what made him a successful physicist.

Almost against his will, Sam laughed at that. Successful. Yeah right. What a career he’d had: faking enthusiasm for a time travel machine he thought was baloney (in order to make money to save his dying wife), then accidentally helping to create that supposedly fake time travel machine, and finally being banished from his own universe with the machine he had faked enthusiasm for in the first place. There were disasters, and then there was his life.


Anyway, I hate this book, and I hate myself for reading it. If you somehow have the good fortune to be reading this review before plunging neck deep into the putrid filth that is Lost in Time, do yourself a favor and find some other book, any book, and read that instead.

title: Piranesi
author: Susanna Clarke
my_review:
Gentle and captivating.

One page, and I knew it would be excellent. The creeping revelation of quiet madness in a nourishing world. The casual unfolding of Piranesi's ignorance. The growing worry as you slowly understand there is something deeply alien about his lovely halls. This is a book that takes you softly by the hand and smiles to show you its secrets.

Not a universal recommendation, but personally, I loved it.

title: The Poisonwood Bible
author: Barbara Kingsolver
my_review:
Deeply cutting and frequenty moving, Poisonwood Bible was a delight to read. Sadly, it lost it's steam in the last 3rd or so, hence 4 instead of 5, but it's absolutely one of the best books I've read this year. I love Barbara's writing and the narrator of my 1998 Brilliance edition was excellent, nailing the subtle southern old person accent. Having grown up in the bible belt, Barbra has some quotes that absolutely nail the fundamentalist mindset. I cried a couple times in this book, notably at mother may I and another that I can't remember.


Father feels makeup and nail polish are warning signals of prostitution, the same as pierced ears.



Our Father probably interpreted Broca’s aphasia as God’s Christmas bonus to one of His worthier employees.



Sending a girl to college is like pouring water in your shoes,” he still loves to say, as often as possible. “It’s hard to say which is worse, seeing it run out and waste the water, or seeing it hold in and wreck the shoes.



That is the best way I can think of to translate the message. Actually he said you are leading our villagers down into a hole, where they may fail to see the proper sun and become trapped like bugs on a rotten carcass.




The things we do not know, independently and in unison as a family, would fill two separate baskets, each with a large hole in the bottom.



But where is the place for girls in that Kingdom? The rules don’t quite apply to us, nor protect us either. What do a girl’s bravery and righteousness count for, unless she is also pretty? Just try being the smartest and most Christian seventh-grade girl in Bethlehem, Georgia. Your classmates will smirk and call you a square. Call you worse, if you’re Adah.



And perhaps it was not evil I saw but merely the way of all hearts when fear has stripped off the husk of kind pretensions.


This one's pretty long, but the way Barbara just kinda casually reveals the domestic situation over the course of the book is chilling.

“I wonder what outlook you might think that to be,” he said to Mother in that same special voice, for bad dogs and morons.

She brushed her hair out of her face and smiled at him as she reached across for the china platter. “Well, for one thing, sir, you and the good Lord better hope no lightning strikes around here in the next six months!”

 “Orleanna, shut up!” he yelled, grabbing her arm hard and jerking the plate out of her hand. He raised it up over her head and slammed it down hard on the table, cracking it right in two. The smaller half flipped upside down as it broke, and lay there dribbling black plantain juice like blood onto the tablecloth. Mother stood helplessly, holding her hands out to the plate like she wished she could mend its hurt feelings.

“You were getting too fond of that plate. Don’t you think I’ve noticed?”

She didn’t answer him.

“I had hoped you might know better than to waste your devotion on the things of this world, but apparently I was mistaken. I am ashamed of you.”

“You’re right,” she said quietly. “I was too fond of that plate.”

He studied her. Father is not one to let you get away with simply apologizing. He asked her with a mean little smile, “Who were you showing off for here, -with your tablecloth and your fancy plate?” He said the words in a sour way, as if they were well-known sins.

Mother merely stood there before him while all the sparkle drained out of her face.

“And your pitiful cooking, Orleanna? The way to a young Negro’s heart is through his stomach—is that what you were counting on?”

Her light blue eyes had gone blank, like shallow pans of water. You could honestly not tell what she was thinking. I always watch his hands to see which way they’re going to strike out. But Mother’s shallow-water eyes stayed on his face, without really looking at it.

title: Tress of the Emerald Sea (Hoid's Travails, #1)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review:
Action adventure just isn't that intersting when there are no stakes.

The writing was good and the characters and plot were interesting enough, just I guess I just really don't vibe with story-book, no-consequences action. It is cool to see this kind of casual project from Sanderson, and I didn't hate the book or anything, but overall it was pretty meh. It felt a bit like reading a less funny Terry Pratchett.

title: I Who Have Never Known Men
author: Jacqueline Harpman
my_review:
What a strange book. I'm kinda...neutral about it? I wonder how it reads in the original french? In english, it's a bit stilted and rambling..which I suppose makes sense. It is very original, and I like what the author does with the plot, but it kinda strikes me as an undergraduate's first artistic writing project. At ~200 pages, it was already quite short, but I rather felt it could have been shorter. I figure some people might find it deeply insightful or symbolic or something. There were certainly a couple nice quotes, but I can't say that it gave me any particular intellectual excitement.

I'm tempted to say that its weird lack of a message was a virtue, but what then is the point of writing? Anyone can scribble to no end.

I don't regret the couple hours of reading, but I definitely won't be recommending this to anyone.

title: Le modèle standard
author: Francis Masse
my_review:
Is this funnier in French? My friend brought this back from CERN, and I was immediately drawn to the art style and the conceit of physics comics.
Then I read it.
The art's ok, I guess, but god, the jokes are neither funny nor physics-related. It's like he picked up an intoduction to modern physics textbook, choose the chapter headings he though sounded weird, drew a randomly related picture, and then called it a joke.

title: The Metamorphosis
author: Franz Kafka
my_review:
Gregor is burning his vitality in the furnace of corporate slavery, when, subjugated by his manager and used by his family, he finally transforms into the disgusting bug that he has long been in the eyes of the world. And ya know? The relinquishing of responsibly is almost worth it. Then his useless family get real jobs, they weirdly abstain from any attempts at communication, and when he finally starves himself to no longer be a burden, they discard his dead body like garbage.

The End.

I mean yeah. I can see why this has long served as an endless springboard for the contrived symbolism of dreary lit classes, and I'm sure the style was unique and shocking when originally published. But on the heels of reading Lolita, Pride and Prejudice, and the Handmaid's Tale, I can hardly see that this deserves its acclaim.

title: Lolita
author: Vladimir Nabokov
my_review:
I was not prepared. Nabokov plays with the reader. Under his deft pen, the english language is warped to make the normal disgusting, and the disgusting rational. He is a twisted sculptor of words, erecting endless masterpieces to astonish and horrify.

His novel wraps its claws delicately around your mind, pulling you deeper into dark waters until at once you emerge gasping, wondering what the fuck you just read. At one point our pedophile main character was describing his disdain for his conventionally sexy adult wife, and I found myself thinking, “ew gross, boobs, yeah i hate those...wait what!?”

It simply cannot be overstated how masterfully Nabokov's words illustrate his rancid portraits, and I must say that Jeremy Irons' narration did the novel no small justice.

Sadly, I felt the novel rather lagged during its middle sections, and could probably have lost ~100 pages with little ill effect. I'd say it probably deserves 4.5 stars instead of 5.

title: The Night Circus
author: Erin Morgenstern
my_review:
I'll overlook a lot if you can give me good imagery and captivating ambience. This novel lacks a strong plot, is a little handwavey about the magical details, and is a bit cheesy...but I still quite enjoyed the read. The author writes a delightful circus in a fractured timeline with fun concepts and a satisfying conclusion, all readable in a long afternoon.

There seems to be an abundance of comments complaining that this book did not live up to to their expectation of an epic, magic, circus duel, and I can only reflect that so long as one has not polluted their mind with the misleading goodreads summary, the book itself is very straightforward about its tone and trajectory.

title: Legends & Lattes (Legends & Lattes, #1)
author: Travis Baldree
my_review: Fluff. Fantasy fluff. I didn't dislike it. And it wasn't a terrible way to waste away 4 hours. But like all fluff, the novel squishes to nothing at a cursory examination. There was just...nothing there. It read like a predictably puerile children's show; fake conflict and fake plot, just kinda there to fill up space. A big shrug from me.

title: Crimes Against Criminals
author: Robert G. Ingersoll
my_review:
Should be required reading. Ingersoll's passionate 1890 address on prison reform puts modern audiences to shame. It's a travesty that his 133 year old words still sound naively optimistic to our supposedly more advanced and progressive ears.

I've assembled the following quotes in order to capture the flavor and arguments of his 59 page speech. By necessity, much has been left out, and if the words reproduced here are at all of interest, I recommend looking for one of the many free pdf scans available online. 30 minutes could see the whole thing read, cover to cover.


All nations seem to have had supreme confidence in the deterrent power of threatened and inflicted pain. They have regarded punishment as the shortest road to reformation...nations have relied on confiscation and degradation, on maimings, whippings, brandings, and exposure to public ridicule and contempt...Curiously enough, the fact is that, no matter how severe the punishments were, the crimes increased.


Degradation has been thoroughly tried...and the result was that those who inflicted the punishments became as degraded as their victims.


Is it not true that the criminal is a natural product, and that society unconsciously produces these children of vice? Can we not safely take another step, and say that the criminal is a victim, as the diseased and deformed and insane are victims? We do not think of punishing a man because he is afflicted with disease--our desire is to find a cure. We send him, not to the penitentiary, but to the hospital, to an asylum...instead of punishing, we pity. If there are diseases of the mind...as there are diseases of the body...and if these deformities produce what we call vice, why should we punish the criminal, and pity those who are physically diseased?


Those who are not affected by the agonies of the bad, will in a little time care nothing for the sufferings of the good.


The average man does not wish to employ an ex-convict, because the average man has no confidence in the reforming powers of the penitentiary. He believes that the convict who comes out is worse than the convict who went in.


What avenue is open to the ex-convict? If he changes his name, there will be some detective, some officer of the law, some meddlesome wretch, who will betray his secret. He is then discharged...He must seek employment again by telling that which is not true. He is again detected and again discharged. And finally he becomes convinced that he cannot live as an honest man.


It has been contended that the death penalty deters others...A few years ago a man was hanged in Virginia. One who witnessed the execution, on that very day murdered a peddler...He was tried and executed, and one who witness his hanging went home, and on the same day murdered his wife.


Those who are the fiercest to destroy their fellow men for having committed crimes, are, for the most part, at heart, criminals themselves.


Some may be, and probably millions have been, reformed, through kindness, through gratitude--made better in the sunlight of charity. In the atmosphere of kindness the seeds of virtue burst into bud and flower. Cruelty, tyranny, brute force, do not and cannot by any possibility better the heart of man.


All the penalties, all the punishments, are inflicted under a belief that man can do right under all circumstances--that his conduct is absolutely under his control, and that his will is a pilot that can, in spite of winds and tides, reach any port desired. All this is, in my judgement, a mistake...as long as this mistake remains the cornerstone of criminal jurisprudence, reformation will be impossible.

title: The Little Prince
author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
my_review: not a kid's book by any stretch, although I see why children would like it. very quotable. "taming" and how it relates to relationship and meaning is pretty interesting. the whole flower thing overall, really. (the flower is all lonely vulnerability hiding under a shell of pompousness)

title: The Stone Sky (The Broken Earth, #3)
author: N.K. Jemisin
my_review:
Ugh. It is simply enraging, the frequency with which the author engenders miscommunication between characters by confidently proclaiming, "but the character couldn't possibly describe it, because the words simply didn't exist," moments before immediately describing it in simple English to the reader. Don't expect me to believe that an intelligent, well-educated character can't possibly explain what you casually achieve a sentence later.

Admittedly a minor nitpick here, but I swear this author has a deep misunderstanding of how big cities are. She describes the entire world as being composed of microscopic 200 person townships, barely subsisting, and yet the equatorial cities hold millions and millions of people? Where are the medium sized cities? Where do the millions get their food? I mean, I don't wanna be that guy obsessing about the sustainability of the agricultural infrastructure in a fantasy novel...but come on.

Another nitpick here, but I'll be in the middle of the story, consumed by the worldbuilding, when suddenly the author will distractingly insert her modern, 2017 views on gender, sex, or race. I do enjoy seeing these topics in my books, as they make you think, remind you how society should be, and can help change the cultural zeitgeist for the better. But I shouldn't suddenly feel preached to in the middle of a novel about magic earthquake wizards. Plenty of authors manage to include commentary on sexism, sexuality, racism, etc while making it a graceful and fluid part of the story. Just glancing at the books I read in July, see: Earthsea, Handmaid's Tale, Poisonwood Bible, and Circe for some excellent examples.

But anyway, nitpicks aside, I constantly wanted to give this series a chance; as it had so much obvious potential, but I really can't recommend it. Yes, the concept is great, but the execution is deeply flawed. The magic and power levels change constantly just to fit the plot, the character writing and behaviors change at the whim of the author, and the author is constantly pulling your attention out of the story with nitpicky bs.

title: The Obelisk Gate (The Broken Earth, #2)
author: N.K. Jemisin
my_review: Better? It's not masterful, but it's good. It's enjoyable. I still don't really buy into the power balancing during the fights. The author definitely tries, and I think it was better during this book than the last, but... Anyway, I love seeing the daughter's life develop. Still not sure if I want a happy or a tragic end for her and the mother, although the daughter is clearly about to become the powerful villain. The daughter seems the most realistic of all the characters, with her troubled pre-teen longings and adolescent logic. Man, if this book just had a little bit better power balancing and a little bit better characters, it would be so amazing.

title: The Fifth Season (The Broken Earth #1)
author: N.K. Jemisin
my_review:
Engaging, fast-paced, imaginative. Really a quite good book. However...I think the power-system is a little underdeveloped. The distance between what a character can accomplish when the plot demands they be powerful, and what a character can accomplish with the plot demands they be weak is too great.

For example, I can think of a dozen ways to destroy those 3 or 4 ships by either the 10 ringer or the 6 ringer. Tsunami, whirlpools, double tsunami, volcano, throwing rocks (which should have been far more successful). Instead, Alabaster's decisions were blatantly silly. Building a massive, energy consuming wall when he could have just precisely thrown boulders? I mean, honestly, that whole fight was breathtakingly stupid and unrealistic.

Stuff like this really takes away from the entire book for me. You have all this build up to a final fight, you're all invested, and then the author ruins it by having strong characters be suddenly weak for no reason, making obviously bad decisions and struggling at simple things, just so they can lose the fight for plot reasons. Compare this to Wheel of Time, where the big fights are fucking incredible and actually make sense.

Also, I'm deeply disappointed in the utter uselessness of the female main character during the late second and entire third part of her life. She's written as having phenomenal innate power and a vast capacity to learn and we're supposed to believe she refuses to do anything about it? This would be one thing as a character-supported decision, but this path is at odds with her personality. It reeks of an intentional weakening to support the plot instead of an honest projection of how the written character would have genuinely behaved.

Anyway. I'll finish the series for sure, because it features a really cool world and really cool powers. But I don't think this will make it to my list of favorites, just because of the horrible power balancing and bad character writing.

title: Best Served Cold
author: Joe Abercrombie
my_review: good, but not as good as the first law trilogy

title: Last Argument of Kings (The First Law, #3)
author: Joe Abercrombie

title: Before They Are Hanged (The First Law, #2)
author: Joe Abercrombie

title: The Blade Itself (The First Law, #1)
author: Joe Abercrombie
my_review: I must have written more about this somewhere, but I really liked this series of 3 books, especially the bad characters that you like anyway for their complexity. I remember that I had a lot to say about the series when i finished it. I love how so many of the typical fantasy "good" characters turn out to be very complicated and perhaps even evil. honestly, the characters are really good. there is a non-trivial amount of pretty gory description which I sometimes struggled with (queasiness)

title: Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell
author: Susanna Clarke
my_review:
this was a very unusual and fascinating book. not like my favorite thing in the world, but really interesting and cool. glad to have read it.

I think any reader going in should be warned not to expect action or adventure in any measure. This is a slow paced, experiential novel.

title: Death's End (Remembrance of Earth’s Past, #3)
author: Liu Cixin
my_review:
vulgarity and spoilers ahead...
I cannot tell you how much I hate the main character. She ruins, EVERYTHING, every fucking time. Why the hell does Wade put up with it? She's just a senselessly bad character whose flaws seem to be more about illustrating some weirdly sexist point about the female gender than about writing an interesting plot or crafting good characters.

Perhaps one could say that this book and the previous one really capture the deep stupidity and fickle nature of humanity. Always making the shitty, short-sighted choices that prevent progress. But the negativity of the plot desperately stretches believability. Every possible thing that could go wrong, does go wrong, and I was just left rolling my eyes by the end.

I guess tldr: the books got worse as they went along. I kinda see what the third book was driving at, and there was some neat science stuff, but I was too busy being enraged by the senseless plot and garbage characters to appreciate it.

title: The Dark Forest (Remembrance of Earth’s Past, #2)
author: Liu Cixin
my_review:
Lame plot holes and a dumb "romantic" subplot made it a challenging read, despite the occasionally interesting science ideas.

he published the paper with the fundamental principles right? so i struggle to see how humanity couldn't figure out that he was pushing the dark forrest with his experiment.

title: The Three-Body Problem (Remembrance of Earth’s Past, #1)
author: Liu Cixin
my_review:
holy shit. chapter one hits you like a ton of bricks. I cried with the final words, as the daughter of the murdered professor found her advisor's freshly suicided body in the apartment she had pieced back together just before killing herself, wearing the lipstick and high heels that the revolutionaries had derided her for.

Unfortunately the rest of the book didn't live up to the first chapter.

title: Shards of Earth (The Final Architecture, #1)
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
my_review: action, action, action. a good book, but imo quite different from Children of Time. not as cerebral, although more politics and spy stuff

title: Children of Ruin (Children of Time, #2)
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
my_review: also very good. i don't think those octopuses could have achieved as much as they did with such mercurial nature. but the linguistic element was really neat, and the consciousness of the octopus was neat. not really enough time spent in the octopus point of view to find them convincing as a spacefaring species like i found the spiders.

title: For We Are Many (Bobiverse, #2)
author: Dennis E. Taylor
my_review:
These books are short, and they occasionally feel like they lack imagination or clear thinking, but I enjoy them anyway and definitely don't regret the quick fun reads. It's like scifi trash reading, lol.

As for my criticisms, the reliance on smashing drones was ridiculous. It would have been child's play to make some kind of projectile system when you have atom by atom 3d printers....of course, that would have ruined large bits of plot.

And the libraries. Bob was originally launched with only the faith libraries, and I originally thought that not getting libraries from the rest of humanity was an gross oversight, but then, wildly, in book 2 the author directly brought it up, how they only had faith records, *completely ignoring* the whole ass 15million human population they could have gotten digital libraries from... but yeah, anyway, there are a ton of things in the books i found dumb, but i still liked them enough to keep reading.

Sometimes the plot feels more like a checklist of cool scifi things we need to accomplish than a well-considered and engaging plot, although I still usually stay pretty engaged in all the sub stories. I imagine i'll read 1 or 2 more books and then get bored of this series.

title: Children of God (The Sparrow, #2)
author: Mary Doria Russell
my_review: sequel to the sparrow. worth reading to finish the plot, but still kinda lacks. I think the biggest thing for me is that it is not emotionally engaging. like, the plot has the potential to be soul shattering, but it just isn't. reading the 3 body problem right now and it takes my breath away in comparison.

title: The Sparrow (The Sparrow, #1)
author: Mary Doria Russell
my_review:
An exciting read, jumping between timelines and slowly building the relationships with a constant undercurrent of dread as the horrors are slowly revealed. I can't say that it really explores too many deep themes about intelligent life or strange societies other than to notice them. Feels more like a story about interesting things than an exploration of scifi themes? The premise is pretty cool tho. Space explorers make first contact with the cattle of the world. I guess it deals a lot with unfairness and misunderstanding and the uncaring cruelty of the world, of God.

A group of Jesuits visits the first known alien species. They had the best intentions, but somehow everything went horribly wrong. The book follows two timelines as we slowly learn what happened.

Present Day: only one of the crew has returned alive, and is horribly disfigured. We try to understand this horribly physically and mentally broken man.

Past: We seem him bright and alive, surrounded by his amazing colleagues, (who we unfortunately know died horrible deaths that we don’t know the details of yet)
genres: Science Fiction|Fiction|Book Club|Fantasy|Religion|Science Fiction Fantasy|Speculative Fiction
