title: A Short History of Nearly Everything
author: Bill Bryson
my_review: A quick and effortless read.  He draws you in with quirky stories of long-dead scientists while still managing to impart a surprising amount of general knowledge. I loved learning about how Newton shoved a knitting needle into his eye to establish the physical nature of sight, and how 18th century geologists were like a pack of bickering school children. It's been 11 or so years now, but I remember that I was very influenced by his and Simon Singh's writing styles when I created my own works.

my_review: Today, in late 2023, the resources of the internet make it trivially easy to learn the most advanced lockpicking techniques. Your choices were basically the MIT field guide, private forums, crappy half-baked websites, or the incredible resources of Deviant Ollam.

my_review: The recipes really bog down the audible version. Overall a pretty fun history of milk, but he fucks up enough basic science to make me question him. Like where he said that humans became antibiotic resistant as if it was the humans that were changing. Kinda makes me wonder how deeply he understands other subjects.

title: Down and Out in Paris and London
author: George Orwell
my_review: Such an interesting look into the past and into poverty. It feels so raw and surreal. Kind of hard to believe the attitudes. "it was dumb work, the is the kind of job women would do if they were strong enough" "you aren't fit to mop the floors of the brothel where you were born" The whole bit about pretending to eat at restraunts to keep up face. Or keeping an empty suitcase full of rocks so it would seem like you had clothes

title: Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly
author: Anthony Bourdain
my_review: if you only read one of bordain's, this is it. just so interesting and awesome. i re listened to parts of it with kumar in the car and didn't mind one bit. this makes me yearn for the foods of tokyo and france, and makes me know that I will never want to be inside a commercial kitchen.

title: Medium Raw: A Bloody Valentine to the World of Food and the People Who Cook (P.S.)
author: Anthony Bourdain
my_review: so cool to see how he felt about life after the fame. I wish that I had read this book second instead of first, so that I would understand the character references. I think it is in this book that he talks in detail about his depression and drug use, and it made me so sad to think how he thought that he had overcome this with the birth of his daughter, and yet to know that he still commited suicide. while living a life that I could only dream of

title: The Black Death: The World's Most Devastating Plague

my_review: excellent treatment of the subject

title: On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft
author: Stephen  King
my_review: I skipped the last bit that wasn't by king, but the parts that were by him were very intersting and fun to read. really makes me realize how much effort it is to be world class in an activity. the hundreds of writing submissions he had that were turned down. I could never come close to that with mere casual effort. some of his negative feelings about adverbs were also pretty interesting

my_review: quick, fun, and worth the read. great book for a car ride with a friend.

title: Blitzed: Drugs in the Third Reich
author: Norman Ohler
my_review: a little self-righteous and judgy at times, but overall a really excellent insight into all the drug culture of the reich. cocaine chewing gum, track marks on hitler's arms, doctor's wars, meth fueled advancements, meth-ruined sieges

title: The Forest of Wool and Steel
author: Natsu Miyashita
my_review: Wow, what a wonderful and captivating novel. It speaks to me like a gentle water colour, the words contemplatively flowing across the page. It has the stylistic feel of sangatsu no lion. Really loved it and would read again without hesitation. Gift from Mononita

title: The Farthest Shore (The Earthsea Cycle, Book 3)
author: Ursula K. Le Guin
my_review: So, I accidently read book 4 first, and it significantly spoiled book 3 for me. Unlike book 2 and 4, this one didn't really get me thinking at any length about deep subjects. I suppose it is about death, but I didn't find the author's treatment of the subject particularly interesting. The plot and characters also didn't particularly hold my interest. For me, this is the weakest of the first 4 books.

title: Tehanu (Earthsea Cycle, #4)
author: Ursula K. Le Guin
my_review: I was really drawn to the world-weary, powerless themes throughout the book. It's sort of as though the entire book was a narrative essay on the female condition. More often than not, it was sobering and slightly depressing. So much natural and interesting exploration of female powerlessness in a male society, as well as gender roles. So, my favorites list was 1, 4, 2, 3.

title: Eyes of the Void (The Final Architecture, #2)
author: Adrian Tchaikovsky
my_review: probably the best book of the trilogy. good pacing and plot etc. kinda weird that chris didn't kill the guy, thought that didn't make sense with her character

title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir
my_review: pretty good. fast read, satisfying story, fun plot, only a few inaccuracies. i thought the language gap was overcome too easily and the process, especially for difficult conceptual words, not explained well enough. it’s been 8 years or something since i read the martian, but iirc this book follows a very similar style. narrative driven by a series of technical problems that need overcoming. i had a few quibbles here and there with the science, but overall there were fun solutions with enjoyable characters. it was a pretty short read, and worth it for the time investment if you liked the martian.

title: The Hero of Ages (Mistborn, #3)
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review: I remember liking this series, and thinking that it seemed fully planned from start to finish. There were the tiniest details like the earring in book one that turned out to be incredibly important in book 3. However, I also remember telling Greg, "the first book had really, fucking garbage dialog. was hard for me to tolerate"

title: Dark Matter
author: Blake Crouch
my_review: this was actually pretty good. way more of a romantic focus that what I usually read. first half excellent, middle meh, ending good. the thing that got me in the middle was some painfully bad choices from the characters that clearly didn't line up with even slightly considered decisions. after the first bad experience, there is no reason to go way into a potential world that is obviously a dead end. peak inside a door, then don't waste any time and peek inside the next door. the book had a miserably pitiful justification of why they made the terrible decisions they made, with no logical, character-based, or technological limitation, only a transparent desire to squeeze action into the plot through forced narrative. plus some dumb throw-ins like how his phone didn't work across timelines...there's no way it wouldn't work. he should have bought a phone in the first timeline and just opened a door and called his wife in every new world. but anyway, the good ending made up for it and overall i liked the book.

title: Arcanum Unbounded: The Cosmere Collection
author: Brandon Sanderson
my_review: im actually not sure if I completely finished this, I may have only gotten halfway. but, i do remember liking it.

my_review: Weaker than the Mistborne books.

my_review: Excellent for self study. Audio is available on a free phone app, and excersizes can be done online. If you are choosing between the 2nd and 3rd edition, choose the 3rd. It makes real improvements in grammar explanations and usefuleness of the vocabulary lists. It is also a more polished work overall.

title: 初級日本語 げんき I[ワークブック](第3版) GENKI: An Integrated Course in Elementary Japanese I [Workbook] (3rd Edition) (Japanese Edition)

title: Life Ascending: The Ten Great Inventions of Evolution
author: Nick Lane
my_review: As usual, difficult to get through in audiobook format, but definitely a lot of interesting stuff in here. It's been a few years since reading Lane, but if I remember correctly, I liked this book more than The Vital Question, and found it more accessible.

title: The Vital Question: Energy, Evolution, and the Origins of Complex Life
author: Nick Lane
my_review: There's some great stuff in here, and the concepts are often fascinating, but holy cow is it hard to get through as an audiobook. I feel like this is a constant complaint for me with Lane's work.

my_review: Very cool. I especially liked learning about Ada Lovelace and other more ancient programers.

my_review: Not as good as Ghost in the Wires and not very actionable for a supposed guide.

my_review: It's been 8.5 years since I read this, but I remember being absolutely floored. Her haunting story sucked me in and gave me insights into places and cultures that at the time I was only vaguely aware of.

title: God Is Disappointed in You
author: Mark   Russell
my_review: Hilarious and irreligious retelling of the old testament. Really focuses on all the great stuff that was too shocking for Sunday school.

title: 配色事典―大正・昭和の色彩ノート (青幻舎ビジュアル文庫シリーズ) A Dictionary of Color Combinations
author: Sanzo Wada
my_review: Perfect little pocket book, but one must understand that it is just an endless collection of color swatches. I'd give it five stars, except they've made it very difficult to look up your favorite swatches in the index, and they could easily have put the RGB or HEX values on the actual page where the swatches appear.

title: Codex Seraphinianus
author: Luigi Serafini
my_review: Ridiculously cool. A huge book full of high quality art and a mysterious language, each quaint diagram is more intriguing than the last.

title: Ten Days in A Mad-House: Illustrated and Annotated: A First-Hand Account of Life At Bellevue Hospital on Blackwell's Island in 1887

my_review: haunting

title: I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream
author: Harlan Ellison
my_review: The specific story, I have No Mouth and I Must Scream is among my favorite short stories, with it's chilling helplessness.

title: The Movement: How I Got This Body By Never Going To The Gym In My Life.
author: Jack Garbarino
my_review: A little random and bogged down at times, but a hilarious concept

title: Animal Skulls: A Guide to North American Species
author: Mark Elbroch
my_review: Fantastic field guide to North American skulls. I have used it countless times to identify bones, and it is an invaluable resource.

title: Fun With A Pencil: How Everybody Can Easily Learn to Draw
author: Andrew Loomis
my_review: Excellent. This is a high-quality reprininting of an old classic (1939), and it's a joy to see the old art styles and follow along with Loomis's excellent teaching.

title: The Wild Trees: A Story of Passion and Daring
author: Richard   Preston
my_review: i remember this being quite good, but perhaps not amazing

title: Oxygen: The molecule that made the world (Popular Science)
author: Nick Lane
my_review: Read in Summer of 2012, review from memory in 2023. This book was an absolute slog to get through, but I remeber it having an amazing scientific perspective. I was constantly learning new things and having my mind blown.

title: Forged: Writing in the Name of God—Why the Bible's Authors Are Not Who We Think They Are
author: Bart D. Ehrman

title: The Gathering Storm (The Wheel of Time, #12)
author: Robert Jordan

title: Darwin on Trial
author: Phillip E. Johnson
my_review: When I was in college, I would occasionally date Christian girls who would give me these books explaining how evolution was a scam. Looking back through some old texts from 11 years ago, I see I had written 12 pages of rebuttals by the time I reached page 58/154. Needless to say, this book is terrible, and full of blatant lies and subtle misdirections. I will say that it introduced me to a funny quote from the 1880s: "Darwinian man, though well behaved, At best is just a monkey shaved."

title: The Code Book: The Science of Secrecy from Ancient Egypt to Quantum Cryptography
author: Simon Singh
my_review: Another excellent book by Simon. I bought this in the spy museum of DC and read it on the plane. My comparison point was Big Bang, which I had read a couple years earlier and loved. This is maybe not so great as Big Bang, but still a wonderful read.

title: Fallacy of Fine-Tuning: Why the Universe Is Not Designed for Us
author: Victor J. Stenger
my_review: It's been 11 years since I read it, and I wanna say that I DNF'd this book. It's a good topic that should have been 1/3 the length.

title: The Religion Virus: Why We Believe in God: An Evolutionist Explains Religion's Incredible Hold on Humanity
author: Craig A. James
my_review: Excellent concept to explore, but set against the backdrop of the other books I had read at the time (Selfish Gene and the entire Dawkins biology library, Carroll, Shubin, Hitchens, etc), I don't think I really needed a book length treatment of the subject. This was the sort of book that seemed like it could have been a chapter in a larger volume.

title: Cannibals and Kings: Origins of Cultures
author: Marvin Harris
my_review: I'm sure a lot of Marvin's specific theories may be out of date by now, but when I read this as an early college student 11 years ago, I remember being floored by the innovative clarity of his ideas.

title: Evolution: The Human Story
author: Alice Roberts
my_review: Books on human evolutionary history go out of date fast, as we discover new fossils, archeological sites, and make genetic discoveries. If I remember correctly, 11 years ago I went to a library or bookstore and looked at all their big evolution books and bought this one. It has excellent photos of the exact bones discovered for each species, alongside key information such as placement on the body, function, notes from researchers, tools discovered at digsites and much more. It's also got migration maps, notes on lifestyle speculation, and possible facial reconstructions. This is an excellent choice for someone wanting a modernized DK style picture and words book.

title: The Fifth Miracle: The Search for the Origin and Meaning of Life
author: Paul C.W. Davies
my_review: I read this near the end of a biology binge, and I think I was exhausted of the subject. It didn't leave much of an impact and I can't remember anything about the book 11 years later, writing this review.

title: Your Inner Fish: A Journey Into the 3.5-Billion-Year History of the Human Body
author: Neil Shubin
my_review: Very enjoyable and easy to read, with tons of neat stuff to teach about how our evolutionary legacy shapes our modern body patterns.
